(4) Whether any of the persons signing the application, or, if a corporation, any of the officers, have ever been convicted of a crime, other than for violation of traffic laws. (5) Whether a previous license issued to applicants or any of them by any state or subdivision thereof or by the federal government has been revoked, and the reasons therefor. (6) The length of residence of the applicant, and if such residence is less than one (1) year prior to the date of application, the last prior place of residence of the applicant. (7) A drawing to scale, showing the nearest church, school or college or by the affidavit of a registered surveyor that the proposed location of the business complies with the minimum distance requirements. (8) Each applicant for an alcoholic beverage license shall attach to his application evidence of ownership of the building or proposed building or a copy of the lease if the applicant is leasing the building. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-4. - Eligibility of applicant generally. No alcoholic beverage license shall be issued to: (1) Any person unless he is the manager or the person actually in charge of the daily operation of the business. Such person must have been a resident of the State of Georgia for at least one (1) year prior to the submission of the application for license and must be a citizen of the United States or a duly-registered foreign national. The applicant must continue to live in the State of Georgia as long as he/she holds an alcoholic beverage license. The applicant must be at least twenty-one (21) years of age. (2) A person who, by reason of reputation, character or mental or physical capacity, is not, in the judgment of the city council, a fit or qualified person to conduct such a business. (3) A person who has been convicted of a felony or a crime involving mortal turpitude or convicted or pled nolo contendere of a violation of any state, local or federal laws pertaining to the manufacture, possession, transportation, or sale of alcoholic beverages, or the taxability thereof, all within the last five (5) years. (4) A partnership, if any member of the partnership is disqualified under this section. (5) A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof is disqualified under this section. (6) A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent, unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the alcoholic beverage license holder. (7) A person who is the previous holder of an alcoholic beverage license and is, in the judgment and discretion of the city council, an unfit person to have a license because of the manner in which he conducted business thereunder, as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law or regulation relating to such business. (8) Any person as close kin as brothers or sisters, by blood or marriage, to one already holding the maximum two (2) licenses permitted under this division. (9) A person who is a full-time paid employee of the city or any elected or appointed official of the city or his or her spouse. (10) A location at which a previous alcoholic beverage license has been revoked or suspended, and where, in the judgment of the city council, the problems which have arisen from the operation of an alcoholic beverage license at such location indicate that it is not in the interest of public health, safety, welfare or morals that the sale of alcoholic beverages be permitted at such location. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-5. - Issuance of licenses. Issuance of licenses under this chapter are limited as follows: (1) No person shall hold a license in any retail category hereunder and a license under any wholesale category hereunder at the same time. (2) Licenses for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises shall be issued only to restaurants, provided, however, that such licenses may be issued to bars, pubs, taverns, public entertainment facilities or brew pubs located in the downtown overlay district. (3) Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, the sale of alcoholic beverages in the city is a privilege, and not a right, and the issuance of a license hereunder shall not create any property rights in the license holder. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-6. - Same—Payment of application fees. All applications for alcoholic beverage licenses shall be accompanied either by lawful money of the United States, certified check or cashier's check payable to the city for the proper amount of the investigation fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) payable in advance which shall not be refundable whether the license applied for is granted or denied. No investigation fee is charged for event permits, alcoholic beverage caterer, and special events facility licenses. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-7. - Application—Investigation/fingerprints. Upon receipt by the city license and permit office of any application for an alcoholic beverage license, or for the transfer of any such license, the office shall forward the same to the chief of police for investigation, who, following such investigation, shall recommend either approval or disapproval of the application. The city license and permit office shall then submit the application, with the approval or disapproval of the chief of police indicated thereon, to the city council. Every partner of a partnership applicant, every corporate officer, owner and manager of a place of business selling alcoholic beverages shall be fingerprinted by the GAPS system or any future replacement system before a license is issued under this chapter. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-8. - Prorated payment of license fees. The license fees provided for in this chapter for the manufacture or sale or offer for sale at wholesale or retail of alcoholic beverages are due and payable upon delivery of the license to the licensee. Any person who is doing business as of the first day of January or who begins to do business at any time during the month of January shall pay the full annual license fee. Any person who begins to do business in any month after January shall pay a prorated fee based on the number of months during which the licensee does business and any portion of a month shall count as a whole month. The prorated fee shall be rounded up to the nearest dollar amount. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-9. - False statements. The making of any untrue or misleading statement in an application for an alcoholic beverage license shall be sufficient cause for the refusal, suspension, revocation or cancellation of such license, as the city council deems proper. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-10. - Denial or revocation. Before the city council shall deny any application for a license under this article or shall revoke any existing license, the applicant or license holder, as the case may be, shall be given notice in writing from the city license and permit office to show cause before the city council at a time and place specified therein not less than two (2) days nor more than fourteen (14) days from the date of service of the notice, why said application for license should not be denied, or why said license should not be revoked, as the case may be, stating the grounds therefor, and at the appointed time and place the applicant or license holder shall have an opportunity to show cause, if any exists, why said application should not be denied or said license revoked, after which the city council shall take such action as it, in its judgment and discretion, shall deem warranted under the facts. No application for an alcoholic beverage license shall be acted upon by the city council except at a regular meeting of said council. A revocation hearing herein provided for need not be at a regular meeting of the city council, but may be at such time and place as shall be fixed in said notice. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-11. - Suspension, revocation, grounds. The following shall be grounds for the suspension and/or revocation of an alcoholic beverage license. Whether or not said grounds exist shall be determined by the city council in its sole discretion: (1) The violation by the license holder or his agents or employees of any provision of this chapter or of any state or federal law or regulation, except misdemeanors, or any ordinance of the city, other than traffic violations. The determination of whether any such violation has occurred shall be made by the city council, and an actual conviction in a court for such offense shall not be necessary in order to suspend or revoke the license. (2) The failure of the license holder or his employee to report promptly to the police department any violation of law or municipal ordinance, breach of the peace, disturbance or altercation resulting in violence occurring inside the premises. (3) Any conduct on the part of the license holder or his employee contrary to the public welfare, safety, health or morals. (4) Operating or conducting the business in a manner contrary to the public welfare, safety, health or morals, or in such manner as to constitute a nuisance. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-12. - Suspension pending hearing. The city council shall have the right, upon the recommendation of the chief of police, to suspend any alcoholic beverage license pending the hearing provided for in section 3-10 of this division, where, in the judgment of the city council, such action is necessary to protect the public health, safety, welfare and morals. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-13. - Change of location. The location named in the licensee's application shall not be changed without permission and approval of the city council upon written application made. Approvals as to change of location shall be at the discretion of the city council. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-14. - Sale of interest by licensee. Where an alcoholic beverage license holder is a partnership or a corporation, or one (1) or more partners as the case may be, may withdraw from the partnership or the corporation in favor of one (1) or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. The sale by a partner of his interest in the partnership to a person who is not at the time of the sale already a partner may constitute a ground for revocation of the license unless the new partner is a person qualified to hold a license, and unless the transaction is approved by the city council. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-15. - Transfer. All alcoholic beverage licenses shall be personal to the licensee to whom issued. Upon proper application and payment of the nonrefundable investigation fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00), the city council may permit the license to be transferred upon payment of a transfer fee equal to an amount prorated by the remaining term of the original license, but not to exceed one-half (½) of the original license fee, provided that the transferee meets all of the qualifications which would have been required had the transferee been an applicant for an alcoholic beverage license. Upon the death of any license holder, his personal representatives or his heirs may continue to operate under said license for the balance of the year without the payment of any fee, if otherwise qualified as license holders, or the license may be transferred to a qualified transferee within thirty (30) days after the condition of the estate of the deceased license holder will permit, upon payment of the above transfer fee. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-16. - Term; refund of fee. No license under this chapter shall be issued for less than a calendar year, or the remainder thereof, and in case of the revocation or surrender of such license before the expiration of such calendar year, the holder thereof shall not be entitled to receive any refund. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-17. - Expiration. All alcoholic beverage licenses shall expire at midnight on December 31 of the year in which issued except event permits which shall expire at the conclusion of the event. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-18. - Renewal. All applications for a renewal of an alcoholic beverage license issued for the ensuing year shall be treated as applications for new licenses, except that they need not be charged an investigation fee if there is no change in the manager, owner or other parties listed requiring investigation on the initial application. All renewals for alcoholic beverage licenses must be filed with the city license and permit office prior to November 15. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-19. - General regulations pertaining to all licenses. (a) Employment of underaged persons. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow or require a person under his employment and under the age of eighteen (18) to dispense, sell, serve or take orders for any alcoholic beverages. This section shall not prohibit persons under eighteen (18) years of age who are employed in supermarkets, convenience stores, or drug stores from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold for consumption off the premises. (b) License not transferrable to another location. Each license is issued for a specific location only and may not be transferred to another location without making a new application. (c) Compliance with regulations . Each license shall be subject to and comply with all ordinances and laws of the city, State of Georgia, and the United States of America. (d) Location. No licenses issued under this chapter shall be issued except for locations in the following zones as defined by the comprehensive zoning ordinance of the city: B-1, B-2, and I. Any license granted under this chapter shall also be considered a conditional use subject to the provisions of the comprehensive zoning ordinance of the city. (e) Interest of public employees. No license shall be granted under this chapter to any city, state or federal employee whose duties include the regulation or policing of alcoholic beverages or licenses, or any tax-collecting activity. (f) Inspection of books and accounts; reports. Upon demand by the director of finance, any person holding a license under this chapter from the city shall open to such official his place or places of business for the purpose of enabling such official to ascertain and gain such information as may be necessary for the determination of the proper classification of such license holder for license fee purposes and determination of the correct amount of license fee to which such person is subject. Upon demand by the director of finance, any person holding a license from the city shall furnish the city, during normal business hours, at such person's place of business, all books of account, invoices, papers, reports and memoranda containing entries showing amount of purchases, sale receipts, inventory or other information, from which the correct amount of the fee to which he is subject may be determined, including exhibition of bank deposit books, bank statements and copies of sales reports, and any other such document as the city may deem necessary. The city license and permit office shall send to each holder of a license to sell distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises a monthly report form containing such information as the director of finance may deem necessary to determine the licensee's compliance with this chapter, and said report form shall be completed and returned to the city by the twentieth day of the following month. Any person holding a license from the city shall secure, preserve, maintain and keep for a period of three (3) years the records and documents enumerated and referred to in this section. (g) False representation of age. It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely misrepresent his age in any manner whatsoever for the purposes of purchasing or otherwise acquiring any alcoholic beverage. (h) Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to: (1) Knowingly allow gambling of any kind or character to be carried on in his place of business. (2) Knowingly allow any person to frequent his place of business for the purpose of soliciting for prostitution. (3) Knowingly allow any criminal act to be perpetuated on the premises, such as the sale of drugs, sale of non-tax paid alcoholic beverages, sale of stolen property, or other offenses. (4) Fail to report to the police department at the earliest possible time known incidents of a criminal nature that happen in his premises. (5) Willfully withhold from any law enforcement agency any information pertaining to any crime that may have happened on his premises and to which he was a witness. (6) No person holding an alcoholic beverage license shall sell or give away, or permit the sale or gift to, or the procuring for, any alcoholic beverage to any person who is physically or mentally incapacitated due to the consumption of any alcoholic beverage. (i) Adding to, refilling bottles, misrepresentation as to quantity, etc. It shall be unlawful for a licensee hereunder or his agents to add to the contents of a bottle or to refill an empty bottle or in any manner to misrepresent the quantity, quality or brand name of any beverage licensed hereunder. Provided however that "growlers" shall be allowed to be filled and refilled by any licensee authorized to sell malt beverages by the package. The filling of growlers by means of a tapped keg shall not constitute the breaking of a package as contemplated by O.C.G.A. section 3-3-26. Growlers may only be filled from kegs procured by the licensee from a duly licensed wholesaler. Growlers may be filled and made available for retail sale only if properly cleaned and securely sealed with a tamperproof cap or seal. (j) Alcohol promotions. No licensee or employee or agent of a licensee shall engage in any of the following practices in connection with the sale or other disposition of alcoholic beverages: (1) The giving away of any ticket, token, or any other item that can be exchanged for any alcoholic beverages with the sale of any other alcoholic beverage. (2) The sale of two (2) or more alcoholic beverages for a single price, or the sale of one (1) alcoholic beverage with a ticket, token, or any other item redeemable for a subsequent alcoholic beverage. Also prohibited hereunder is the sale of all such beverages a customer can or desires to drink at a single price. (k) Suspension of sales during civil emergency. The mayor, or the chief of police in the absence of the mayor, may, upon determining that there is an immediate danger of civil disorder or natural disaster or any other immediate threat to the public peace and order, by executive order suspend the sales of all beverages licensed under this chapter until such danger or threat has passed and for a reasonable period of time thereafter. (l) Reserved. (m) On-premises entertainment. (1) No holder of a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages issued hereunder shall knowingly allow any performance or entertainment or act on the licensed premises which, when applied to contemporary standards, the dominant theme taken as a whole appeals to the prurient interests or is licentious or obscene. This provision shall be construed so as to be consistent with the Winder Adult Entertainment Ordinance [chapter 3.5, article II, of this Code]. (2) It shall be unlawful to permit on the premises so licensed any contest or form of entertainment which consists of the wetting or soaking of the upper torso of a female or the pelvic areas of a male or female. This provision shall be construed so as to be consistent with the Winder Adult Entertainment Ordinance [chapter 3.5, article II, of this Code]. (3) It shall be unlawful to permit on the premises so licensed any contest or form of entertainment which consists of fighting, boxing, wrestling or other violent physical contact sport or event. (4) Upon the violation hereof by any such licensee, its license may, after a hearing before the judge of municipal court, be revoked, suspended, or put on probation under conditions. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12; Ord. ( W-20-17 ) of 11-14-17) Sec. 3-20. - Building. No alcoholic beverage license shall be issued to any person unless the building in which the business will be located is or unless proposed plans and specifications and a building permit of a proposed building to be built are attached to the application. The completed building or the proposed building shall comply with this Code of Ordinances, regulations of the state revenue commissioner and the laws of the state. The proposed building shall also be subject to final inspection and approval, when completed, by the building inspector. Each building in which the business will be located shall contain sufficient lighting so that the building itself and the premises on all sides of the building are readily visible at all times. Premises licensed for sale of alcoholic beverages by the package shall be lighted so as to reveal the inside retail area of the building and so as to reveal all of the outside premises of said building. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-21. - Proximity to school, churches or other sites. No alcoholic beverages shall be sold or offered for sale in violation of O.C.G.A. section 3-3-21 provided, however, that the provisions of that section shall not apply as to consumption of alcohol by the drink on premises within the city limits as established by the city council from time to time so that within the city limits there shall be no distance requirements as to the consumption of alcohol by the drink on premises as set forth in that section. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12; Ord. ( W-10-17 ) of 5-2-17) Sec. 3-22. - Signs. The city shall provide for all retail licensees under this article a decalcomania sign to post on the premises of their places of business. Licensees shall not post more than one (1) authorized sign at their places of business and shall not display outside signs or signs in their windows of any other type which advertise either brand, product or price. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-23. - Drive-in window. No license holder under this article shall sell any alcoholic beverages through or by means of a drive-in window. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-24. - Deliveries. It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this article to make deliveries of any alcoholic beverage by the package or drink beyond the boundaries of the premises covered by the license. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-25. - Time of operation. (a) No alcoholic beverages shall be sold by the bottle, package or by the drink in the city on Christmas Day or Sunday except as provided in this section. On days when business is permitted, the sale of alcoholic beverages shall cease at 1:55 a.m. and shall not resume before 6:00 a.m. except on Saturdays, when the sale of alcoholic beverages shall cease at 1:55 a.m. Sunday morning and shall not resume before 6:00 a.m. on the following Monday morning. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the package sale of malt beverages, wine and/or distilled spirits shall be permitted on Sundays between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. (b) Notwithstanding subsection (a), the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be lawful on Sundays from 12:30 p.m. until 1:55 a.m. Monday morning in any licensed restaurant. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-26. - Unlawful possession of open containers. It shall be unlawful for any person to carry about on any street or public place in the city, either upon his person or in any vehicle operated or owned by him, or occupied by him, any open containers of alcoholic beverages or to possess such beverages in an open container on the premises but outside any establishment holding a permit for the sale thereof. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-27. - Allowing on-premises alcoholic beverages purchased elsewhere. No alcoholic beverage licensee for the sale of alcoholic beverages or any other business shall authorize or permit any patron or customer to bring on said property alcoholic beverages purchased elsewhere. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-28. - Misrepresenting age. It shall be unlawful for any minor to misrepresent his or her age in any manner whatsoever, in order to acquire alcoholic beverages. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-29. - Sales to minors. Any alcoholic beverage license holder under this chapter who shall sell alcoholic beverages to a minor shall be fined a maximum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and a minimum of thirty-day suspension of the license for the first offense. For the second offense, the holder shall be fined one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and a revocation of the license. For the purposes of this section, sales by either the alcoholic beverage license holder or any employee or agent of such holder shall be deemed a violation by the holder of the license. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-30. - Acquiring for minors. No person shall knowingly and intentionally act as agent to purchase or acquire any alcoholic beverages for or on behalf of a minor, or otherwise procure for or furnish to a minor any alcoholic beverages, except for medical purposes upon the prescription of a duly licensed physician under the laws of the state. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-31. - Conduct on premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit on any premises licensed under this chapter any acts which are contrary to law or subversive of the public morals. If the premises are commonly resorted to for the commission of such acts of the proprietor's knowledge and should in reason know what is occurring and does nothing to prevent it, he shall be guilty of a violation of this section. The person in charge of such premises at the time that such acts are being committed shall immediately report such conduct to the police department. Minors are not allowed on the premises of bars, pubs or taverns. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-32. - Closing times. (a) All premises upon which alcoholic beverages are sold by the bottle or package not for consumption on the premises and not in conjunction with another authorized business shall be closed and empty of customers between the hours of 1:55 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. except on Sundays when said premises shall be closed between the hours of 1:55 a.m. Sunday morning and 6:00 a.m. the following Monday morning. Notwithstanding the foregoing, premises where malt beverages, wine and/or distilled spirits are sold by the package may be open on Sundays between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. (b) All premises upon which alcoholic beverages are sold for consumption on the premises shall be closed and empty of customers between the hours of 1:55 a.m. and 6:00 a.m., except on Sundays, when said premises shall be closed between the hours of 1:55 a.m. Sunday morning and 6:00 a.m. the following Monday morning. (c) Notwithstanding subsection (b), restaurants, as defined in section 3-1 of this chapter, whereupon alcoholic beverages are sold for consumption on the premises shall be allowed to be open on Sundays from 12:30 p.m. until 1:55 a.m. the following Monday morning. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-33. - Possession of alcoholic beverages upon which taxes have not been paid. (a) An individual may possess and transport in this city the following quantities of alcoholic beverages upon which Georgia taxes have not been paid: (1) In the case of distilled spirits, not in excess of one-half (½) gallon. (2) In the case of malt beverages, not in excess of one thousand four hundred forty (1,440) ounces or five (5) standard cases of twelve-ounce cans or its equivalent. (3) In the case of wine, not in excess of one-half (½) gallon. (b) The provisions of this section shall apply only with respect to alcoholic beverages purchased by the possessor outside of this state in accordance with the laws of the place where purchased and brought into this state by the purchaser. The burden of proof that the beverages were purchased outside this state and in accordance with the laws of the place where purchased shall in all cases be upon the possessor of the beverages. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-34. - Catered functions. (a) An authorized catered function is any event at which an alcoholic beverage caterer sells alcoholic beverages and a meal is served. (b) No authorized catered function shall take place on the premises of any alcoholic beverage licensee who is not also the caterer for the function. (c) All alcoholic beverage licensees for consumption on premises must also have an alcoholic beverage caterers license in order to sell or serve the type of alcoholic beverages for which they are licensed on premises at any authorized catered function or event off-premises. Alcoholic beverage caterers licenses can only be issued to licensees that already hold a license for consumption on premises. (d) All alcoholic beverage caterer licensees must obtain an event permit from the City of Winder prior to selling or serving any alcoholic beverages at any authorized catered function or event. The application shall include the name of the caterer, the date, address, and time of the event; and the licensed alcoholic beverage caterer's license number. When the caterer is licensed by a local government other than the City of Winder, an event permit fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be charged and the city shall levy local excise taxes on the total quantity of alcoholic beverages brought into the city by the caterer. (e) At any event at which alcoholic beverages are served, sold or offered for sale, the license holder shall provide a City of Winder uniformed police officer for safety and security purposes beginning at the time the first drink is poured or served and until fifteen (15) minutes following the close of the event. At least one (1) officer shall be provided for the first two hundred (200) persons in attendance and at least one (1) additional officer for every additional one hundred (100) persons in attendance. (f) All persons employed at the alcoholic catered event must be at least twenty-one (21) years of age. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-35. - Exception for city sponsored events. (a) Whenever the city council shall determine that the public interest would be served by such action, the council may designate by resolution that the provisions of ordinance section 3-26 shall not apply to city sponsored events at such place, at such time and in such manner as specifically designated by resolution. (b) In the event that the city council does enact a resolution excepting a specific event from the provisions of ordinance section 3-26, the following provisions shall control in that instance: (1) Two-drink on-street limit. Any establishment licensed to dispense alcoholic beverages by the drink for consumption on the premises is authorized to dispense beer or wine only (and not distilled spirits) in a paper or plastic cup, or other container other than a can, bottle, or glass, away from or for removal from the premises; provided, however, that no establishment shall dispense to any person more than two (2) such alcoholic beverages at a time away from or for removal from the premises, and no person shall possess or remove at one (1) time more than two (2) such alcoholic beverages from the licensed premises. A single one-half (½) carafe container shall be considered to be two (2) such alcoholic beverages. Employees of licensed establishments, if on duty and not consuming alcoholic beverages, may exceed this limit during the performance of their duties, if allowed by the resolution. (2) Size limited to sixteen ounces for single beverage or one-half carafe for wine. No container in which beer or wine is dispensed pursuant to this section shall exceed sixteen (16) fluid ounces in size for a single drink; provided, however, that wine may be dispensed in a one-half (½) carafe container not exceeding twenty (20) fluid ounces in size. No person shall hold in his or her possession on the streets and sidewalks, in parks and squares, or in other public places within the defined area any open alcoholic beverage container which exceeds the restrictions contained in this section. (3) Drinking from can, bottle, or glass prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or attempt to drink any alcoholic beverage from a can, bottle, or glass or to possess in an open can, bottle, or glass any alcoholic beverage on the streets, sidewalks, rights-of-way, and parking lots, whether public or private. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-36. - Violations. Any alcoholic beverage license holder or his agents or employees violating this chapter shall forfeit his privilege of doing business in the city, and the alcoholic beverage license theretofore granted by the city may be revoked or suspended; and in addition thereto such person shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-8 for violations of this Code, or such other penalties that may be provided for in this chapter. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-37. - Reporting of disciplinary actions. (a) Definitions. Bar, for the purposes of this section, means any licensee that derives seventy-five (75) percent or more of total annual gross revenue from the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. Disciplinary action means any citation or arrest arising out of the violation of any law, rule, regulation, resolution or ordinance of the city relating to the manufacture, distribution, sale or possession of alcoholic beverages against a licensee, an employee of a licensee, or any person holding a financial interest in the license of the licensee on the premises or place of business or any licensee. Licensee, for the purposes of this section, means any entity licensed by the city that operates a bar. (b) Reporting. Within forty-five (45) days following any disciplinary action against a licensee taken by any officer, department, agency or instrumentality of the city, the city clerk, or the clerk's designee, shall report the disciplinary action and the identity of the licensee to the Georgia Department of Revenue. (Ord. ( W-7-16 ) of 9-22-16) Secs. 3-38—3-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DISTILLED SPIRITS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 3-51. - Closing of business by police—Generally. The chief of police or any police department shift commander on duty at the time shall have the authority to close any location holding a distilled spirits license either by the package or for consumption on premises for a period not in excess of twenty-four (24) hours in the event there shall occur on the premises any violation of law or municipal ordinance, breach of the peace, disturbance or altercation resulting in violence or other occurrence which is contrary to the public health, welfare, safety or morals when, in the judgment of the chief of police or said shift commander, such action is necessary to protect the public health, welfare, safety or morals. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-52. - Location of business generally. No distilled spirits license shall be granted: (1) For a location not suitable in the judgment and discretion of the city council because of traffic congestion, general character of the neighborhood or by reason of the effect which such an establishment would have on the adjacent and surrounding properties, or on the neighborhood. (2) For a location within an area where, in the judgment of the city council, the number of alcoholic beverage licenses already granted makes it contrary to the public interest and welfare. (3) For a location at which the operation of the proposed business would be in violation of the zoning ordinance of the city. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-53. - Minors on premises. No person who holds a retail distilled spirits package sale license, or any employee or agent of such holder, shall allow any minor to be in, frequent, or loiter about the licensed premises unless such minors are accompanied by a parent or a legal guardian. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-54. - Wholesale excise tax. Wholesale dealers of distilled spirits shall pay an excise tax hereby levied on the sale of distilled spirits in the amount of eighty cents ($0.80) per gallon. Said excise tax shall be paid by persons selling liquors to retail licensees by the tenth day of each month following the month in which deliveries were made. Copies of the summary of sales showing deliveries by each supplier to retailers shall be furnished to the city clerk with each monthly payment. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Secs. 3-55—3-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE
Sec. 3-61. - Types of distilled spirits licenses. The types of distilled spirits licenses shall be: (a) Manufacturer; (b) Wholesaler; (c) Retail by the package; and (d) Retail for consumption on premises. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-62. - Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture or sell or offer for sale at wholesale or retail in the city any distilled spirits without having obtained the license required in this chapter. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-63. - State law. No license shall be issued under this article if the granting of such license would constitute a violation of state law or regulations. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-64. - Number of licenses. No business shall be licensed under this division for operation by any person already holding the maximum two (2) licenses or having beneficial interest in any corporation holding two (2) such licenses. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-65. - Retailers and wholesalers separate. It shall be unlawful for any person to hold a distilled spirits retail dealer's license who also has any direct financial interest in any wholesale distilled spirits business. It shall be unlawful for the holder of any distilled spirits retail dealer's license to accept or receive financial aid or assistance from the holder of any distilled spirits manufacturer's or wholesale dealer's license. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-66. - Effect of license—Manufacturer. A manufacturer's license under this article will entitle the licensee to manufacture only distilled spirits, and at one (1) location only. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-67. - Same—Wholesale dealer. A wholesale dealer's license under this article will entitle the licensee to sell only distilled spirits and only in the original unbroken container, to persons holding a retail license for the sale of distilled spirits for the purpose of resale only. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-68. - Effect of retail dealer's license—Generally. A retail dealer (sale by package only on licensed premises) license under this article will entitle the licensee to sell only distilled spirits, at one (1) location only, and only in the original and unopened container, and shall not permit the opening of containers in the package store where sold, and shall not permit the drinking of the contents of said containers in the package store where sold. All distilled spirits possessed by a licensee shall be kept in the package store, and no retailer's place of business shall have more than one (1) entrance, which must open on a public street or pedestrian way of a planned shopping center, and such place of business shall have no other entrance except as approved by state law, and shall contain no vestibule, closet, booth, room or other place where persons may consume alcoholic beverages. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-69. - Same—Connecting premises; windows. The place of business operated under a retail dealer's license for distilled spirits by the package shall not be operated in conjunction with or open into or have access to or from any lunchroom, dining room, dance hall or store. The windows in such retail place of business shall not be obstructed or obscured, but shall be so arranged that a passerby on the street can view the premises of such retailer by looking through windows opening onto such street. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-70. - Same—Additional rooms. A holder of a retail dealer's license for distilled spirits by the package shall be allowed to construct a restroom for the use of owners and employees only, an office of transparent material clearly visible from everywhere in the package store and a storage area in each licensed package store. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Secs. 3-71—3-80. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - MIXED DRINK EXCISE TAX
Sec. 3-81. - Definitions. For the purpose of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them below except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: City: The City of Winder, Georgia. Distilled spirits or liquor: Any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than twenty-one (21) percent alcohol by volume, including, but not limited to, all fortified wines. Drink: Any alcoholic beverage served for consumption on the premises that may or may not be diluted by any other liquid. Due date: The twentieth day after the close of the monthly period for which tax is to be computed. Licensee: Any person who holds a license from the city to sell distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises. Monthly period: The calendar months of any year. Person: An individual, firm, partnership, joint, venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative non profit membership, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular member, excepting the United States of America, the State of Georgia, and any political subdivision of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax provided herein. Purchase price: The consideration received for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink valued in money, whether received in cash or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the licensee to the purchaser, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. Purchaser: Any person who orders and gives present or future consideration for any distilled spirits by the drink. Return: Any return filed or required to be filed as provided in this division. Tax: The tax imposed by this division. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-82. - Administration generally. (a) The director of finance or his authorized representative shall administer and enforce the provisions of this division for the levy and collection of the tax imposed hereby. (b) The director of finance shall have the authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article or other laws of the city for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this division and the collection of the taxed hereunder. (c) Every licensee shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the director of finance may require. (d) The director of finance or his designee may examine the books, paper, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any licensee liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the licensee, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. (e) In the administration of the provisions of this division, the director of finance may require the filing of reports by any person having in such person's possession or custody information relating to the sales of distilled spirits which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the finance department when required and shall set forth the price charged for each sale, the date of the sale and such other information as the director of finance may require. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-83. - Imposed rate. There is hereby imposed and levied upon every sale of distilled spirits purchased by the drink in the city a tax in the amount of three (3) percent of the purchase price of said drink. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-84. - Collection by licensee. Every licensee or his agent is hereby authorized and directed to collect the tax imposed by this division from the purchasers of distilled spirits by the drink sold within his licensed premises. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-85. - Payment; returns, collection fees; penalties and interest for late payments. (a) All amounts of such taxes shall be due and payable monthly to the finance department of the city on or before the twentieth day of the next succeeding monthly period. (b) The remittance of the taxes collected should be on a return which shall include gross receipts from the sale of distilled spirits by the drink, the amount of tax collected or due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the director of finance. (c) Payments received after the twentieth date of the month shall be assessed a penalty of ten (10) percent of the amount due but not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month or any part thereof. (d) Licensees collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of deduction in submitting, reporting, and payment of the amount due, if the amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. section 48-8-50. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-86. - Determination of deficiency amount. (a) If the director of finance is not satisfied with the return of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any licensee he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One (1) or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one (1) or more monthly periods. (b) The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month or fraction thereof from the due date of the taxes. (c) In making the determination, the finance department may offset overpayment, for a period or in periods, against penalties and against the interest on underpayment. The interest on overpayment shall be computed in the manner set forth in subsection (b) above. (d) If any part of deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to negligence or disregard of rules and regulations, a penalty amount of ten (10) percent per month shall be added to the amount of the deficiency. (e) If any part of deficiency for which a deficiency determination has been made is due to fraud or an intent to evade any provisions of this chapter or other authorized rules and regulations, a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of the deficiency shall be added to the amount of the deficiency. (f) The director of finance, or authorized representative, shall give to the licensee written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the licensee at the address as it appears in the records of the director of the finance. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee. (g) Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of deficiency determination shall be mailed within three (3) years after the twentieth day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined or within three (3) years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-87. - Determination upon failure to file return. (a) If any licensee fails to make a return, the director of the finance shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the licensee for the sale of distilled spirits by the drink at said licensee's pouring outlet. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into possession of the finance department. Upon the basis of this estimate, the director of finance shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid the city, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty equal to ten (10) percent thereof, but not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). One (1) or more determinations may be made for one (1) or for more than one (1) period. Written notice shall be given in the manner prescribed in subsection 3-86(f). (b) The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month or fraction thereof from the twentieth day of the month that any portion thereof should have been returned, until the date of payment. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-88. - Overpayment. If the licensee determines that he has overpaid a tax, penalty or interest, or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the director of finance, the licensee will have three (3) years from the date of payment to file a claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which the claim is founded. If the claim is approved by the director of finance, the excess amount paid the city may be credited on any amount then due payable from the persons by whom it was paid. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-89. - Purchasers or successors of business. (a) If any licensee liable for any amount under this division sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the director of finance showing that the city has been paid or a certificate stating no amount is due. (b) If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold from the purchase price as required, he shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-90. - Legal action to collect. At any time within three (3) years after any tax or any amount of tax is required to be collected becomes due and payable and at any time within three (3) years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the director of finance may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect the amount the delinquent tax, together with penalties, interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-91. - Revocation of license. The failure to pay the above prescribed tax shall render the licensee liable therefore subject to revocation of their alcoholic beverages license in accordance with the procedures set forth in chapter 3, article I. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-92. - Penalty. (a) Any licensee or person violating any of the provisions in this division shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 3-36 of this Code. Any licensee or other person who fails to furnish any return required by the director of finance or who renders a false or fraudulent return shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as aforesaid. (b) Any person who fails to pay any taxes due under this division shall not be permitted to renew his occupation tax certificate or alcoholic beverage license until all said taxes have been paid in full. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Secs. 3-93—3-99. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - MALT BEVERAGES DIVISION 1. - EXCISE TAX
Sec. 3-100. - Excise tax—Imposed. There is hereby imposed and levied an excise tax on malt beverages, in addition to the excise taxes levied by the state, in the sum of five cents ($0.05) per twelve (12) ounces, or proportionately thereof, so as to graduate the tax on bottles, cans and containers of various sizes. The excise tax on tap or draft malt beverages shall be in the sum of six dollars ($6.00) for each container sold as specified in this section, containing not more than fifteen and one-half (15½) gallons and at a like rate for fractional parts. The excise tax shall be imposed upon and shall be paid by the licensed wholesale dealer in malt beverages. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Secs. 3-101—3-105. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE
Sec. 3-106. - Types of beer, ale, or malt beverage licenses. Licenses for the sale of beer, ale and other malt beverages shall be of three (3) kinds, to wit: (1) Manufacturer; (2) Wholesaler; (3) Retail by the package; (4) Retail for consumption on premises; and (5) Brew pubs. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-107. - Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture or sell or offer for sale at wholesale or retail in the city any beer, ale or other malt beverages without having obtained the license required in this chapter. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-108. - Effect of license—Manufacturer. A manufacturer's license under this division will entitle the licensee to manufacture only malt beverages, at one (1) location only. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-109. - Same—Wholesale dealer. A wholesale dealer's license under this division will entitle the licensee to sell only malt beverages, and only in the original unbroken container, to persons holding a retail license for the sale of malt beverages for the purpose of resale only. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-110. - Effect of retail dealer's license—Generally. A retail dealer license for sale by the package under this article will entitle the licensee to sell only malt beverages, at one (1) location only, and only in the original and unopened container, and shall not permit the opening of containers in the package store where sold, and shall not permit the drinking of the contents of said containers in the package store where sold. All malt beverages possessed by a licensee shall be kept on the premises. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-111. - Effect of consumption license—Generally. A consumption license under this article will entitle the licensee to sell only malt beverages at only one (1) location, and only by the drink for consumption on the premises. such sale is authorized in restaurants and private clubs, and in bars, pubs, taverns, brew pubs and public entertainment facilities in the downtown overlay district. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-112. - Ancillary growler malt beverage tasting license. (a) The holder of a malt beverages package sales license shall be eligible for an ancillary growler malt beverage tasting license to provide samples of malt beverages offered for sale to customers under the conditions set forth in this section. (b) Samples shall not exceed two (2) ounces per sample, and no customer shall consume more than ten (10) ounces per day. Sample shall be poured only by the licensee or his employees. (c) No open containers shall be removed from the licensed premises. (d) Growler malt beverage sampling and tasting is only permitted within the enclosed interior portion of the premises. The premises shall not be used for the sale of distilled spirits. (e) Minors under the age of twenty-one (21) are not allowed in the tasting portion of the premises. (f) Holders of an ancillary growler malt beverage tasting license shall not charge for samples or tastings. (g) The annual fee for an ancillary growler malt beverage tasting license fee shall be set and may be revised from time to time by the mayor and council. ( Ord. (W-3-15) of 6-2-15 ) Secs. 3-113—3-115. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - WINES DIVISION 1. - EXCISE TAX
Sec. 3-116. - Excise tax—Amounts. In addition to the charges levied in this article for a retail license, an excise tax is hereby levied on the sale of wines in the following amounts: (1) On wines produced within the state, wholly from fruits and berries grown within the state, having an alcoholic strength of not more than fourteen (14) percent alcohol by volume, eighty cents ($0.80) per gallon and a proportionate tax at like rates on all fractional parts of a gallon. (2) On wines produced from fruits and berries grown without the state, whether produced within or without the state, having an alcoholic strength of not more than fourteen (14) percent alcohol by volume, eighty cents ($0.80) per gallon and a proportionate tax at like rates on all fractional parts of a gallon. (3) On wines produced within the state, wholly from fruits and berries grown within the state, having an alcoholic strength of more than fourteen (14) percent alcohol by volume, eighty cents ($0.80) per gallon and a proportionate tax at like rates on all fractional parts of a gallon. (4) On wines produced within the state, wholly from fruits and berries grown within the state, to which wine spirits produced from without the state have been added, having an alcoholic strength of more than fourteen (14) percent alcohol by volume, eighty cents ($0.80) per gallon and a proportionate tax at like rates on all fractional parts of a gallon. (5) On wines produced from fruits and berries grown without the state, whether produced within or without the state, having an alcoholic strength of more than fourteen (14) percent alcohol by volume, eighty cents ($0.80) per gallon and a proportionate tax at like rates on all fractional parts of a gallon. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-117. - Same—Payment. The excise tax levied in the preceding section shall be paid by persons selling wines to retail licensees by the tenth day of each month following the month in which deliveries were made. Copies of the summary of sales showing deliveries by each supplier to retailers shall be furnished to the city finance director with each monthly payment. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Secs. 3-118, 3-119. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE
Sec. 3-120. - Types of wine licenses. Licenses for the sale of wines shall be of four (4) kinds, to wit: (1) Manufacturer; (2) Wholesaler; (3) Retail by the package; and (4) Retail for consumption on premises. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-121. - Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture or sell or offer for sale at wholesale or retail in the city any wine beverages without having obtained the license required in this chapter. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-122. - Effect of license—Manufacturer. A manufacturer's license under this division will entitle the licensee to manufacture only wines, at one (1) location only. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-123. - Same—Wholesale dealer. A wholesale dealer's license under this division will entitle the licensee to sell only wines, and only in the original unbroken container, to persons holding a retail license for the sale of wines for the purpose of resale only. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-124. - Effect of retail dealer's license—Generally. A retail dealer license for sale by the package under this article will entitle the licensee to sell only wines, at one (1) location only, and only in the original and unopened container, and shall not permit the opening of containers in the package store where sold, and shall not permit the drinking of the contents of said containers in the package store where sold. All wines possessed by a licensee shall be kept on the premises. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-125. - Effect of consumption license—Generally. A consumption license under this article will entitle the licensee to sell only wine, having an alcoholic strength of no greater than twenty (20) percent alcohol by volume, at only one (1) location, and only by the drink for consumption on the premises. Such sale is authorized in restaurants and private clubs, and in bars, pubs, taverns, brew pubs and public entertainment facilities in the downtown overlay district. A partially consumed bottle of wine purchased with a meal from a restaurant and resealed may be removed from the restaurant by a patron as permitted by O.C.G.A. section 3-6-4 and Ga. Reg. 40-6-253(2). (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-126. - Same—Unopened containers. A consumption license under this division does not permit the sale of wine in unopened containers. The sale of wine in unopened containers shall require the additional licenses otherwise provided by law, and the license holder must otherwise comply with the laws pertaining thereto. It shall be unlawful for the holder of a consumption license to sell or permit the sale of unopened bottles or packages of wine at the same location where he operates his consumption license. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-127. - Ancillary wine tasting license. (a) The holder of a wine package license shall be eligible for an ancillary wine tasting license to provide samples of wine offered for sale to customers under the conditions set forth in this section. (b) Samples shall not exceed two (2) ounces per sample, and no customer shall consume more than ten (10) ounces per day. (c) Wine bottles shall be opened only by the licensee or his employees and samples shall only be poured by the licensee or his employees. (d) No open containers of wine shall be removed from the licensed premises. (e) Wine sampling and tasting is only permitted within the enclosed interior portion of the premises. The premises shall not be used for the sale of distilled spirits. (f) Minors under the age of twenty-one (21) are not allowed in the tasting portion of the premises (g) Holders of an ancillary wine tasting permit shall not charge for samples or tastings. (h) The annual fee for an ancillary wine tasting license fee shall be set and may be revised from time to time by the mayor and council. ( Ord. (W-3-15) of 6-2-15 ) Secs. 3-128—3-129. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - SPECIAL EVENT FACILITY LICENSE
Sec. 3-130. - Special events license required. Any owner of a special events facility wishing to sell or offer for sale malt beverages or wines for consumption on the premises shall obtain a license required by this article which shall supplemental to and in addition to any other alcoholic beverage license required by this chapter. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-131. - State law. No license shall be issued under this article if the granting of such license would constitute a violation of state law or regulations. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-132. - Number of licenses. No business shall be licensed under this article to any person or entity already holding a maximum of two (2) licenses under this chapter. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-133. - Application requirements. Alcoholic beverage licenses issued under this article shall only allow the sale of ale, beer, malt beverages and wine for sale for consumption only on the premises of the special events facility for which the license is issued. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-134. - Limitations. (a) At any special event at which alcoholic beverages are sold or offered for sale, the license holder shall provide a City of Winder uniformed police officer for safety and security purposes beginning at the time the first drink is poured or served and until fifteen (15) minutes following the close of the event. At least one (1) officer shall be provided for the first two hundred (200) persons in attendance and at least one (1) additional officer for every additional one hundred (100) persons in attendance. (b) The City of Winder Fire Chief or his designee, the City of Winder Building Inspector or his designee and the City of Winder Police Chief or his designee shall recommend to the city administrator any additional limitations to the license which they deem necessary to protect public health, safety and welfare for any special events at which alcoholic beverages will be sold or offered for sale. The city administrator shall present any special conditions or limitations to the city council. The city council may incorporate such limitations on the license when granted. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Secs. 3-135—3-139. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - LICENSES IN DOWNTOWN OVERLAY DISTRICT
Sec. 3-140. - Bar, pub, tavern, public entertainment facility and brew pub licenses. Any owner of a bar, pub, tavern, public entertainment facility or a brew pub wishing to sell or offer alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises and located within the downtown overlay district shall obtain a downtown overlay district license which shall be supplemental to and in addition to any other alcoholic beverage license required by this chapter. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-141. - Hours of operation. Bars, pubs, taverns or public entertainment facilities that do not otherwise qualify as a restaurant or brew pub must be closed between the hours of 1:55 a.m. on Sunday morning and 6:00 a.m. the following Monday morning. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Sec. 3-142. - State law. No license shall be issued under this article if the granting of such license would constitute a violation of state law or regulations. (Ord. (W-10-12) of 9-11-12) Secs. 3-143—3-149. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - SALES AT CITY GOLF COURSE
Sec. 3-150. - [Regulations]. (a) The city is authorized to sell at retail, food and drink and malt beverages, wine and distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises at any public golf course owned and operated by the city. (b) The provisions of article I, sections 3-2 through 3-24, inclusive, and section 3-26 of this chapter shall not apply to the sale of alcoholic beverages at such city owned and operated golf courses. The provision of article II, III and IV of this chapter shall not apply to the sale of alcoholic beverages at such city owned and operated golf courses. (c) The hours of sale of alcoholic beverages at city owned and operated golf courses shall be the same as restaurants as provided section 3-25. (d) The provisions of sections 3-27 through 3-31, inclusive, of this chapter shall apply to city owned and operated golf courses. (e) The golf course manager shall be the license holder for the city. (Ord. (W-10-13) of 9-10-13)

div.head: Chapter 3.5 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 3.5-1. - Amusement device code adopted. The latest edition of the Standard Amusement Device Code, as adopted and amended by the state department of community affairs, is hereby adopted by reference as though it were copied herein fully. (Ord. (W-1-97) of 3-4-97) Editor's note— Ord. (W-1-97) of Mar. 4, 1997, did not specifically amend the Code; hence inclusion of the above provisions as § 3.5-1 was at the discretion of the editor. Secs. 3.5-2—3.5-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. W-02-05, adopted June 7, 2005, delete Art. II, §§ 3.5-21—3.5-52, in its entirety and enacted a new Art. II, §§ 3.5-21—3.5-49, to read as set out herein. Former Art. II, §§ 3.5-21—3.5-52, pertained to similar subject matter ad derived from Ord. W-4-94, adopted July 5, 1994.
Sec. 3.5-21. - Findings; public purpose. Based on the experiences of other counties and municipalities, including, but not limited to Houston, Texas, Tucson, Arizona, Minneapolis, Minnesota, Garden City, California, Peach County, City of Lavonia, and Gwinnett County, Georgia, which experiences are found to be relevant to the problems faced by the City of Winder, and based upon the record of the public hearing on May 17, 2005, including the record of testimony by Chief Stanley Rodgers and Lt. Dennis Dorsey of the Winder Police Department, and further comments in that meeting by the public and representatives of the adult entertainment industry, the mayor and council take note of the well-known and self-evident conditions and secondary effects attendant to the commercial exploitation of human sexuality, which do not vary greatly among the various communities within our country. (1) Sexually oriented businesses lend themselves to ancillary unlawful and unhealthy activities that are presently uncontrolled by the operators of the establishments. Further, there should be a mechanism to make the owners of these establishments responsible for the activities that occur on their premises. (2) Certain employees of sexually oriented businesses, defined in this article as adult entertainment establishments, engage in higher incidence of certain types of illicit sexual behavior than employees of other establishments. (3) Sexual acts, including masturbation, and oral and anal sex, occur at sexually oriented businesses, especially those which provide private or semi-private booths or cubicles for viewing films, videos, or live sex shows. (4) Persons frequent certain adult theaters, adult arcades, and other sexually oriented businesses for the purpose of engaging in sex within the premises of sexually oriented businesses. (5) Numerous communicable diseases may be spread by activities occurring in sexually oriented businesses, including, but not limited to, syphilis, gonorrhea, human immunodeficiency virus infection (HIV-AIDS) and genital herpes. (6) Since 1981 and to the present, there has been an increasing cumulative number of reported cases of AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) caused by human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) in the United States. (7) The number of cases of early (less than one (1) year) syphilis in the United States, as well as Georgia, reported annually has risen. (8) In his report of October 22, 1986, the Surgeon General of the United States has advised the American public that AIDS and HIV infection may be transmitted through sexual conduct, intravenous drug abuse, exposure to infected blood and blood components, and from an infected mother to her newborn. (9) According to the best scientific evidence, AIDS and HIV infection, as well as syphilis and gonorrhea, are principally transmitted by sexual acts. (10) Sanitary conditions in some sexually oriented businesses are unhealthy, in part, because the activities conducted there are unhealthy, and, in part, because of the unregulated nature of the activities and the failure of the owners and the operators of the facilities to self-regulate those activities and maintain those facilities. (11) Numerous studies and reports have determined that semen is found in the areas of sexually oriented businesses where persons view "adult" oriented films. (12) The findings noted in subsections (1) through (11) raise substantial governmental concerns. (13) Sexually oriented businesses have operational characteristics which should be reasonably regulated in order to protect those substantial governmental concerns. (14) A reasonable licensing procedure is an appropriate mechanism to place the burden of that reasonable regulation on the owners and the operators of the sexually oriented businesses. Further, such a licensing procedure will place an incentive on the operators to see that the sexually oriented business is run in a manner consistent with the health, safety, and welfare of its patrons and employees, as well as the citizens of the city. It is appropriate to require reasonable assurances that the licensee is the actual operator of the sexually oriented business, fully in possession and control of the premises and activities occurring therein. (15) Removal of doors on adult booths and requiring sufficient lighting on premises with adult booths advances a substantial governmental interest in curbing the illegal and unsanitary sexual activity occurring in adult theaters. (16) Requiring licenses of sexually oriented businesses to keep information regarding current employees and certain past employees will help reduce the incidence of certain types of criminal behavior by facilitating the identification of potential witnesses or suspects by preventing minors from working in such establishments. (17) The disclosure of certain information by those persons ultimately responsible for the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the sexually oriented business, where such information is substantially related to the significant governmental interest in the operation of such uses, will aid in preventing the spread of sexually transmitted diseases. (18) In the prevention of the spread of communicable diseases, it is desirable to obtain a limited amount of information regarding certain employees who may engage in the conduct which this article is designed to prevent, or who are likely to be witnesses to such conduct. (19) The fact that an applicant for an adult use license has been convicted of a sexually related crime leads to the rational assumption that the applicant may engage in that conduct in contravention of this article. (20) The barring of such individuals from the management of adult uses for a period of years serves as a deterrent to, and prevents conduct which leads to, the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases. (21) The general welfare, health, morals, and safety of the citizens of the city will be promoted by the enactment of this article. It is the finding of the mayor and council that public nudity (either partial or total) under certain circumstances, particularly circumstances related to the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages in establishments offering live nude entertainment or "adult entertainment," (whether such alcoholic beverages are sold on the premises or not) begets criminal behavior and tends to create undesirable community conditions. In the same manner, establishments offering cinematographic or videographic adult entertainment have the same deleterious effects on the community. Among the acts of criminal behavior found to be associated with the commercial combination of live nudity and alcohol, live commercial nudity in general, and cinematographic or videographic adult entertainment are disorderly conduct, prostitution, public solicitation, public indecency, drug use and drug trafficking. Among the undesirable community conditions identified in other communities with the commercial combination of live nudity and alcohol, commercial nudity in general, and cinematographic or videographic adult entertainment, are depressions of property values and acceleration of community blight in the surrounding neighborhood, increased allocation of and expenditure for law enforcement personnel to preserve law and order, and increased burden on the judicial system as a consequence of the criminal behavior herein above described. The mayor and council find it is reasonable to believe that some or all of these undesirable community conditions will result in the city, as well. Furthermore, it is the finding of the mayor and council that other forms of adult entertainment including, but not limited to, adult book stores, adult novelty shops, adult video stores, peep shows, adult theaters, and massage parlors have an adverse effect upon the quality of life in surrounding communities. The mayor and council find that the negative secondary effects of adult entertainment establishments upon the city are similar whether the adult entertainment establishment features live nude dancing or sells video tapes depicting sexual activities. In addition, Gwinnett County's experience with the adult bookstore located within the county has shown that a substantial amount of activity at the bookstore involves booths which an individual may enter, view videos depicting sexual activity, and sexually interact with a bookstore patron in an adjoining booth through a hole strategically placed in the wall of adjoining booths. The city therefore finds that it is in the best interests of the health, welfare, safety and morals of the community and the preservation of its businesses, neighborhoods, and of houses of worship (religious institutions), schools, residential areas, public parks and children's daycare facilities to prevent or reduce the adverse impacts of adult entertainment establishments. Therefore, the mayor and council find that licensing and regulations are necessary for any adult entertainment establishment. The mayor and council find that these regulations promote the public welfare by furthering legitimate public and governmental interests, including but not limited to, reducing criminal activity and protecting against or eliminating undesirable community conditions and further find that such will not infringe upon the protected Constitutional rights of freedom of speech or expression, which rights are expressly acknowledged herein. To that end, this article is hereby adopted. The purpose of this article is to regulate certain types of businesses including, but not limited to, adult entertainment establishments, to the end that the many types of criminal activities frequently engendered by such businesses will be curtailed. However, it is recognized that such regulation cannot de facto approach prohibition. Otherwise, a protected form of expression would vanish. This article represents a balancing of competing interests: reduced criminal activity and protection of the neighborhoods through the regulation of adult entertainment establishments versus the protected rights of adult entertainment establishments and patrons. (Ord. (W-02-05) of 6-7-2005) Sec. 3.5-22. - Definitions. Except as specifically defined herein, all words used in this article shall be as defined in the most recent edition of the New Illustrated Book of Development Definitions (Rutgers). Words not defined herein or in the above book shall be construed to have the meaning given by common and ordinary use, and shall be interpreted within the context of the sentence and section in which they occur. Adult bookstore means any commercial establishment in which more than five (5) per cent of its total floor space, but no more than one hundred (100) square feet, is used for the display or offer for sale of any book or publication, film, or other medium which depicts sexually explicit nudity or sexual conduct by its emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas." Adult entertainer means any person employed by an adult entertainment establishment who exposes his or her "specified anatomical areas," as defined herein. For purposes of this section, adult entertainers include employees as well as independent contractors. Adult entertainment means entertainment that is characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, display or the featuring of "specified anatomical areas." Adult entertainment establishment and sexually oriented business shall be defined to include the following types of business: (1) Any commercial establishment that employs or uses any person live, in any capacity in the sale or service of beverages or food while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing, so as to expose any portion of his or her "specified anatomical areas," as defined herein; (2) Any commercial establishment which provides live entertainment where any person appears unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing so as to expose any portion of his or her "specified anatomical areas" as defined herein or where such performances are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on "specified sexual activities," as defined herein; (3) Any commercial establishment which holds, promotes, sponsors or allows any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where live patrons of the establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct described in subsections (1) and (2) [above];
