(13) A stormwater management program provides the most practical and appropriate means of properly delivering stormwater management services throughout the city's service area, and the most equitable means to regulate the use of a higher level of stormwater management services within the city's service area through stormwater service fee charges and other mechanisms. (14) The area of impervious surfaces on each improved property is the most important factor influencing the cost of the stormwater management services provided by the city or to be provided by the city in the future, and the area of impervious surfaces on each property is therefore the most appropriate parameter for calculating a periodic stormwater service fee charge. (15) A schedule of stormwater service fees based in part on the area of impervious surface located on each improved property is the most appropriate and equitable means of allocating the cost of stormwater management services throughout the city's service area. Such stormwater service fees may be complemented by other types of charges which address specific needs, including, but not limited to, special service fees, special assessments, revenue bonds, use of proceeds from special purpose local option sales taxes and other forms of revenue, as deemed appropriate by the mayor and city council. (16) It is imperative that the proceeds from all stormwater service fees, together with any other revenues raised or otherwise allocated specifically to stormwater management services, systems or facilities, be dedicated solely to those purposes, and such proceeds of stormwater service fees and revenues shall therefore be deposited into the enterprise accounting fund of the city stormwater utility and shall remain in that fund and be dispersed only for stormwater management capital, operating and non-operating costs, lease payments and debt service of bonds or other indebtedness for stormwater management purposes. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-223. - Establishment of a stormwater utility and stormwater enterprise fund. (a) There is hereby established a stormwater utility within and under the supervision of the city's department of stormwater management, which stormwater utility shall be responsible for providing stormwater management services, for providing stormwater management programs and related facilities, and for determining labor, material and administrative fees for the operation of the city's stormwater management programs. (b) The city stormwater enterprise fund, established in 2018 to fund the operation of the city's stormwater management programs and performance of inspections of and repairs to city stormwater management programs and facilities, is hereby designated as a funding mechanism for the stormwater utility and shall continue to operate as a funding mechanism for the maintenance, repair and construction of city stormwater management programs. (c) The city hereby transfers to the stormwater utility responsibility for stormwater services, city stormwater management programs and related facilities, and other related assets, including, but not limited to, properties upon which such facilities are located, and related easements, rights-of-entry and access rights. (d) The city finance department shall maintain the stormwater enterprise fund in the city budget and accounting system, separate and apart from its general fund, for the purpose of dedicating and protecting all funding applicable to the purposes and responsibilities of the stormwater utility, including, but not limited to, charges, rates, fees and licenses as may be established from time to time by the mayor and city council. All revenues and receipts of the stormwater utility shall be deposited promptly upon receipt into the stormwater enterprise fund, to be held and invested in trust and expended exclusively for the purposes of the stormwater utility, including but not limited to repayment of loans and capital project construction. No other funds of the city shall be deposited in the stormwater enterprise fund or commingled with dedicated stormwater utility funds, except that other revenues, receipts, and resources not accounted for in the stormwater enterprise fund, including grants, loans, loans from the general fund and bond proceeds, may be combined with and applied to stormwater utility capital projects as deemed appropriate by the mayor and city council, upon recommendation of the stormwater coordinator. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-224. - Scope of responsibility for the city stormwater management programs. (a) The city stormwater management program consists of all rivers, streams, creeks, branches, lakes, reservoirs, ponds, drainage ways, channels, ditches, swales, storm sewers, culverts, inlets, catch basins, pipes, headwalls, and other structures, natural or manmade, within the city limits of the city, which control or convey stormwater and through which the city intentionally diverts surface waters from its public streets and properties. The city owns or has legal access for purposes of operation, maintenance and improvements to those segments of the stormwater management program that: (1) Are located within city streets, rights-of-way or easements; (2) Are subject to city easements, rights of entry, rights of access, rights of use, or other permanent rights of the city for adequate access for operation, maintenance and/or improvement of stormwater management programs and facilities; or (3) Are located on public lands to which the city has adequate access for operation, maintenance, and/or improvement of stormwater management programs and related facilities. Operation and maintenance of stormwater management programs and related facilities which are located on private property, or public property not owned by or otherwise accessible pursuant to written property rights to the city, and for which there has been no public dedication of such stormwater management programs and related facilities for operation, maintenance, and/or improvement of such stormwater management programs and related facilities shall be and remain the legal responsibility of the applicable property owner or occupant, except as that responsibility may be otherwise affected by the laws of either the state or federal government. (b) It is the intent of this article to protect the public health, safety and general welfare of all properties and persons in the city in general, but not to create any special duty or relationship with any individual person or to any specified property within or without the boundaries of the city. (c) If any permit, plan approval, inspection or similar act is required by the city as a condition precedent to any activity or change upon property not owned by the city pursuant to this or any other regulatory ordinance, regulation or rule of the city, or under federal or state law, the issuance of such permit, plan approval or inspection shall not be deemed to constitute a warranty, express or implied, nor shall it afford the basis for any action, including any action based on failure to permit, negligent issuance of a permit, negligent plan approval, or negligent maintenance of any permitted stormwater management program or facility not expressly dedicated to and accepted by the city for further maintenance in an action seeking the imposition of money damages or equitable remedies against the city, its council members, mayor, officers, employees or agents. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-225. - Requirements for commercial and industrial on-site stormwater systems; enforcement methods and inspections. All owners and developers of developed commercial or industrial parcels within the city developed or constructed after July 24, 2018, and such parcels that have existing stormwater facilities shall provide, manage, maintain, and operate on-site stormwater management programs sufficient to collect, convey, detain, and discharge stormwater in a safe manner consistent with all federal, state, and city regulations. Any failure to meet this obligation shall constitute a nuisance and be subject to an abatement action filed by the city in any court of competent jurisdiction. In the event a public nuisance is found to exist by the court, which nuisance the owner fails to properly abate within such reasonable time as allowed by the court, the city may enter upon the property and cause such remedial work as is reasonably necessary to be performed, with the actual cost thereof assessed against the property owner. From the date of the filing of such action, the city shall have lien rights which may be perfected, after judgment, by filing a notice of lien on the general execution docket of the Superior Court of Barrow County. The city shall have the right, pursuant to the authority of this article, for its designated officers and employees to enter upon private property, upon reasonable notice to the owner thereof, to inspect the property and conduct surveys and engineering tests thereon in order to assure compliance with this section. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-226. - Determination and modification of stormwater service fees. Stormwater service fees shall be based upon an estimate of stormwater runoff from a property and shall be determined and modified from time to time by resolution of the city council. The area of impervious surface on each parcel shall be calculated as of January 1 preceding each fiscal year. In setting or modifying such rates, it shall be the objective of the city to establish rates and fees that are fair and reasonable, which may include flat fee rates for certain classifications of properties, reflect the value of stormwater management services and facilities to those properties that benefit therefrom and which, together with any other sources of revenue that may be made available to the stormwater utility, will be sufficient to meet the cost of budgeted programs, services and facilities including, but not limited to, the payment of principal and interest on revenue bond obligations incurred for construction and improvements to the city stormwater management programs. Future capital investments and necessary reserve accounts, including but not limited to an emergency reserve account, may be included in the calculation of the stormwater service fees. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-227. - Effective date of stormwater service fees. (a) An annual service charge is imposed upon each parcel of developed land in the city as of July 1 each fiscal year, effective July 1, 2018, to fund stormwater utility programs. This annual service charge shall be known as the "stormwater service fee." Stormwater service fees shall be maintained in the stormwater enterprise fund by the city. Purchases by the stormwater utility shall be made through the Stormwater Management program for the sole purpose of performing the obligations of the stormwater utility. (b) Stormwater service fees supporting stormwater utility needs will be determined for each fiscal year and will be approved by resolution during the budgeting process by the city. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-228. - Stormwater service fee billing, delinquencies, collections. (a) A stormwater service fee bill shall be attached to and/or included in the annual property tax bill generated by the county tax commissioner. The stormwater service fee is due as stated on said bill as well as past due late charges. Failure to receive a bill is not justification for nonpayment. Regardless of the party to whom the bill is initially directed, the owner of each parcel of developed land, as shown from public land records of the county, shall be ultimately obligated to pay the stormwater service fee. If a customer is under-billed or if no bill is sent for developed land, the city may back-bill for a period of up to four (4) years, but shall not assess penalties, other than the late charge for delinquency as described in this section. The inclusion of the stormwater service fees with the annual tax bill is intended for convenience only, such stormwater service fee are fees for utility services provided to customers by the stormwater utility and are not a tax or regulatory fee. (b) The city reserves the right to place stormwater service fees on utility bills in lieu of a tax bill or when a tax bill on a property is not a feasible option to collect the stormwater service fees on a property. (c) Suits for collection of unpaid stormwater service fees shall be filed in a court of competent jurisdiction. No lien shall be imposed for delinquent collections unless a judgment is first obtained. (d) Unpaid stormwater service fees may be collected by filing suit to collect on an unpaid account and by using all methods allowed by state law to collect on any judgment obtained thereby. (e) A late charge of ten (10) percent of the amount due per year shall be assessed against the customer for the unpaid balance of any stormwater service fee that becomes delinquent. In addition, the city shall assess all costs of collection, including attorney's fees and court costs, against the property owner. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-229. - Requests for modification of the stormwater service fee. (a) Any property owner may request a review and adjustment of their stormwater service fee by submitting a request in writing, along with any supporting information, to the stormwater coordinator within thirty (30) days after the date the tax bill is mailed or issued to the property owner. Grounds for modification of the stormwater service fee include, complete demolition and removal of all impervious surfaces on the parcel in question making up greater than fifty (50) square feet of impervious surface area subject to documentation and city personnel inspection. The filing of a request for review does not excuse payment of the fee when due. (b) The stormwater coordinator shall administer the procedures and standards for the adjustment of the stormwater service fee charge as approved by the city. (c) Reserved. (d) Customers requesting the adjustment shall be required, at their own expense, to provide supplemental information at the request of the stormwater coordinator including, but not limited to, an "as-built" survey certified by a registered land surveyor or a professional engineer if the stormwater coordinator cannot make a determination based on field inspection and/or review of existing city aerial photography. Failure to provide the required information within the time limits established by the stormwater coordinator, as may be reasonably extended, may result in denial of the adjustment request. (e) Once a completed adjustment request and all required information are received by the stormwater coordinator, the city shall have thirty (30) calendar days within which to render a written decision. If the city fails to render a decision within thirty (30) days, the adjustment request shall automatically be deemed denied, but said denial shall be subject to appeal to the zoning board of appeals. Appeals shall be filed with the zoning board of appeals within thirty (30) days of the denial in accordance with section 24-214. (f) In considering an adjustment request, the city shall consider whether the calculation of the stormwater service fee for the property is correct. (g) The stormwater coordinator decision shall be in writing and will be mailed to the address provided on the adjustment request, and service shall be complete upon mailing. (h) If the result of an adjustment is that a refund is due the applicant, the refund will be paid within forty-five (45) days. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-230. - Stormwater credit. Stormwater credit is a reduction in the stormwater service fee for properties that meet certain requirements. Such properties shall be eligible for a reduction in the stormwater service fee based on the latest city stormwater credit manual. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-231. - Stormwater credit application procedures. (a) In order to obtain a credit, applicants must make application to the stormwater coordinator on forms provided by the stormwater coordinator for such purpose. (b) Applicants must apply for any credits or adjustments that they believe apply. (c) The application for any credit or adjustment must be in writing and must include the information necessary to establish eligibility for the credit or adjustment, any application fee, and be in the format established by the stormwater coordinator. Incomplete applications will not be accepted by the city. (d) Applicants that have on-site detention or retention must have an approved maintenance plan on file with the stormwater coordinator. (e) Applicants that have on-site detention or retention must have a licensed engineer provide documentation that the detention/retention area meets applicable code. (f) When an application for a credit is deemed complete, the stormwater coordinator shall have thirty (30) days from the date the complete application is accepted to grant or deny the credit by written decision. Failure to render a decision within thirty (30) calendar days shall be deemed a denial. The applicant may appeal a denial by application to the zoning board of appeals, filed within thirty (30) days of the date of the denial by the stormwater coordinator in accordance with section 24-214. (g) The application deadline for each year is July 1. Applications submitted after the deadline will be processed during the next billing cycle. Applicants that obtain a credit for on-site detention or retention shall not have to reapply annually for the credit granted. (h) The stormwater coordinator may review the credit annually and may terminate the credit if the stormwater coordinator or city engineer determines that on-site detention or retention facilities are no longer in compliance with the current edition of the state stormwater management manual. Properties no longer in compliance will be provided with sixty (60) days written notice to correct the deficiencies before such credit is terminated. If terminated, the applicant may, if possible, correct the deficiencies which caused the termination and reapply for the credit, or may appeal such determination by application before the zoning board of appeals, filed within thirty (30) days of the date of the decision of the stormwater coordinator or city engineer in accordance with section 24-214. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-232. - Stormwater service fee exemptions. Except as provided in this section or otherwise provided by law, no public or private property located in the service area of the city shall be exempt from the stormwater service fee. No exception, credit, offset, or other reduction in stormwater service fees shall be granted based on age, tax status, economic status, race, religion or other condition unrelated to the stormwater utility's cost of providing stormwater management services and facilities. Exemptions to the stormwater service fee are as follows: (1) Railroad rights-of-way (tracks) shall be exempt from stormwater service fee. However, railroad stations, maintenance buildings, and/or other improved property used for railroad purposes shall not be exempt from stormwater service fees. (2) Georgia Department of Transportation (GDOT) streets and rights-of-way shall be exempt from stormwater service fees. This exemption is in recognition of routine drainage system maintenance and capital construction services undertaken by GDOT in association with GDOT rights-of-way and road systems. However, maintenance buildings and/or other improved property used for GDOT purposes shall not be exempt from stormwater service fee. All other state, federal, and county properties are subject to the user fee charges on the same basis as private properties. (3) City and county streets and rights-of-way shall be exempt from stormwater service fees. This exemption is in recognition of routine drainage system maintenance and capital construction services undertaken by the county and city. However, other improved property used for city and county purposes shall not be exempt from stormwater service fee. (4) In consideration for the city allowing the stormwater utility to use the city's existing streets, curbs, gutters, drainageways and ditches, storm sewers, culverts, inlets, catch basins, pipes, head walls and other structures, natural and manmade within and owned, leased or maintained by the city which controls and diverts surface water for the purposes of collecting, diverting, transporting and controlling surface and stormwaters; the utility shall not charge the city a stormwater service fee for developed land owned or leased by the city or public rights-of-way owned or maintained by the city. (5) Any parcel or lot that is not developed land. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-233. - Enforcement methods and inspections. (a) Any violation of this article shall be subject to citation and prosecution in the city municipal court. Each day such violation exists shall constitute a separate offense, subject to the penalties set forth the City Code section 1-8. (b) In the event a public nuisance is deemed to exist by the stormwater coordinator, code enforcement officer or other city official, the city may sue in the county superior court to abate such nuisance. In the event a public nuisance is found by the court to exist, which the property owner fails to abate within such reasonable time as allowed by the superior court, the city may enter upon the property and cause work as is reasonably necessary to be performed. (c) The city shall have the right for its designated officers and employees to enter upon public and private property during reasonable hours, and after reasonable notice to the owner thereof, in order to assure compliance with the provisions of this article, and state and federal law. Such inspections shall generally be limited to the following purposes: (1) Inspecting or conducting engineering analyses on existing stormwater management programs and facilities located on-site; or (2) Determining whether stormwater management programs and facilities need to be constructed. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18) Sec. 24-234. - Appeals, hearings. (a) Appeals. An appeal to the zoning board of appeals may be taken by any property owner or customer aggrieved by any decision of the stormwater coordinator. The appeal shall be taken within thirty (30) days of the decision of the stormwater coordinator by filing with the zoning board of appeals a notice of appeal in writing specifying the grounds thereof. Upon the filing of the notice of appeal, the stormwater coordinator shall forthwith transmit to the zoning board of appeals all documentation constituting the record upon which the decision appealed from was taken. (b) Hearing. The zoning board of appeals shall fix a time not greater than sixty (60) days after the filing of the appeal for hearing the appeal and give written notice to the appellant at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing date. The notice shall indicate the place, date and time of the hearing. The zoning board of appeals shall affirm, reverse, affirm in part, or reverse in part the decision of the stormwater coordinator after hearing the evidence. If the decision of the stormwater coordinator is reversed in whole or in part, resulting in a refund or credit due to the property owner, then such refund or credit shall be calculated retroactive to the date of the appeal and applied as a credit to the next year's bill. (c) The decision of the zoning board of appeals shall be final, and there shall be no further administrative action. Any person aggrieved or dissatisfied with the decision of the zoning board of appeals may appeal that decision to the county superior court by writ of certiorari. (Ord. ( W-3-18 ) of 7-24-18)

div.head: Chapter 25 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. W-2-13, adopted Jan. 18, 2013, deleted ch. 25 in its entirety and inserted a new ch. 25 to read as herein set out. Former ch. 25 pertained to the same subject matter, was comprised of §§ 25-1—25-78, and derived from §§ 13-28—13-50 of the 1968 Code, the amendatory history for which can be found in the Code Comparative Table at the back of this volume. Charter reference— Power of city as to collection and disposal of solid waste, § 1-3(19). Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 5; food and food establishments, ch. 10; housing, ch. 12; mobile homes, ch. 14; parks and recreation, ch. 17; streets and sidewalks, ch. 27; water, ch. 31. State Law reference— Power of city to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV; Solid Waste Management Act, Ga. Code Ann., § 12-8-20 et seq.; Litter Control Law, Ga. Code Ann., § 16-7-40 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL
Secs. 25-1—25-9. - Reserved. Sec. 25-10. - Municipal jurisdiction. It shall be mandatory that all owners, occupants, tenants and lessees of residential buildings, offices or businesses and commercial building and premises and the same shall be required to accept such collection and removal services as may be provided by the city relating to the disposal of garbage, trash, rubbish and other debris within the municipal jurisdiction of the city. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-11. - Commercial notification for collection. All commercial businesses that require cart service shall notify the city that collection of garbage from such places is needed. For dumpster or roll-off containers see section 25-103. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-12. - Businesses and industries within the city. (a) All businesses and industries located in the city shall place all the garbage and rubbish generated by them in containers. All commercial containers must have closefitting lids. All lids and side doors shall be kept closed by the users so the contents are covered at all times. (b) All containers shall be stored on private property and may not interfere with vehicular or pedestrian traffic. In the event that a container is placed on city property a lease agreement shall be first entered into with the city. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-13. - Reserved. Sec. 25-14. - Pre-collection. (a) All garbage and refuse shall be placed in plastic or paper bags securely closed and stored in solid waste containers authorized by the city. (b) Any solid waste that may injure or hamper a collector, such as, but not limited to, broken glass; light bulbs; razor blades; or other potentially sharp or dangerous objects shall be securely wrapped so as to prevent puncture to the wrapping or solid waste container. (c) Private streets and other roads which are not dedicated city rights-of-way shall be fully accessible to the city's provider and equipment in order for collections to be made in an unobstructed fashion by the city. The city reserves the right to select an alternative location for collection when private roads are not suitable. (d) If an authorized garbage container is obstructed in such a manner as to prohibit the automated collection vehicle from dumping the container, the container's contents will not be collected and/or an additional charge may be imposed for any additional effort to collect such waste. (e) Waste placed in containers other than authorized containers will not be collected and the customer will be subject to fines. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-15. - Authorized containers. Each residential dwelling unit or commercial business will be provided one (1) standard authorized rollaway cart/garbage container by the city or its contractor. Upon request additional garbage containers may be delivered to a residential dwelling unit at an additional monthly charge to the resident. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-16. - Loss or damage to authorized containers. (a) Authorized containers assigned to residential or commercial customers by the city are and shall remain property of the city's provider. (b) Damage to, loss, or removal of an authorized container assigned to a residential or commercial unit shall be the responsibility of the holder of the utility account for the unit at the time such damage, loss or removal is discovered by the city/the city's provider, and such holder of the utility account or property owner (if no water account is noted) shall be liable for all costs associated with replacing the container. (c) Persons moving from one (1) address in the city to another address in the city, or from the city to another locality shall leave all authorized containers at the location to which the containers have been assigned. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-17. - Maintenance of authorized containers. (a) Authorized containers assigned to a customer shall be the responsibility of and kept and maintained by the customer in a clean and sanitary manner so as to prevent the breeding of insects, vermin, vectors, and/or the release of odors. (b) Dumpsters, roll-off containers, and compactors shall be the responsibility of and maintained by the owner of such property in a clean, disinfected, and sanitary manner so as to prevent the breeding of insects, vermin, or vectors, and/or the release of odors. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-18. - Time of placement of residential solid waste for collection. (a) Authorized carts shall be placed by the owner of such property in a location that is readily accessible to collection equipment, not to exceed three (3) feet from the curb or edge of the traveled portion of the street or road and not to be located in a manner that will block the driveway or interfere with vehicular or pedestrian traffic. Such placement shall not restrict access to public sidewalks, pathways and bicycle paths. Where there is no curb, authorized carts shall be placed next to the edge of the road pavement in the same manner as if there were a curb. (b) Household garbage shall be set out for collection entirely within fully closed authorized garbage carts and placed by the owner of such property on the street abutting the residential or commercial unit for which the container was assigned. (c) For proper automated collection, the authorized garbage container shall be placed by the owner of such property in such a manner as to have sufficient clearance on each side so as to be accessible to the automated collections vehicle with the container handle facing away from the street or right-of-way. Containers shall be placed at a minimum of three (3) feet from vehicles, utility poles and boxes, trees, mailboxes, and other objects. (d) Authorized containers shall be removed by the owner of such property from the street and stored on the side or rear of the dwelling to which it is assigned as soon as possible after collection. Containers shall not be permitted to be placed before 12:01 a.m. the day before the scheduled pickup or remain on the street after midnight of the day following the scheduled collection day. Each resident, property owner, agent, manager and/or occupant of a property is responsible for compliance with this provision. Exception: For nonresidential property, carts may be placed curbside after 2:00 p.m. on Friday if the day for collection is Monday. The fine for a violation of this subsection shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per citation after the first warning is provided. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-19. - Collection assistance due to physical limitations. (a) A written verification by a medical doctor that the resident is unable to physically place carts at the curbside may be required to receive non-curbside cart assistance. Handicapped or disabled residents must live alone or all persons living in household must be disabled to receive non-curbside cart assistance. (b) Residences receiving assistance with the non-curbside service will utilize a collection point designated by the city's provider. (c) Assistance for nonresidential property non-curbside service will charged an additional monthly rate of twelve dollars ($12.00) per cart. (d) A disability form may be required by the contracted provider and shall be available at City Hall. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-20. - Special service. Any person requesting special service, that is the collection of any items not otherwise provided for in this chapter, may inquire with the city for such service. Special services provided by the city shall be billed in addition to the standard monthly cost and payment may be required in advance. Special service may be provided through the city's provider or a third party contractor. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-21. - Scavenging. No person other than the occupants of the property/owners, city code enforcement officials, or authorized collection personnel shall sift the contents of or remove anything from carts, bags, or boxes containing items placed for disposal and/or recycling. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-22. - Move-outs and evictions. (a) For rental properties, garbage, trash, or other solid waste originating from the property during the clean up between tenants shall be the responsibility of the landlord and/or the property owner. Following an eviction, any property, trash, belongings, or other items shall be placed adjacent to some portion of the property, immediately behind the sidewalk or if there is no sidewalk, a minimum of three (3) feet behind the curb or off the pavement and shall not be located as to impede or obstruct or divert either pedestrian or vehicular traffic or the flow of surface water or block drains. (b) The city and/or the selected provider are not responsible for and will not return any items collected curbside once the item has been removed. It is the property's owner or tenant's responsibility to ensure that items not intended for collection are not placed at and/or are timely removed from the curbside. (c) Items place on city right-of-way or near the edge of a public road will be removed by the city and the utility customer or property owner will be billed seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per cubic yard. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-23. - Reserved. Sec. 25-24. - Building materials. The city shall not be responsible for collecting or hauling discarded building materials, dirt, broken concrete, bricks, rock or debris resulting from repairs, renovations, remodeling, or construction waste (plumbing fixtures, including, but not limited to, sinks, bath tubs, shower stalls, toilets, cabinets, doors, windows, roofing debris, lumber, siding, carpet and/or floor coverings). Such material must be disposed of by the builder, property owner, tenant, or their authorized contractor. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-25. - Prohibited materials. (a) Dead animals, tires, sewage, poisons, commercial medical waste, explosives, dangerous or corrosive chemicals, motor oil, bulky items and/or cylinders containing gas under pressure, air conditioners, vehicle batteries, paint cans (unless all paint is dry), or lumber shall not be placed in carts used for regular collection service. (b) No person shall dispose of any hypodermic syringe, needle, instrument or any device used for injections except when such disposal is in compliance with state and federal regulations and, at a minimum, making this material completely incapable of reuse; prior to disposal, such material shall be placed in an appropriate container and secured so as to prevent injury to collectors. (c) Cardboard boxes. All cardboard boxes must be flattened before these items will be acceptable for collection. When available, cardboard should be placed in the recycling cart. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-26. - Drainage of refuse. All refuse capable of holding liquids must be drained before being deposited in the city's containers. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-27. - Transportation. It is unlawful for any person to transport any solid waste or recovered material over any city road unless the solid waste or recovered material is securely tied, placed in a secure container, or covered when necessary so as to prevent leakage or spillage. It is unlawful for any person to allow solid waste or recovered materials to spill, blow or drop from any vehicle on any road. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-28. - Illegal disposal of garbage, etc. (a) No person shall deposit garbage, trash or refuse of any kind on or bury garbage, trash or refuse of any kind in any public easements or right-of-way, street, alley, sidewalk, or other public land, vacant or unoccupied lot. (b) It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or lessee of any building, yard or lot of ground within the city to allow garbage, trash or refuse of any kind to accumulate or remain in the building, or upon the yard or lot, unless placed in a container as required by this article. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person to place garbage, yard debris, or refuse for collection in such a manner as to obstruct gutters, drains, stormwater ditch, or any natural waterway. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-29. - Nuisance. (a) The keeping of garbage in containers other than containers prescribed by this chapter or the keeping upon premises of garbage or yard waste which is allowed to become a public health hazard, cause odor, or blight, shall constitute a public nuisance and may be abated in the manner provided by city ordinance and/or state law. (b) A separate violation shall be deemed committed each day during or upon which such unlawful accumulation continues. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 22-30. - Recycling. (a) In order to promote recycling, the city shall provide each residence with one (1) recycle cart. Customers not wishing to participate are required to contact the waste provider for non-delivery or removal of the recycling cart. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to place any material not designated for recycling in the recyclable material cart. (c) Recycling carts shall be removed from customers not complying with the established recycling program. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-31. - Removal of nonconforming solid waste or other debris. If a customer has not removed extra or nonconforming solid waste, or refuse within forty-eight (48) hours after notification by the city, the city administrator or designee may order such removal and all actual costs incurred plus a fifty dollar ($50.00) administrative fee shall be billed to the customer's utility account. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-32. - Penalties. (a) Any person violating this article shall be punished by a fine not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, by imprisonment for a term not to exceed thirty (30) days and/or a combination of such fine and imprisonment. (b) Upon conviction, the court may also order the convicted person to remove any solid waste that has been accumulated in violation of this article from the property. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Secs. 25-33—25-44. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - YARD TRIMMINGS AND BULK WASTE DISPOSAL REGULATIONS
Sec. 25-45. - Definitions. For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed in this section: (a) Bulky waste. Those items whose large size or weight precludes or complicates their handling by normal collection, processing and disposal methods. Common examples are furniture, carpet, and appliances. (b) Commercial solid waste. All types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. (c) Composting. The controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odor-free humus. (d) Cubic yard. Three (3) feet high, by three (3) feet deep, by three (3) feet wide. (e) Last week of the month. The last week having a Monday through Friday of the month. (f) Yard debris. Leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree pruning, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-46. - Leaves and grass clippings. (a) Yard debris such as leaves, grass clippings and pine straw shall be bagged and placed adjacent to the street for collection. Yard debris will be picked up by the city. Each single-family or duplex residential property may place up to eight (8) bags weighing less than thirty (30) pounds by the street each week for no additional charge. (b) Residential property owners with more than eight (8) bags should contact the city's public works department to make arrangements for an additional charge. (c) Yard debris not bagged will be picked up upon request, but will be subject to a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per cubic yard. All fees shall be added to the monthly utility bill. Any delinquent or unpaid fees shall be subject to the enforcement, delinquency and execution provisions as set forth in this chapter. (d) The city shall conduct loose leaf roadside collection, from October 1 to January 31. Residents shall rake or blow their leaves to edge of the road during this time frame, without blocking traffic or drainage ditches, and the city will pick them up. During this time frame leaves will be collected twice per month. (e) The loose leaf roadside collection only applies to property zoned residential that have an active solid waste account with the city. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-47. - Time of placement of yard debris for collection. (a) All residents utilizing city collection of yard debris shall place such items on their premises behind the curb line, located so as to be easily accessible to street pickup, not to be placed over or next to fixed items such as fire hydrants, telephone poles or electrical boxes, water meters, mail boxes or anything that could be damaged by equipment or personnel picking up said items. The City of Winder and its collection contractor will not be responsible for repairing or replacing items removed or damaged which were placed curbside in such a manner that it appeared to be intended for removal or was not visible because it was mixed with other items placed curbside. (b) The total allowable volume of yard debris to be collected at curbside per residential property per week is a maximum of one (1) pile approximately four (4) feet in length by four (4) feet in height by a width of four (4) feet. This includes the combined total of both bulk and vegetative waste. Limbs shall not be greater than four (4) inches in diameter or longer than four (4) feet. Yard debris shall be stacked and bundled with string, twine, or other similar materials. (c) Loose yard debris not complying with section 25-47(b) will be collected at a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per cubic yard and billed to the property's utility bill. Properties that do not have an active utility bill will be subject to collections as provided in this chapter. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-48. - Tree and landscaping service disposal. (a) All holders of a tree service license or any person engaging in the cutting of trees/vegetation for hire or compensation shall be required to remove all debris, brush and limbs. It shall be unlawful for any person to trim or remove trees within the city unless the byproduct from those services is immediately removed from the premises and properly disposed of. (b) This section shall apply to all debris which exceeds the definition of yard debris acceptable for monthly collection by the city noted in section 25-47(b). (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-49. - Bulk waste. (a) Bulk waste from residences may be placed at curbside for collection the last week of the month, provided that such waste is in piles separate from yard waste and all other solid waste. One (1) cubic yard will be collected per month for each active residential account at no additional charge. (b) All residents utilizing city collection of bulk waste shall place such items on their premises behind the curb line, located so as to be easily accessible to street pickup, not to be placed over or next to fixed items such as fire hydrants, telephone poles or electrical boxes, water meters, mail boxes or anything that could be damaged by equipment or personnel picking up said items. The city and its collection contractor will not be responsible for repairing or replacing items removed or damaged which were placed curbside in such a manner that it appeared to be intended for removal or was not visible because it was mixed with other items placed curbside. (c) Bulk waste placed curbside outside of the last week of the month and/or exceeding the one (1) cubic yard per month shall be picked up at a cost of fifty dollars ($50.00) per cubic yard and billed to the property's utility account. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-50. - Penalties. Any person violating this article shall be subject to a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, by imprisonment for a term not to exceed thirty (30) days and/or a combination of such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Secs. 25-51—25-59. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LITTER
Sec. 25-60. - Litter control—Definitions. As used in this article, the following definitions shall apply: (a) Litter means all sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, rubbish, waste material, tin cans, refuse, garbage, paper, trash, debris or discarded materials of every kind and description; (b) Public or private property means the right-of-way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or the shores or beaches thereof; any park, playground, building, refuge, or conservation or recreation area; and residential or farm properties, timberlands or forests within the city limits of Winder or any other privately or publicly owned property within the city limits of Winder. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-61. - Same—Unlawful activity enumerated; penalty. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to dump, deposit, throw or leave, or to cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving of, any litter, garbage, rubbish or refuse on any public or private property in this municipality or any waters in this municipality, unless: (1) The property is designated by the federal government, State of Georgia, or by any of its agencies or political subdivisions, for the disposal of litter and the person is authorized by the proper government authority to use such property; (2) The litter, garbage, rubbish or refuse is placed into a litter, garbage, rubbish or refuse receptacle or container installed on such property and the person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property or has first obtained consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession, or unless the act is done under the personal direction of the owner or tenant, all in a manner consistent with the public welfare. (b) Any person who violates subsection (a) of this Code section shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as follows: (1) As provided in section 1-8 of this Code and shall be cited to appear before the municipal court for hearing and determination of the applicable fine. Each and every violation of the provisions of this article shall constitute a separate offense. (2) In the sound discretion of the judge, when conviction is obtained, the person also may be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of-way, located within the city limits, for a distance not to exceed one (1) mile, any litter he has deposited and any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone else prior to the date of execution of sentence; or (3) In the sound discretion of the judge, should conviction be obtained, the person also may be directed to pick up and remove from any public beach, public park, private right-of-way or, with the prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that he has deposited litter, located within the city limits, any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence. (c) The judge may publish the names of persons convicted of violating subsection (a) of this section. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-62. - Same—Prima facie evidence. Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane or other conveyance in violation of section 25-61, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance has violated section 25-61. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-63. - Litter receptacles to be provided by city. The public works director shall establish and maintain receptacles for the deposit of litter at appropriate locations within the city where the property is frequented by the public. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Secs. 25-64—25-89. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ADMINISTRATION
Sec. 25-90. - Schedules for collection, disposal—Establishment. The city administrator or designee shall be authorized to establish schedules for the collection of garbage, recycling, yard debris and bulk waste within the city limits. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-91. - Same—Public information. (a) The city administrator or designee shall notify the public by publishing in the official organ of the county and/or the city's website, garbage, rubbish and refuse collection schedules or changes in such schedules. (b) When applicable, collection schedules will be placed via a sticker on the individual containers. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-92. - Frequency, time of collection—Residential. The city shall provide for the collection and removal of residential household garbage at least once per week for an established fee. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-93. - Enforcement generally. It shall be the duty of the police department, with the assistance of such other persons or code enforcement officials as the city administrator may direct, to see that the provisions of this chapter are enforced except where otherwise specifically provided for by ordinance. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Secs. 25-94—25-99. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - SOLID WASTE PROVIDER
Sec. 25-100. - Contracts with independent solid waste providers. In order for the city to provide adequate service to the citizens of the city for the collection, removal and disposal of refuse accumulated within the city, the city may enter into a contract with an independent contractor, either private or another municipal corporate entity, for such services. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-101. - Contract price. The city council may negotiate with an independent contractor or another municipal corporate entity the terms, conditions and consideration to be paid for the services sought under such a contract; and it shall be presumed that any consideration agreed upon between the city and such independent contractor or municipal corporate entity shall be in the best interest and welfare of the citizens of this city. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-102. - Minimum vehicle standards. (a) An adequate number of vehicles shall be provided by the commercial contractor to service its city customers. All such vehicles shall be licensed in the State of Georgia and shall operate in compliance with all applicable state, federal and municipal regulations. (b) All vehicles and other equipment shall be kept in proper repair and sanitary condition. Each vehicle shall have at least one (1) broom and shovel to clean up solid waste that may be spilled or otherwise scattered during the contractor's process of collection. (c) All vehicles shall be sufficiently secure so as to prevent any littering of solid waste and/or leakage of fluid. No vehicle shall be willfully overloaded. Each vehicle shall be operated by a qualified driver holding a valid license of the category required to operate such vehicles. (d) All vehicles shall be clearly marked with the company's name and telephone number in letters not less than two (2) inches in height. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-103. - Commercial and industrial refuse collection to be provided on a competitive fair market value. It is the policy and intent of the City of Winder that commercial and industrial refuse collection services be provided within the city on a competitive, free market basis for dumpsters and roll-offs. In order to promote this policy and intent, commercial and industrial customers within the city are encouraged to solicit multiple bids from qualified licensed providers and may contract for such services. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-104. - Exclusive right of collection; ownership of materials collected or dumped. (a) The city council shall have the exclusive right to award the collection, removal and disposal of garbage with the city limits. No private individual, business, agent or other operation shall be permitted to haul garbage produced by owners, occupants, tenants and lessees of residential buildings and premises for residential property and premises without first having obtained permission from the council therefore. (b) Any person or company desiring such permission shall bid on the service during times specified, giving the details of operation and any charges to be made, all as may be required by the council and, where allowed, may negotiate such additional terms and conditions. Once a contract is issued by the council for such operations, the contract shall be issued in the name of the applicant and such permit shall not be transferable. The council shall have full authority to make any other reasonable regulations relating to the hauling of garbage over city streets and thoroughfares by outside collectors. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Secs. 25-105—25-119. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - RATES AND CHARGES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Refuse collection charges subject to lien, § 1-3(19). State Law reference— Tax executions and sales, Ga. Code Ann., title 48, chs. 3, 4.
Sec. 25-120. - Refuse collection rates and charges not affected by Code. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance relating to rates and charges for refuse collection or disposal, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-121. - Rates. (a) Fees for collection of solid waste, garbage and yard debris shall be those as established by resolution of the city council; and shall be published in the office of the city clerk and where utility bills may be paid. (b) Rates for service to residential and light commercial service will be subject to periodic review and adjusted by city council by separate resolution as necessary to ensure adequate cost recovery for operation of the sanitary municipal solid waste system. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-122. - Billing and assessment. (a) Levy, amount. For the promotion of public health and safety, there shall be charged against each family occupying a mobile home trailer, house, apartment or other dwelling and against each person, partnership, corporation or other entity owning or operating a business an amount fixed from time to time by the mayor and council, which charge may be included with the monthly water and gas bill, provided said charge is separately stated. (b) The city will not split bills or charge for portions of use. The price shall be billed in full to one (1) single owner. (c) Exemptions. Businesses requiring dumpster or industrial, medical, or hazardous wastes removal services are exempt from city solid waste service and assessed fees provided other arrangements are made for disposal through a licensed provider. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13) Sec. 25-123. - Nonpayment of fees. (a) Should any owners, occupants, tenants and lessees of residential buildings and premises or business and commercial buildings and premises fail or refuse to pay the charges fixed against such owners, occupants, tenants and lessees as provided for in this article when due, the city may discontinue garbage collection services to the residential buildings and premises or business and commercial buildings and premises of such owners, occupants, tenants and lessees against such sanitary service charge or fee and charge for the collection, removal and disposal of garbage services until such fees have been paid in full. (b) If the tenant of any property has no city utility meter and the sums due under this article are not paid when due, the landlord or lessor shall be responsible for such charges and shall be billed for the charges. (c) Upon delinquent notification, if a delinquent account is not paid within five (5) days, the city or the contracted provider may cease all refuse collection for that account or individual address. Service shall be resumed thereafter only upon payment of the entire balance on the account plus all penalties, and all applicable reconnection or container resetting charges. (d) Any person failing or refusing to pay the monthly solid waste or other related charges provided for in this chapter, after having been duly billed by the city, shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter, and all solid waste services and water service provided by the city to the premises for which the monthly charges are past due shall be terminated by the city. (e) Enforcement. In the event charges remain unpaid for fifteen (15) days after the bill or account for service has been rendered to the customer, execution shall be issued in favor of the city against such delinquent user for the amount of such unpaid charges, which execution shall be issued and enforced, levied and collected in the same manner as other executions running in favor of the city. (f) If the account or bill remains unpaid after said past delinquent/due notice is mailed, then the public water supply will be turned off and will not be turned back on until said bill is paid. (g) In addition to all other rates, charges, penalties, fees, expenses and cost otherwise provided for in this chapter, the city may also collect all costs incurred for the collection of delinquent utility accounts, including, but not limited to, postage expenses, late fees as established by resolution or ordinance of the council from time to time, court filing fees, attorney's fees incurred by the city, and fees paid to third-party collection agencies. The city is authorized to use third-party collection agencies to collect delinquent utility accounts and all cost, fees and expenses of such third-party agencies shall be the responsibility of the delinquent customer. (Ord. (W-2-13) of 1-8-13)

div.head: Chapter 26 - SPECIAL SALES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Licenses and business regulations, ch. 13. State Law reference— Sales, Ga. Code Ann., title 11, ch. 2.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 26-1—26-15. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - GOING-OUT-OF-BUSINESS SALES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 26-16. - Definitions. For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given in this section: City: The mayor and council of the City of Winder. City clerk: The clerk of the mayor and council of the City of Winder. Fire and other altered goods sale: A sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the sale will offer goods damaged or altered by fire, smoke, water or other means. Going-out-of-business sale: A sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that upon the disposal of the stock of goods on hand, the business will cease and be discontinued, including but not limited to the following sales: Adjuster's; adjustment; alteration; assignee's; bankrupt; benefit of administrator's; benefit of creditors; benefit of trustees; building coming down; closing; creditor's committee; creditor's; end; executor's; final days; forced out; forced out of business; insolvents'; last days; lease expires; liquidation; loss of lease; mortgage sale; receiver's; trustee's; quitting business. Goods: Any goods, wares, merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated under this article. Removal of business sale: A sale held out in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the person conducting the sale will cease and discontinue business at the place of sale upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand and will then move to and resume business at a new location in the city or will then continue business from other existing locations in the city. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 1) Sec. 26-17. - Effect of article. The provisions of this article are intended to augment and be in addition to the provisions of the general licensing ordinance of this city. Where this article imposes a greater restriction upon persons, premises, businesses or practices than is imposed by the general licensing ordinance of this city, this article shall control. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 3) Sec. 26-18. - Exemptions. The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following persons: (1) Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction; (2) Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials; (3) Duly licensed auctioneers, selling at auction; (4) Any publisher of a newspaper, magazine or other publication, who publishes in good faith, any advertisement, without knowledge of its false, deceptive or misleading character, or without knowledge that the provisions of this article have not been complied with. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 3) Sec. 26-19. - Duties of licensee. A licensee under this article shall: (1) Adhere to inventory. Make no additions whatsoever, during the period of the licensed sale, to the stock of goods set forth in the inventory attached to the application for license. (2) Advertise properly. Refrain from employing any untrue, deceptive or misleading advertising. (3) Adhere to advertising. Conduct the licensed sale in strict conformity with any advertising or holding out incident thereto. (4) Keep duplicate inventory. Keep available at the place of sale a duplicate copy of the inventory submitted with the application and shall present such duplicate to inspecting officials upon request. (5) Segregate noninventoried goods. Keep any other goods separate and apart from the goods listed in the filed inventory as being objects of sale and shall make such distinction clear to the public by placing tags on all inventoried goods in and about the place of sale apprising the public of the status of all such goods. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 6) Secs. 26-20—26-30. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSE
Sec. 26-31. - Required. A license issued by the city clerk shall be obtained by any person before selling or offering to sell any goods at a sale to be advertised or held out by any means to be one of the following kinds: (1) Going-out-of-business sale; (2) Removal of business sale; and (3) Fire and other altered goods sale. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 2) Sec. 26-32. - Issuance generally. A license shall be issued under this article on the terms provided in this division. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 5) Sec. 26-33. - Established business. Any person who has not been the owner of a business advertised or described in the application for a license under this article for a period of at least six (6) months prior to the date of the proposed sale shall not be granted a license. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 3) Sec. 26-34. - Survivors of owner. Upon the death of a person doing business in this city, his or her heirs, devisees or legatees shall have the right to apply at any time for a license under this article. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 3) Sec. 26-35. - Application. A person desiring to conduct a sale regulated by this article shall make a written application to the city clerk setting forth and containing the following information: (1) The true name and address of the owner of the goods to be the object of the sale; (2) The true name and address of the person from whom he purchased the goods to be sold and the price therefor, and if not purchased, the manner of such acquisition; (3) A description of the place where such sale is to be held; (4) The nature of the occupancy, whether by lease or sublease and the effective date of termination of such occupancy; (5) The dates of the period of time in which the sale is to be conducted; (6) A full and complete statement of the facts in regard to the sale, including the reason for the urgent and expeditious disposal of goods thereby and the manner in which the sale will be conducted; (7) The means to be employed in advertising such sale together with the proposed content of any advertisement; (8) A complete and detailed inventory of the goods to be sold at such sale as disclosed by the applicant's records. Said inventory shall be attached to and become part of the required application. a. Bona fide orders. All goods included in such inventory shall have been purchased by the applicant for resale on bona fide orders without cancellation privileges and shall not comprise goods purchased on consignment. b. Goods purchased for sale. Such inventory shall not include goods ordered in contemplation of conducting a sale regulated hereunder. Any unusual purchase, or additions to the stock of goods of the business hereby affected within ninety (90) days before the filing of an application hereunder shall be deemed to be of such character. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 4) Sec. 26-36. - Location. Where a person applying for a license under this article operates more than one place of business, the license issued shall apply only to the one store or branch specified in the application, and no other store or branch shall advertise or represent that it is cooperating with it, or in any way participating in the licensed sale, nor shall the store or branch conducting the licensed sale advertise or represent that any other store or branch is cooperating with it or participating in any way in the licensed sale. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 3) Sec. 26-37. - Fee. Any applicant for a license under this article shall submit to the city clerk with his application a license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Any applicant for a renewal license hereunder shall submit to the city clerk with his renewal application a renewal license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 4) Sec. 26-38. - Surrender of general license. Upon being issued a license under this article for a going-out-of-business sale, the licensee shall surrender to the city clerk all other business licenses he may hold at that time applicable to the location and goods covered by the application for a license under this article. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 5) Sec. 26-39. - Nature of sale. A license issued under this article shall authorize only the one type of sale described in the application at the location named therein. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 5) Sec. 26-40. - Saleable goods. A license issued under this article shall authorize only the sale of goods described in the inventory attached to the application. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 5) Sec. 26-41. - Transfer. Any license provided for in this article shall not be assignable or transferable. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 5) Sec. 26-42. - Duration. A license issued under this article shall authorize the sale described in the application for a period of not more than sixty (60) consecutive days, Sundays and legal holidays excluded, following the issuance thereof. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 5) Sec. 26-43. - Renewal. The city clerk shall renew a license issued under this article for one period of time only, such period to be in addition to the sixty (60) days permitted in the original license and not to exceed fifteen (15) consecutive days, Sundays and holidays excluded, when he finds: (1) That facts exist justifying the license renewal; (2) That the licensee has filed an application for renewal; (3) That the licensee has submitted with the application for renewal a revised inventory showing the items listed on the original inventory remaining unsold and not listing any goods not included in the original application and inventory. For the purposes of this subsection, any application for a license under the provisions of this article covering any goods previously inventoried as required hereunder, shall be deemed to be an application for renewal, whether presented by the original applicant, or by any other person. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 5) Sec. 26-44. - Interval between sales. Any person who has held a sale, as regulated under this article, at the location stated in the application, within one year last past from the date of such application, shall not be granted a license hereunder. (Ord. of 12-12-78, § 3)

div.head: Chapter 27 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Power of city as to streets and walkways, § 1-3(12), (18). Cross reference— Animals and fowl running at large upon streets of the city, § 4-1; underground utility damage prevention, § 5-270 et seq; obstructing walkways in cemeteries, § 6-1; flood hazard prevention, ch. 6.5; use of streets and passageways for charitable solicitations, § 13-63; roads in mobile home parks, § 14-107; walkways in mobile home parks, § 14-111; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 15; loitering, § 16-1; parks and recreation, ch. 17; planning and development, ch. 19; railroads, ch. 21; trains blocking streets, § 21-3; sewers, ch. 23; placing garbage, trash or refuse in streets or alleys, § 25-9; obstructing gutters, drains, walkways, or streets with garbage, rubbish or refuse, § 25-10; subdivisions, ch. 28; vehicles for hire, ch. 30; zoning, app.A. State Law reference— Obstructions in streets, Ga. Code Ann., § 36-30-10; franchises in streets, Ga. Code Ann., § 36-34-2(7); general powers of city as to streets and sidewalks, Ga. Code Ann., § 36-34-3.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 27-1. - Street numbers—Required. Any person owning a residence or other structure used for the housing of persons or property in the city shall secure and place upon said structure iridescent numbers indicating the correct street number according to the city directory, which said directory, marked "Official Directory," signed by the mayor and the city clerk and on file in the office of the city clerk, is hereby incorporated by reference as fully as if set out at length in this section. (Code 1968, § 21-1) Sec. 27-2. - Same—Placement. The street numbers to be placed as provided in the preceding section shall be placed about the front entrance to a structure in a secure manner, and in such manner as to be conspicuous and readable from the street or other public way leading to said structure. (Code 1968, § 21-2) Sec. 27-3. - Displays of food, merchandise on sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for any person to use any of the sidewalks of the city to display or to keep thereon any foods, wares or merchandise of any character. (Code 1968, § 21-7) Sec. 27-4. - Authority as to poles and wires in streets and public places. It shall be the duty of the building inspector acting as electrical inspector to so direct the placing of poles and wires in the streets, alleys and public places of the city that the same shall cause as little obstruction as possible, either to such thoroughfares or to the private use and enjoyment of adjacent property. It shall also be his duty, and he shall have authority, to compel the removal of unsafe or unnecessary poles. (Code 1968, § 21-4) State Law reference— Franchise for use of streets by utilities, Ga. Code Ann., § 36-34-2(7). Sec. 27-5. - Zones for joint use of wires, poles. On any pole of an electric light, power, telephone or telegraph company used jointly by two (2) or more such companies, each company shall be allotted a special zone and shall confine its wires to that zone. Spaces shall be measured from the tops of poles downward, and a suitable zone on every pole shall at all times be reserved for the free use of the city in stringing its fire alarm or police telegraph wires. (Code 1968, § 21-6) Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 9; police, ch. 20; telecommunications, ch. 29.5. Sec. 27-6. - Unlawful use of poles. Any person owning and using any poles and wires located in streets, alleys and public places, who shall fail or refuse, after five (5) days' notice from the building inspector acting as electrical inspector, to remove any pole deemed by him unsuitable, unsafe or improperly located, or the location of which he shall require to be changed, shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-8, and the erection or use of any poles rejected or condemned by said officer shall subject the offender, upon conviction, to a like penalty. (Code 1968, § 21-5) Sec. 27-7. - Obstructing streets and sidewalks generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any street or sidewalk in any way or manner, except in cases of necessity occasioned by building, repairing, improving or other similar work, the necessity thereof to be judged by the mayor. (Code 1968, § 21-3) Charter reference— Obstructions on or near streets, § 1-3(16). State Law reference— Authority of city to permit obstructions in public streets, Ga. Code Ann., § 36-30-10. Sec. 27-8. - Playing games on streets and sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for any person to play ball, marbles or any other game on the streets or sidewalks of the city, except play streets, without written permission from the mayor, except that this shall not apply to schoolchildren on school grounds. (Code 1968, § 21-8) Sec. 27-9. - Curfew—Authority. Upon the issuance by the mayor of a proclamation imposing a curfew, no person shall remain upon the streets of the city, either as a pedestrian or in vehicles of whatever kind or character, except those who are bona fide transients through the city, after the hour of 10:00 p.m. and before 6:00 a.m. the following day, until such curfew has been terminated by proclamation of the mayor or by order of the mayor and council. (Code 1968, § 17-33) Sec. 27-10. - Same—Application to businesses. Upon the issuance by the mayor of a proclamation imposing a curfew, it shall be unlawful for any business to continue to do business past the hour of 10:00 p.m. and before 6:00 a.m. the following day until further notified by proclamation that such curfew has been terminated either by proclamation of the mayor or by order of the mayor and council. (Code 1968, § 17-34) Sec. 27-11. - Vagrancy. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to be and remain in a place, at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals, under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. (b) Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such alarm or immediate concern is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstance makes it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting him to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer did not comply with this procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person is true and, if believed by the officer at the time, would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. (Code 1968, § 17-41) Sec. 27-12. - Juvenile curfew. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: (1) Adult means a person who is at least seventeen (17) years of age or is an emancipated minor. (2) Curfew hours means 12:00 a.m. on any day until 6:00 a.m. of the same day. (3) Emancipated minor means: a. Any person under the age of seventeen (17) years who is or has been married or who is not under the care, custody, and control of a parent, parents, guardian, person standing in locus parentis, or the juvenile court of competent jurisdiction; or b. Any person under the age of seventeen (17) years who has had the disabilities of minority removed by a court of competent jurisdiction. (4) Establishment means any privately owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited including, but not limited to, any place of amusement or entertainment. (5) Guardian means a person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor, or a public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by the court. (6) Loiter means to stand or sit idly about or to linger at a place aimlessly. (7) Minor means any person sixteen (16) years of age or under. (8) Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term "operator" includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and officers of a corporation. (9) Parent means a person who is a natural parent, an adopted parent, or stepparent of another person. (10) Prescribed authority means when a parent/guardian grants supervisory rights of a minor to an adult to oversee a minor's activity. (11) Public place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access that includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, alleys, roads, parks, sidewalks, public buildings and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities, and shops. (12) Remain means linger or stay, or fail to leave premises when requested to do so by an officer or the owner, operator, or the person in control of the premises. (13) Serious bodily injury means bodily injury that causes death or creates a substantial risk of serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. (14) Vacant property means a parcel of land which is either an unimproved parcel or an improved parcel which is unoccupied. (15) Wander means to move about aimlessly. (b) Persons sixteen years of age or younger. Curfew for persons sixteen (16) years of age or younger is as follows: (1) It is unlawful for any minor, to loiter, wander or play in or upon the public places, establishments or vacant property in the city unsupervised by a parent, guardian or through prescribed authority and having the lawful authority to be in such places, between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. (2) It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other person having custody or control of any minor sixteen (16) years of age or younger to knowingly allow or by insufficient control allow such minor to loiter, wander or play in or upon a public place, establishment or vacant property unsupervised between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. (3) It shall be unlawful for any owner, operator, or employee of an establishment to knowingly allow a minor to loiter, wander or play unsupervised in or upon the premises of the establishment in the city between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the owner, operator, or employee of an establishment promptly notified the police department that a minor was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave. (c) Exceptions.
