(5) The mechanisms, such as performance bonds, security funds or letters of credit, to be put in place to ensure the performance of the grantee's obligations under the franchise or revocable license; (6) For the limited purpose of ensuring that the grantee is complying with the terms of the franchise or revocable license, including, but not limited to, any compensation or street management provisions, the city's right to inspect the facilities and records of the grantee; (7) Insurance and indemnification requirements applicable to the grantee; (8) The obligation of the grantee to maintain complete and accurate books of account and records with respect to its obligations under the franchise or revocable license, including, but not limited to, any compensation or street management provisions, and the city's inspection rights with respect thereto; (9) Provisions to ensure quality workmanship and construction methods in the streets; (10) Provisions to ensure that the grantee will comply with all applicable city, state and federal laws, regulations, rules and policies; (11) Provisions to ensure adequate oversight by the city of the grantee's use of streets and compliance with the franchise or revocable license; (12) Provisions relating to an assignment or other transfer of the franchise or revocable license or the telecommunications system that results in a change in control; (13) Remedies available to the city to protect the city's interest in the event of the grantee's failure to comply with terms and conditions of the franchise or revocable license; (14) Provisions to ensure that the grantee will obtain all licenses and permits necessary to provide telecommunications services by use of the city's streets from any governmental body having jurisdiction over the grantee, including, but not limited to, the Federal Communications Commission; (15) Provisions to ensure that the grantee will protect the property of the city from damage or interruption of city operations resulting from the construction, operation, maintenance, repair or removal of improvements of the telecommunications system, or from the provision of facility services; (16) Provisions designed to minimize the extent to which the public use of the streets of the city are disrupted in connection with the construction of improvements relating to the telecommunications system, or the provision of facility services; and (17) Such other provisions as the city reasonably determines are necessary or appropriate to permit the city to manage its streets or ensure compliance with the franchise or revocable license, to the extent not prohibited by law. (b) The city clerk may make available to an applicant a model franchise or revocable license, as applicable, containing the terms and conditions the city seeks to impose pursuant to subsection (a) hereinabove. The city clerk shall have the right to modify from time to time such model franchise or revocable license, so long as such modifications are consistent with this article and applicable law. (Ord. (W-9-01) of 10-2-01, § I) Sec. 29.5-60. - Revocation of revocable license. The revocable license shall be revocable at any time by the city for cause or, if the revocable license is for the provision of private telecommunications services or facility services, for the city's convenience. The revocable license, together with all revocable licenses granted to the applicant or affiliated persons, shall not authorize the occupation and use of more than five hundred (500) linear feet of specifically identified streets, unless the use or occupation of the streets does not involve the offering or provision of telecommunications services by the grantee, any affiliated persons or any other persons to or from any person or location in the city, or unless the use or occupation of the streets is for the provision of facility services. (Ord. (W-9-01) of 10-2-01, § I) Sec. 29.5-61. - Severability. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or other portion of this article is, for any reason, declared invalid, in whole or in part, by any court, agency, commission, legislative body or other authority of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent portion. Such declaration shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof, which other portions shall continue in full force and effect. (Ord. (W-9-01) of 10-2-01, § I) Sec. 29.5-62. - Delegation. Consistent with applicable law, the city council shall have the right to delegate and redelegate, and to revoke any such delegation or redelegation, from time to time, any of its rights or obligations under this article to any body, organization or official. Any such delegation, redelegation or revocation, no matter how often made, shall not be deemed an amendment to this article or to require the consent of any applicant for a franchise or revocable license or grantee. The city council may also establish and appoint one or more advisory boards, with such duration and such number of members as the city council shall determine, to advise it on such of the matters which are the subject of this article. (Ord. (W-9-01) of 10-2-01, § I) Sec. 29.5-63. - Application to existing telecommunications systems and providers of telecommunications services and private telecommunications services. This article shall not be retroactively applied to franchises for the operation of telecommunications systems used to provide telecommunications services existing on the effective date of this article, but shall apply to any renewal or extension of such franchises. (Ord. (W-9-01) of 10-2-01, § I) Sec. 29.5-64. - Applicability of other ordinances. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this article are hereby repealed. (Ord. (W-9-01) of 10-2-01, § I) Sec. 29.5-65. - Franchise fee for state issued cable or video franchise. This city hereby requires a franchise fee of five (5) per cent of gross revenues generated within the city for any cable or video state franchise issued in its corporate boundaries by the State of Georgia. (Ord. (W-03-08) of 4-8-08) Sec. 29.5-66. - Authorized designee. The city hereby authorizes the city administrator or his designee, upon receipt of notice to the city of its right to designate a franchise fee for an applicant for or holder of an existing state franchise, to provide written notice to the secretary of state and each applicant for or holder of a state franchise within a service area that is wholly or partially located within the city limits of the five (5) per cent franchise fee rate applicable to such applicant or holder of a state franchise. (Ord. (W-03-08) of 4-8-08) Sec. 29.5-67. - Due compensation for telephone companies with end user retail customers within the city. (a) The city hereby requires due compensation of three (3) percent of actual recurring local service revenues, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1(b)(8) and (9), provided, however, that any company which pays in excess of three (3) percent of actual recurring local service revenues pursuant to an existing franchise agreement shall continue to pay in accordance with the agreement until the expiration of the franchise agreement or December 31, 2012, whichever occurs first, and any company which pays in excess of three (3) percent of actual recurring local service revenues in accordance with an occupational license tax arrangement shall continue to pay in accordance with such payment schedule until December 31, 2012. (b) Regarding any telephone company that does not have retail, end user customers located within the city's municipal boundaries, the payment by such company to a municipal authority in accordance with the rates set by regulations promulgated by the department of transportation for the use of its rights-of-way shall be considered the payment of due compensation. (Ord. (W-11-09), 6-29-09) Sec. 29.5-68. - Authorized designee. The city administrator shall, on behalf of the city, exercise day-to-day administrative duties necessary to fulfill the regulatory authority of the city under O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1, et seq. and shall perform the following duties: (a) Review application information submitted by a telephone company to the city and, if an application is incomplete, notify the telegraph or telephone company within fifteen (15) business days of the receipt of such application, identifying in such notice all application deficiencies. (b) Report the receipt of a completed application to the council within sixty (60) calendar days of the receipt of such completed application. (c) Review payments of due compensation submitted by the company to ensure compliance with the provisions of the amended law and this section. (d) Provide a coordination function between a telephone company and all city departments on any matter relating to the amended law and this section. (e) Arrange and evaluate, no more than once a year, a comprehensive review of the records of a company which is reasonably related to the calculation and payment of due compensation. (f) Provide to all telegraph and telephone companies located in its rights-of-way written notice of annexations and changes in municipal corporate boundaries. (Ord. (W-11-09), 6-29-09)

div.head: Chapter 30 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Power of city to regulate and license vehicles operated for hire, § 1-3(10). Cross reference— Licenses and business regulations, ch. 13; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 15; streets and sidewalks, ch. 27. State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate traffic, Ga. Code Ann., § 40-6-371.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 30-1. - Effect on buses. The limitations of this chapter are not to pertain to a properly constructed bus, which has a seating capacity for more than nine (9) persons. However, where any bus, operated by any person within the city for hire in the transportation of passengers, does not have individual seats for each passenger, not more than three (3) passengers shall be seated on a seat therein, and in the event said seat shall not exceed the width of three (3) feet, not more than one passenger to each one and one-half (1½) feet shall be seated thereon for transportation. (Code 1968, § 26-1) Secs. 30-2—30-17. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 30-18. - Definitions. Words and phrases used in this article shall have the meanings respectively ascribed herein: Driver: Any person in charge of or operating a cab or taxicab, whether as owner, agent, employee or otherwise. Highway: Any of the public streets, boulevards, avenues, drives or alleys of the city. Owner: Any person having control of the operation or maintenance of, and collection of the revenue derived from, taxicabs, livery cars and sight-seeing cars. Permit: The written authority granted by the mayor and council to engage in the cab or taxicab business in the city. Taxicab or cab: A motor-driven vehicle of distinctive color or design with a seating capacity of not less than five (5) nor more than seven (7) persons including the driver, operated for hire from a fixed stand in the street or from garages, the destination of which is under the direction of the passenger or passengers transported therein. Taximeter: Any meter which is an instrument or device attached to a taxicab and measuring mechanically the distance driven and the waiting time upon which the cab fare is based. Waiting time: The time when a taxicab is not in motion, beginning with the arrival of the cab at the point to which it has been called and the time consumed while standing at the direction of a passenger or passengers. (Code 1968, § 26-13) Sec. 30-19. - Scope of article. Every person engaged in the operation of any vehicle in the city for hire in the transportation of passengers, commonly known as taxicabs, shall be subject to the rules and regulations contained in this article pertaining to their operation upon the public streets. (Code 1968, § 26-12) Sec. 30-20. - Violations. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, at the option of the mayor and council, have his permit or license, or both, revoked and in addition shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-8 of this Code. (Code 1968, § 26-46) Sec. 30-21. - Owner's license fee; amount, payment required. All persons engaged in the taxicab business in the city shall pay to the city a license fee for engaging in such business, the amount of such fee to be as prescribed in section 13-31(150) of this Code. (Code 1968, § 26-19) Sec. 30-22. - Owner's identification, rate card displayed. (a) Every taxicab shall display inside the cab, at a convenient place visible to passengers, a card not less than two (2) inches in width by four (4) inches in length, which shall have printed thereon the name, business address and telephone number of the owner and the rates charged for the use of such vehicle. (b) Every such car shall have displayed on each side thereof the name and telephone number of the owner in letters and numerals of such size as to be readily visible to the public, and not less than three (3) inches high. (Code 1968, § 26-35) Sec. 30-23. - Taximeters—Required. All taxicabs operating in the city shall be equipped with taximeters of the type required by this article; provided however, that in case of any unusual demand for taxicabs in the city the mayor and council may in their discretion suspend the taximeter requirements for a limited time and authorize licensed taxicabs to operate without a taximeter within the rates specified by the mayor and council. (Code 1968, § 26-36) Sec. 30-24. - Same—Use. The use of taximeters on taxicabs shall be subject to the following rules and regulations: (1) Taximeters shall be fastened in front of the passengers, visible to them at all times, day and night; and after sundown, the face of the taximeter shall be illuminated. They shall be operated mechanically by a mechanism of standard design and construction, driven either from the transmission or from one of the front wheels by a flexible and permanently attached driving mechanism. They shall be sealed at all points and connections which, if manipulated, would affect their correct reading and recording. (2) Taximeters shall be subject to inspection from time to time by the police department. Any inspector or other officer of said department shall be authorized, either with or without complaint of any person, to inspect any meter and, upon discovery of any inaccuracy therein, to notify the person operating said taxicab to cease operation, whereupon such taxicab shall be removed from the highways until the taximeter is repaired and put in satisfactory working condition. (Code 1968, § 26-37) Sec. 30-25. - Regulation of rates. The mayor and council shall have the right at any time to regulate the rates and fares to be charged by taxicabs in the city. Taxicab rates advertised and charged shall be computed only upon a meter basis. Rates and fees shall be filed as part of the business license application and updated annually as part of the license renewal process. Rates shall be posted inside the taxicab in a place visible to passengers. (Code 1968, § 26-38; Ord. (W-45-06) of 12-5-06) Sec. 30-26. - Fare—Refusal to pay. It shall be unlawful for any person to use a motor vehicle operated as a taxicab and refuse to pay therefor the amount accrued on the taximeter. (Code 1968, § 26-40) Sec. 30-27. - Same—Receipts. The driver of any vehicle covered by this article shall at all times, when requested by a passenger, render a receipt for the fare charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or by a specially prepared receipt on which shall be set out the name of the owner, the license number or motor number, the amount of meter recording or charges and the date of the transaction. (Code 1968, § 26-39) Sec. 30-28. - Insurance. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab in the city unless a certificate or policy of automobile liability and property damage insurance has been issued, covering said taxicab, in the amounts of not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for injury to one (1) person, one hundred thousand ($100,000.00) for injuries to more than one (1) person in one (1) accident and twenty five thousand ($25,000.00) for property damage. Evidence of such insurance shall be produced by the operator upon request therefore. In the event state minimum insurance requirements exceed these amounts, these amounts will automatically increase to those set by the state. (Code 1968, § 26-41; Ord. (W-42-06) of 12-5-06) Charter reference— Power of city to fix the amount of public liability insurance on taxicabs, § 1-3(10). State Law reference— Motor vehicle insurance, Ga. Code Ann., § 40-9-37. Sec. 30-29. - Inspection of vehicle—Required. Each vehicle operating as a taxicab in the city may periodically be inspected by the chief of police, and the chief of police shall have full authority to remove from the streets of the city any vehicle operating as a taxicab, not meeting required safety standards, until the necessary repairs are made and the vehicle is approved by the chief of police. (Code 1968, § 26-42) Sec. 30-30. - Same—Certificate. The chief of police may periodically require the owner or operator of a taxicab to submit a certificate of inspection to the city clerk or his/her designee for the information of the police department and the mayor and council. Said certificate shall be in the form prescribed by the mayor and council, showing the mechanical condition of the vehicle and the serviceability of the body, and the condition of the tires on said vehicle and their serviceability. The prescribed form shall be obtained from the city clerk or his/her designee. A sticker will be issued annually upon registration and presentment of a completed safety standards inspection sheet as part of a new business license application or renewal. The sticker shall be affixed to the vehicle itself or displayed to show it has been registered or inspected. (Code 1968, § 26-43; Ord. (W-30-06) of 12-5-06) Sec. 30-31. - Suspension of operation of vehicles—Authority. The chief of police may suspend from operation any taxicab found to be unsafe, and any vehicle so suspended shall not be operated again until repaired and put in proper condition for use, and then only after its condition has been approved by the chief of police. Likewise, the chief of police may suspend from operation any city driver's license or any taxicab if the taxicab is found in charge of any person other than the driver licensed by the city, and also when found in charge of an intoxicated driver. (Code 1968, § 26-44) Sec. 30-32. - Same—Effect. The chief of police shall report his actions under the preceding section to the mayor and council for consideration, and the license of an intoxicated driver shall be taken up and deposited with the city clerk. It shall be unlawful for such driver to refuse to deliver the license to the chief of police on demand. (Code 1968, § 26-44) Sec. 30-33. - Same—Duration of suspension. Any suspension from operation of a taxicab or license under the second sentence in section 30-31 will be for not more than fifteen (15) days. Sec. 30-34. - Cruising. It shall be unlawful for any person operating a taxicab to cruise, for the purpose of soliciting passengers, within the city. (Code 1968, § 26-45) Sec. 30-35. - Taxicab zones. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked any vehicle except a taxicab within those areas where the curbing is marked by lines and where there is a sign denoting the same as a parking space for taxicabs only, such areas being reserved for the use of taxicabs only. (Code 1968, § 16-115) Charter reference— Power of city to regulate and rent taxicab parking spaces, § 1-3(10). Sec. 30-36. - Transporting alcoholic beverages. Persons operating taxicabs upon the highways of the city are prohibited from transporting alcoholic beverages in a taxicab when no passengers are present or as regulated by state. (Ord. No. W-37-06, 12-5-06) Secs. 30-37—30-46. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERMIT
Sec. 30-47. - Required. No person shall operate a taxicab upon the highways of the city until a permit has been granted after the application therefor has been approved and the fees for the permit have been paid. (Code 1968, § 26-14) Sec. 30-48. - Reserved. Sec. 30-49. - Application—Contents; filing. An application for a taxicab permit shall be in writing, addressed to the mayor and council and shall be filed with the city clerk or his/her designee. It shall contain the full name and address of the applicant, and if the applicant is a corporation, the names of its officers. It shall also state the business to be engaged in, the location from which the business is to be operated, the type of equipment to be used, the maximum number of passengers each vehicle is manufactured to carry, the number of vehicles to be operated and such other information as may be requested by the mayor and council. (Code 1968, § 26-15; Ord. (W-30-06) of 12-5-06) Charter reference— Power of city to limit the number of vehicles operated for hire, § 1-3(10). Sec. 30-50. - Same—Investigation; approval. Upon the filing of an application for a taxicab permit with the city clerk or his/her designee, the mayor and council shall refer the same to the police chief to investigate the applicant. The police chief shall make its report to the mayor and council at its next regular meeting and the mayor and council shall either approve or deny the application. If the application is approved, the city clerk or his/her designee shall issue the permit. (Code 1968, § 26-16 Ord. (W-30-06) of 12-5-06) Sec. 30-51. - Driver's license. No permit shall be issued to any person to operate a taxicab in the city before the person who is to drive said taxicab is approved for driving a motor vehicle by the state department of public safety after an examination given by said department. (Code 1968, § 26-17) Charter reference— Power of city to require operators of vehicles for hire to be licensed, § 1-3(10). State Law reference— Issuance of driver's licenses, Ga. Code Ann., § 40-5-20 et seq. Sec. 30-52. - Appeal from denial. Any person applying for a taxicab permit which is denied by the police chief for any cause, may appear before the mayor and council at their next meeting following the denial of said permit or at such time as the mayor and council shall designate, and request that said mayor and council review the application for permit and the reason for refusal. Said mayor and council shall review the application as requested, and, in their discretion, may overrule the police chief and order the permit issued on behalf of the mayor and council. (Code 1968, § 26-18; Ord. (W-41-06) of 12-5-06) Sec. 30-53. - Posted. A taxicab permit shall be posted at all times in the taxicab vehicle in a conspicuous manner so that it can be easily seen by any passengers transported in said vehicle. (Code 1968, § 26-21) Sec. 30-54. - Transfer, encumbrance. No taxicab permit granted to any person under this division may be sold, assigned, transferred, leased or mortgaged by the holder. (Code 1968, § 26-22) Sec. 30-55. - Suspension, revocation—Grounds. The wilful violation of any ordinance of the city or the laws of the state shall be grounds for the suspension or permanent revocation of a taxicab permit as set out in this division. (Code 1968, § 26-23) Sec. 30-56. - Same—Power of mayor. When the mayor and council are not in session, the mayor shall have the authority and power, in his discretion, upon sufficient evidence or information, to suspend the permit of any taxicab owner or operator for a period of sixty (60) days by a written order, a copy of which shall be served upon said owner or operator of a taxicab within two (2) days after the suspension of his permit, and he shall address a communication in writing to the mayor and council of his action in the premises in suspending such permit and the reason therefor. (Code 1968, § 26-24) Sec. 30-57. - Same—Appeal. The owner or operator of a taxicab shall be entitled to a hearing before the mayor and council upon application therefor, for said body to determine whether or not the suspension of his permit to operate a taxicab shall be made permanent or not within the city; provided such application is filed with the city clerk within five (5) days from the date of suspension by the mayor. (Code 1968, § 26-25) Sec. 30-58. - Operation of taxicab during suspension. It shall be unlawful for an owner or operator or any driver employed by such owner or operator during the period of suspension of a taxicab permit to furnish service under the permit issued by the city, and a violation of this section shall be punishable by the city as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. Such penalty to be in addition to the suspension. (Code 1968, § 26-26) Sec. 30-59. - Disposition of permit during suspension. Any taxicab permit of any owner or operator in the city which has been suspended by the mayor shall be returned to the city clerk, to be retained by said clerk during the period of suspension and until the suspension by the mayor is revoked and relieved by the mayor and council. (Code 1968, § 26-27) Sec. 30-60. - When revoked. If the suspension of a taxicab permit is made permanent and the permit is revoked by the mayor and council, the permit shall be canceled by the city clerk. (Code 1968, § 26-28) Secs. 30-61—30-71. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - CITY DRIVER'S LICENSE
Sec. 30-72. - Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any of the vehicles regulated by the provisions of this article until he first shall have obtained a driver's license therefor, from the mayor and council, as provided in this division. (Code 1968, § 26-29) Charter reference— Power of city to require operators of vehicles for hire to be licensed, § 1-3(10). Sec. 30-73. - Application—Submission. Before any person shall drive any of the vehicles regulated by this article, he shall make written application to the mayor and council for a taxicab driver's license upon blanks furnished by the city. (Code 1968, § 26-30) Sec. 30-74. - Same—Contents. Every applicant for a taxicab driver's license under this division shall provide the following information on the application therefor: (1) The age and home address of the applicant. (2) Whether the applicant is of sound physique. (3) Whether the applicant has good eyesight. (4) Whether the applicant uses intoxicating liquors, drugs or narcotics. (5) Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of violating any city, state or federal criminal law, and if so, the number of times, the kinds of offenses and the sentences imposed. (6) Any other such information as may be required by the mayor and council. (Code 1968, § 26-31) Sec. 30-75. - Same—Investigation. The chief of police is hereby charged with the duty of investigating the facts stated in an application for taxicab driver's license before recommending to the mayor and council the granting of such license, and the mayor and council shall not grant such license to any person which is not at least eighteen (18) years of age nor to any person who in the opinion of the police department is not physically, mentally and morally fit to operate a taxicab upon the highways of the city. Background checks will be run on each driver at renewal each year and on each new driver upon application for a taxicab driver's business license. (Code 1968, § 26-32; Ord. (W-45-06) of 12-5-06) Sec. 30-76. - Fee. The charge for the issuance of a taxicab driver's license shall be the amount prescribed in section 13-31(150) per calendar year, and said license shall be valid for the calendar year in which issued and only for that calendar year. (Code 1968, § 26-33) Sec. 30-77. - Issuance, display. If the mayor and council shall grant a taxicab driver's license to an applicant, the city clerk or his/her designee shall issue to the holder thereof a badge or license card of a design, and bearing such words and numerals, as may be fixed by the mayor and council, including suitable space thereon to enable the applicant to attach his photograph of size and design likewise to be fixed by said mayor and council. Such person shall attach his photograph to his license card and shall keep said card posted in view of passengers at all times when operating a taxicab. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any such vehicle upon the highways unless the driver has posted such license card, therein, in full view as provided in this section. (Code 1968, § 26-34; Ord. (W-44-06) of 12-5-06)

div.head: Chapter 31 - WATER[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. (W-12-13) § 1, adopted Oct. 21, 2013, repealed the former Ch. 31, §§ 31-1—31-17, and enacted a new Ch. 31 as set out herein. The former Ch. 31 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for a complete history of former Ch. 31. Charter reference— Powers of city as to public utilities, § 1-3(21), (22); special assessments, § 4-15. Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 5; fire prevention and protection, ch. 9; housing, ch. 12; mobile homes, ch. 14; planning and development, ch. 19; sewers, ch. 23; solid waste, ch. 25; underground utility damage prevention, § 5-170 et seq.; provisions for flood hazard reduction, § 9.5-31 et seq.; flood hazards, § 19-1 et seq. State Law reference— Municipal water systems generally, Ga. Code Ann., § 36-34-5 and Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV.
Sec. 31-1. - Scope of chapter. The rules and regulations in this chapter shall govern payment by consumers for water furnished such consumers by the water system of the city and its water service territory. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-2. - Water rates and charges not affected by Code. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance relating to rates and charges under this chapter, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-3. - Water charges. The schedule of charges for water service effective in the city shall be fixed from time to time by the mayor and council. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-4. - Deposit before service turned on—Required. Before water service is turned on and city utility services are provided, utility deposits shall be made with the city according to a schedule of deposits and subject to exceptions and provisions as adopted in policy. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-5. - Deposit—Refund. (a) If a deposit is required, it shall be refunded without interest, or applied as a credit to an open account, at the end of twelve (12) consecutive months of on-time and in-full payment of the bills for all water services. Any remainder shall also be refunded without interest upon termination of service by the customer and payment in-full of all outstanding charges. (b) Due date. All refunds shall be paid or credited to an open account within 30 days after the finance director or designee determines that such refund is due. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-6. - Use of mails for billing and payment. All bills and accounts for the amounts charged for water service and water used from the city's water system shall be mailed to the respective consumers, with proper postage affixed and addressed to the consumer at the address where such water service may be furnished; however, neither the city nor its employees shall be responsible for such bills and water accounts not reaching customers, nor for such remittance made through the mails therefor not reaching the city in due time. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-7. - Tampering and theft of services. (a) Under no circumstances is any customer or individual authorized to turn water back on or alter services if water service has been disconnected by the city. Only authorized city staff or contracted employees may connect services or work on city lines. (b) All persons are prohibited from interfering with or disturbing in any manner or form, any water meters, radio equipment, switches, locks, cutoffs or other appliances of the city, including fire hydrants, or to appropriate or use any water after service has been cut off or discontinued for nonpayment or in order to avoid payment. (c) The property owner, legal tenant, or person(s) noted on the utility account shall be held responsible for the violation of this section. A tampering fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be assessed where a meter or water line has been disturbed. A tampering fine of seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) shall be assessed for tampering with a fire hydrant or any fire meter. (d) The City of Winder reserves the right to prosecute in the accordance with established laws after any tampering of water services has been discovered. (e) If, after removal of service, an alternative means of obtaining water service is attempted (such as a "jumper" or straight piping), then the water service to that property will be removed until such time as the case can appear and be settled before the city's municipal court. (f) If the city determines theft of service has occurred, it reserves the right to adjust the customer's current bill and the bills for the past six (6) months usage. If the approximate amount of service that was stolen cannot be reasonably determined, the customer's usage will be set at three (3) times the average volume. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-8. - Damage to meter and radio equipment. (a) Customers shall be responsible to ensure that city equipment is not damaged through the routine maintenance adjacent to city equipment/property. The property owner may be deemed responsible for damages to city meters and equipment. (b) The city reserves the right to assess the cost of the damaged equipment to the utility account. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-9. - Responsibility for damages and maintenance to service lines. The city shall in no event be responsible for maintaining any service line owned by the consumer, nor for damage done by water escaping therefrom, nor for defects in lines or fixtures, on the property of the consumer. The consumer shall at all times comply with all regulations of the city and of regulations relating to the service lines, and shall make all changes in the line as required on account of change in grade or otherwise. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-10. - Wasting water; repair of leaks. (a) Whenever it comes to the attention of the utilities department that any service connection upon the property of any owner is leaking, the utilities department shall serve written notice upon the property owner requiring the owner to repair the condition. If the property owner does not repair the leak within five (5) days after receiving the notice, the city shall be authorized to disconnect water service until notification that the leak has been corrected and has been verified. (b) The city administrator or designee, upon investigation of any leaks or waste that may jeopardize the city's water system or deemed a nuisance, will be disconnected immediately. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-11. - Suspension of service. (a) When water service is discontinued and all bills paid, the security deposit shall be refunded to the consumer by the city. (b) Upon discontinuance of service for nonpayment of bills, the security deposit will be applied by the city toward the settlement of the account. Any balance will be refunded to the consumer; however, if the security deposit is insufficient to cover the bill, the city may proceed to collect the balance in the usual way provided by law for collection of debts. (c) The city reserves the right to discontinue its service without notice for the following additional reasons: (1) To prevent fraud or abuse; (2) Consumer's willful disregard of the city's policy; (3) Emergency repairs; (4) Insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the city's control; (5) Legal processes; (6) Direction of public authorities; (7) Strike, riot, fire, flood or unavoidable accident. (d) Service disconnected for nonpayment of bills will be restored only after bills are paid in full, including the service charge (delinquent fee) in an amount set forth in the schedule of fees and charges to be paid for each meter reconnected. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-12. - Cross connection and backflow prevention. (a) Employees of the city water system are authorized to discontinue water service when necessary to prevent contamination of the public water supply or public water system due to possible cross connections or when it is necessary to protect the water system or individual properties from emergency cross connection or backflow situations. (b) The city water system and utilities department is further authorized to install or require to be installed suitable backflow prevention devices at the customer's service connection or other areas as needed to prevent contamination or the risk of contamination of the public water system. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-13. - Installation of meters. (a) Upon payment of all associated fees, the city shall install water meters on the premises or property occupied by all users of water furnished by the city, both within and without the corporate limits of the city. All users of water shall pay the entire expense of such installation in advance. (b) The city administrator is authorized to allow a customer of an existing residence who is currently on a well and requesting to switch to city water to enter into payment arrangements not to exceed six (6) months. (c) In all multi-unit residential developments, each unit shall be individually metered. (d) Location of installation. Meters shall be installed as close to the property line of the customer as possible. All connections shall be inspected by a designated city employee from the utilities department. Only those properties where meters have been installed will be furnished water from the city's water system. (e) Access to premises. An authorized employee of the city shall have during times of normal operations noted between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. free access to the premises for the purpose of reading the meter or removing the same for the purpose of testing its accuracy. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-14. - Cost of water meters and installations thereof. (a) The city shall charge water customers for making taps in the city water mains according to the fees established by the mayor and council. (b) When the size of the meter is upgraded for any reason, the cost associated with the new meter size must be paid in full prior to any work being started. (c) When a customer requests a reduction in meter size, there will be no charge to the customer for the reduction of meters two (2) inches and below. Meters larger than two (2) inches will be handled according to a fee established by the mayor and council. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-15. - Service to fire suppression systems. (a) All new customers who request fire suppression service shall install a separate line. (b) The customer shall not be permitted to take water from the fire suppression system except for fire suppression purposes. (c) Monthly fees for fire suppression service will be charged in accordance with a schedule of fees established by the mayor and council. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-16. - Water construction standards. (a) General. All extensions of the water system shall be designed and built in accordance with current city standards. The standards shall be those stated in the latest edition of the City of Winder's Minimum Standards, which is available at the utilities department. No installation of pipe or other materials for water extensions shall be allowed until the required information is received and the design is approved by the City of Winder. Inspection and acceptance procedures shall be specified in the city's minimum standards. (b) Other regulations. Design and construction of water system extensions shall comply with all local, state, and federal rules and regulations pertaining to water line installation, including but not limited to rules and regulations for safety, erosion and sediment control, stream buffer protection, wetlands and water quality standards. (c) Authority. The mayor and city council are hereby authorized to issue and from time to time amend the water installation regulations and specifications. (d) Enforcement. Failure to comply with the provisions of this section may result in enforcement and fines as described in this chapter. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-17. - Ownership of water meters and service lines. (a) The City of Winder retains all ownership of water meters connected to the city's water system. (b) No applicant named on the utility bill or person associated with the property connected to the water distribution system shall sell, transfer or assign water rights to the City of Winder's system unless authorized in writing by the City of Winder. (c) Only city employees or those directly authorized by the city may work on water meters, water lines maintained by the city and/or tap into city water lines. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-18. - Restriction on outdoor watering of landscape. (a) Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants in the City of Winder water service area may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: (1) Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including, but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; or the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; (2) Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable City of Winder ordinances and state guidelines; (3) Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; (4) Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to provide reclaimed wastewater; (5) Watering personal food gardens; (6) Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of thirty (30) days immediately following the date of installation; (7) Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; (8) Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; (9) Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property is such well or surface water is on said property; (10) Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; (11) Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; (12) Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; (13) Hydroseeding. (b) No person shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in this section. Violations of this section shall be punishable in accordance with section 31-22 of this Code. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-19. - Emergency restrictions of service. The utilities director is authorized and empowered to implement water conservation measures during emergency conditions including implementation of such outdoor water use restrictions as may be recommended by state officials during such times and days as he deems necessary in any area served by the water system. When such water use restrictions are imposed, notice shall be given through the public media and published in the legal organ of the city. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-20. - Water service policies. In addition to all other provisions of this chapter, water services shall also be subject to such water service policies adopted by the mayor and council from time to time. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-21. - Customers outside the city limits. (a) Water customers located outside the corporate boundaries of the City of Winder are subject to the rules and regulations contained in this chapter. (b) The property owners shall pay all applicable tap fees to make the water available to the property. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-22. - Penalties. (a) Civil penalties. Violations of this chapter may be prosecuted upon citations issued by officers of the city police department. The violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine for each offense or violation not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense or violation. (b) Criminal penalties. Knowingly violating any provision of this chapter which poses or could pose a threat to public health or safety shall be considered a criminal act and shall be punishable by imprisonment and fines commensurate with the risk to the public as determined by the judiciary. (c) Additional penalties. In addition to civil and criminal penalties, any person violating any provision of this chapter may be liable to pay restitution in the discretion of the court for: (1) The total cost incurred by the city to repair or replace facilities damaged as a result of the violation; (2) Any injury or damage to person or property or loss of services resulting from the violation. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-23. - Collection costs for delinquent accounts. Customers that have a past due balance after disconnection are subject to being referred to collection agencies and are required to pay all fees as permitted by law. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) Sec. 31-24. - Charges constituting lien. The charges for water shall be a lien upon the account holder as provided for in the charter of the city. Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid sixty (60) days after it has been disconnected, the city clerk may file with the clerk of the Superior Court of Barrow County, a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain a legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the city claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges for water service subsequent to the period covered by the bill. (Ord. (W-12-13) of 10-21-13, § 1) APPENDIX A - COMPREHENSIVE ZONING ORDINANCE[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-W-89, adopted Aug. 8, 1989, repealed the former zoning ordinance, which was enacted June 20, 1963, as amended by Ord. No. 6-W-87 of July 7, 1987; and added a new zoning ordinance as herein set out with no substantive changes having been made by the editor. Absence of a history note in parentheses following a section indicates that the section originated from Ord. No. 11-W-89; conversely, the presence of a history note indicates an amendment thereto. Charter reference— Corporate powers of city to adopt zoning provisions, § 1-3(36). Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; alcoholic beverages, ch. 3; animals and fowl, ch. 4; buildings and building regulations, ch. 5; flood damage prevention ordinance, ch. 9.5; housing, ch. 12; mobile homes, ch. 14; loading zones, § 15-163 et seq.; planning and development, ch. 19; designation of historic districts, § 19-49; soil erosion and sedimentation control, ch. 24; subdivisions, ch. 28.
ARTICLE I. - AUTHORITY, JURISDICTION AND SHORT TITLE
Sec. 10. - Authority. This ordinance is in pursuance of the authority granted by the Georgia General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957, No. 358, as amended. Sec. 11. - Jurisdiction. The provisions of this ordinance shall govern all land, buildings and structures within the corporate limits of Winder, Georgia. Sec. 12. - Short title. This ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the "Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance, City of Winder, Georgia." ARTICLE II. - PURPOSE
Sec. 20. - Purposes enumerated. The purpose of this ordinance shall be: To lessen congestion in the streets; to secure safety from fire, panic and other dangers; to promote health and the general welfare; to provide adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue concentration of population; to facilitate the adequate provision of transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks and other public requirements; to sustain the stability of neighborhoods; to protect property against blight and depreciation; to secure economy in governmental expenditures; to conserve the value of buildings; to encourage the most appropriate use of land and all buildings and structures; and to assist the orderly, efficient and integrated development of the city. ARTICLE III. - DEFINITIONS
Sec. 30. - As used in this appendix. Except where specifically defined herein, all words used in this ordinance shall carry their customary dictionary meanings. For the purpose of this ordinance, certain words or terms herein are defined as follows. The singular includes the plural; the word building includes the word structure the word shall is intended to be mandatory; the word used or occupied as applied to any land or building shall be construed to include the words intended, arranged or designed to be used or occupied : Accessory building or use: A use or building customarily incident and subordinate to that of the principal building on the same building lot. Automobile wrecking yard or automobile used parts lot: Any place where three (3) or more vehicles not in running condition, or the parts thereof, are stored in the open or any building or structure used principally for wrecking or storage of automobiles not in running condition. Bar, pub or tavern: Any establishment selling alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises not otherwise qualified as a restaurant or brew pub. Brew pub: Any eating establishment in which beer or malt beverages are manufactured or brewed, subject to the barrel production limitation prescribed in O.C.G.A. section 3-5-36, for retail consumption on the premises and solely in draft form. As used in this appendix, the term "eating establishment" means an establishment which is licensed to sell distilled spirits, malt beverages, or wines for consumption on the premises and which derives at least fifty (50) percent of its total annual gross food and beverage sales from the sale of prepared meals or food. Billboard: Any sign or advertisement used as an outdoor display by the painting, posting or affixing on any surface of a picture, emblem, words, figures, numbers or lettering for the purpose of making anything known, such sign or advertisement being remote from the point of sale. Buffer: That portion of a lot, tract or parcel set aside for open space and visual screening purposes, pursuant to applicable provisions of this ordinance, to separate different use districts or to separate uses on one (1) property from uses on another property of the same use district or different use districts. Building: A structure for the shelter, support or enclosure of persons, animals or property. When separated from the ground or floor up without openings or connections, each portion of such building shall be deemed a separate building. Building height: The vertical distance measured from the level of the established grade opposite the middle of the front of the building to the highest point of the roof surface of a flat roof, to the deck of a mansard roof and to the mean height level between eaves and ridge for a gable, hip or gambrel roof. Building line: A line between which line and any property line of a district, lot, tract or parcel of land, no building or part of building may be erected, altered or maintained. Building line setback: The distance between the building line and the property line in a district, lot, tract or parcel. Chord length: The length of the front property line of a cul-de-sac lot that follows the circumference of the cul-de-sac right-of-way. Club, nonprofit: Buildings and facilities owned or operated by a corporation, association, person or persons for a social, educational or recreational purpose but not primarily for profit or to render a service which is customarily carried on as a business. Dance hall: A "dance hall" for the purposes of this appendix shall include any business where one (1) of its purposes is conducting, facilitating or promoting public dancing on the premises. Developer: Any person engaged in development or proposed site development. Dwelling: Any building which is designed or used for permanent living quarters for one (1) or more persons. Dwelling unit: A dwelling or portion thereof providing permanent living quarters for one (1) or more persons living as a single-housekeeping unit. First fire district: Beginning at the intersection of Park Avenue and Stephens Street and extending thence along Stephens Street to Center Street; thence along Center Street to May Street; thence along May Street to the point where the intersection would be if Park Avenue were extended on a projection from where Candler Street crosses said Park Avenue to said May Street. Household: One (1) or more persons occupying a dwelling unit and living as a single-housekeeping unit. Industrialized building: Any building or building component which is manufactured in accordance with the Georgia Industrialized Building Act and the rules of the commissioner of community affairs issued pursuant thereto. Each unit must bear a seal of approval issued by the commissioner or must be inspected during the time of manufacture by the inspection department of this jurisdiction. Institution: Any building or group of buildings used for public or private educational, religious, civic or other similar purpose. Live entertainment: For the purposes of this appendix live entertainment shall include, but is not limited to, any musical performance, theatrical performance, literary reading, and disc jockey performance, where the audience is present at the actual time of occurrence. Lodginghouse or boardinghouse: A building designed or used for the more or less permanent occupancy, with or without meals, of more than two (2) lodgers or boarders, whether the compensation is paid directly or indirectly. Lot: A lot or parcel of land occupied, capable of being occupied or intended to be occupied by a principal building or use and any accessory building and use customarily incident to it, and including open spaces not less than in extent than those required in connection therewith by this ordinance. Lot, corner: A lot which abuts at the intersection of two (2) or more streets or upon a curved street, provided that the two (2) sides of the lot or the tangents to the curve of the street line at its starting points at or within the sidelines of the lot intersect to form an interior angle of not more than one hundred thirty-five (135) degrees. Lot depth: The distance between front and rear lot lines. If two (2) opposite sides of said lot are not parallel, the depth shall be deemed to be the mean distance between the front and rear lot lines. Lot width: The distance between the side boundaries of the lot as measured at the building line. Lot line, front: Shall be the property line, except that the lot line shall not exceed past a point five (5) feet from the curb on the point where the curb would ordinarily be placed. Lot line, rear: Shall mean the rear lot line boundary opposite and more or less parallel to the front lot line. Lot line, side: Shall mean a side lot boundary line. Manufactured home: A single-family dwelling that is constructed in accordance with the Federal Manufactured Home Construction and Safety Standards and bears an insignia issued by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). Mobile home: Any vehicle or similar portable structure having been constructed with wheels (whether or not such wheels have been removed) or being constructed off-site and transported to the lot or having no foundation other than wheels, jacks or skirting and so designed or constructed as to permit occupancy for dwelling or sleeping purposes. The term shall include manufactured and modular homes. Mobile home park: Any plot of ground upon which two (2) or more mobile homes, occupied for dwelling purposes, are located, regardless of whether or not a change is made for such accommodations. Mobile home park plan: A plan prepared by a registered engineer showing all existing conditions and the proposed site development of a mobile home park. Mobile home space: A plot of ground within a mobile home park designed for the accommodation of one (1) mobile home. Modular home: A factory-fabricated, single-family dwelling which is constructed in one (1) or more sections and complies with the definition of industrialized building. Multiple dwelling: Any structure designed and intended to accommodate more than one (1) family and shall include, but is not limited to, duplex buildings, group houses and apartment buildings. Parking space: An area of appropriate dimensions of not less than nine (9) feet by eighteen (18) feet, exclusive of access or maneuvering area, to be used exclusively as a temporary storage space for private motor vehicles. Truck loading and unloading space shall not be included in such area. Public entertainment: For the purposes of this appendix, public entertainment shall include live entertainment and public dancing. Public entertainment facility: A business which is open to the public and provides public entertainment or live entertainment, including, but not limited to, dance halls, is a public entertainment facility for the purposes of this appendix. Restaurant: The word "restaurant" for the purpose of this appendix shall have the same definition as set forth in section 3-1 of chapter 3 of this Code. Sign, business: An attached or freestanding structure on which is stated the business use of the premises or the name of the operator of the business. Sign, outdoor advertising: An attached or freestanding structure conveying some idea, information or knowledge to the public. Site plan: A map of a proposed development or subdivision. A site plan will be submitted as part of an application for a zone change variance, conditional use permit or subdivision. The site plan should show property lines, buildings, roads, natural features and the north direction (north arrow). Street: A public or private thoroughfare which affords the principal means of access to abutting property. Structure: Anything constructed or erected on the ground or attached to the ground. The term includes tents, bleachers, gasoline pumps, automobile house trailers, advertising signs, billboards, portable vehicles or structures from which products are sold. Travel trailer: Any vehicle or similar portable structure mounted on wheels, designed and intended primarily for short-term occupancy, for dwelling or sleeping or other purposes and not exceeding thirty (30) feet in length. Undisturbed buffer: No land-disturbing activities shall be conducted within the buffer and the buffer shall remain in its natural, undisturbed state of vegetation until all land-disturbing activities on the construction site are completed. Once the final stabilization of the site is achieved, the buffer may be thinned or trimmed of noxious weeds, noxious plants and like vegetation, as long as protective vegetative cover remains. No trees, other than dead or diseased trees shall be removed from the buffer, but additional trees and plant material may be added to the zone. Dead limbs and branches, trash, litter and like debris may be removed from the buffer at any time. The buffer zone shall be maintained in a natural state and shall not be paved or graded. No building shall be erected or placed in a buffer zone and a buffer zone shall not be used for parking, storage, loading, animal pens or any other use. Unless otherwise specified by the Winder City Council, all undisturbed buffers shall have a minimum width of twenty-five (25) feet. Yard, front: An open space extending the full width of a lot and of a depth measured horizontally at right angles to the front lot line. Yard, rear: An open space on the same lot with a principal building, unoccupied except by a permitted accessory building or use, extending the full width of the lot and located between the rear line of the lot and the rear line of the building projected to the sidelines of the lot. Yard, side: An open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a principal building located between the side of the building and the sideline of the lot and extending from the rear line of the front yard to the front line of the rear yard. Sec. 40. - Districts enumerated. For the purposes of this ordinance, the city is hereby divided into the following districts or zones:

(Ord. (W-6-97) of 5-6-97) Sec. 42. - Rules governing district boundaries. Where uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of any of the aforementioned districts as shown on the comprehensive zoning map, the following rules shall apply: 42.1. Unless otherwise indicated, the zone boundaries are the centerlines of streets, railroad rights-of-way, streams or extensions of such lines. Sec. 50. - Application of regulations. Upon the effective date of the adoption of this ordinance, no building, structure or premises shall hereafter be used, and no building, structure or part thereof shall be erected, moved, remodeled, extended, enlarged or altered except in conformity with the regulations herein specified for the use district in which it is located. Any building, structure or use lawfully existing at the time of the enactment of this ordinance may be continued as a nonconforming use even though such building, structure or use does not conform with the provisions of this ordinance for the use district in which it is located. Similarly, whenever a use district shall be changed hereafter, uses existing and lawful at the time may be continued. Sec. 51. - Nonconforming uses. 51.1. General provisions: (a) No building, structure or property containing a nonconforming use shall hereafter be extended unless such extension or alteration shall conform to the provisions of the use district in which it is located. (b) Any nonconforming building or structure which has been damaged to the extent of not exceeding fifty (50) per cent of its replacement valuation may be reconstructed and reused as before if done within twelve (12) months from the time such damage occurred. If such damage is greater than fifty (50) per cent of its replacement valuation, such building or structure may only be reconstructed to conform with the provisions of the use district in which it is situated. 51.2. Discontinuance: Wherever a nonconforming use has been discontinued for a period of three (3) months, such use shall not thereafter be reestablished, and any future use shall be in conformity with the provisions of this ordinance. 51.3. Change: No conforming use shall be permitted to revert to a nonconforming use. 51.4. Unsafe buildings: Nothing in this ordinance shall prevent the strengthening or restoring to a safe condition of any part of any building or structure declared unsafe by the building inspector or not in compliance with the City of Winder or State of Georgia's lawful requirements. 51.5. Pending application for building permits: Nothing herein contained shall require any change in the plans, construction, size or designated use of any building, structure or partthereof for which a building permit has been granted prior to the adoption of this ordinance; provided that construction shall start within sixty (60) days after the granting of such permit. 51.6. General height provisions: Except as hereinafter provided or as specified in the Winder Barrow Airport Ordinance, whichever is more stringent, no building or structure shall be erected or enlarged for the zone wherein such building or structure is located. 51.7. General area provisions: Except as hereinafter provided, no building or structure shall be erected on a lot unless such building or structure conforms with the area regulations of the zone in which it is located. (a) Reduction of lot area: No lot shall be reduced in area so that the yards, other open spaces or total lot area shall be smaller than that prescribed by the ordinance, nor shall the density of population be increased in any manner except in conformity with the regulations herein established. (b) Recorded lots less than minimum area: Lots of record at the time of the enactment of this ordinance which have less than the minimum requirements for residential zones may, nevertheless, be used for uses permitted in the respective zone; providing that a variance is granted by the board of appeals. All lots in a residence zone shall be for uses prescribed for the zone in which they are located. (Ord. W-8-95) of 11-7-95, § VI; Ord. ( W-9-17 ) of 5-2-17, §§ I, II; Ord ( W-16-17 ) of 8-8-17) Sec. 52. - Signs. Refer to the Sign Regulations, Article XXIII. 52.1. Quasi-public uses: Quasi-public uses, by tradition and precedent, have been and are presently identified with promoting the general welfare of the city, including athletic events, festivals and similar events. Such signs shall be of a temporary nature. They shall be placed in a manner which will not be hazardous to or impede traffic circulation. A permit from the City of Winder License and Permits Office will be required prior to the erection of such signs. (Ord. ( W-9-17 ) of 5-2-17, § III) Sec. 53. - Parking. 53.1. Parking area design standards: For every parcel of land that, after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives, is constructed, reconstructed, moved or altered, off-street parking in the form of garages or parking areas made available exclusively for parking shall be provided in conformity with this section. Thus, parking spaces shall be located entirely on the same property as the main use, except in the Downtown Overlay District, with no portion of the parking area other than necessary drives extending into any street or other public right-of-way. (1) The issuance of building permits or certificates of occupancy shall require compliance with the minimum parking standards of this section even though a final site development plan may have been approved previously which included fewer parking spaces due to the unknown or changing status of occupancy. (2) No property owner or tenant shall use or allow the use of any parking space or area designed for the parking of vehicles, and necessary to provide parking spaces in satisfaction of the off-street parking requirements of this section, for any purpose which obstructs or prevents the use of such parking space or area for the parking of vehicles on a regular basis. (3) Any accessible parking spaces required by federal or state law shall be provided for in addition to the minimum number of spaces required by this section. 53.2. Such area shall be paved or have equivalent surfacing subject to the approval of the planning commission. 53.3. Where such area adjoins a lot in a residential zone, a solid wall, fence or compact planting screen at least five (5) feet high shall be erected and maintained between such area and the residential district. All parking areas shall be at least five (5) feet from the side of a lot in a residential district, and all required front and side yards shall be properly maintained as such. 53.4. Any light used to illuminate said parking area shall be so arranged as to reflect light away from the residential district. 53.5. All off-street parking facilities shall be designed with the appropriate means of access to street, alley and maneuvering area. No driveway or curb cuts shall exceed forty (40) feet. Detailed plans shall be submitted to the planning commission for approval of all driveway openings or curb cuts before a permit may be obtained. 53.6. Parking requirements by use: Off-street automobile storage or parking shall be provided with vehicular access to a street or alley and shall meet the following minimum requirements for the land use specified:
53.7. Parking lot plantings: Shade trees shall be provided within or adjacent to any parking lot designed or intended to accommodate ten (10) cars or more, in accordance with the requirements of this section. In addition to trees, landscaping is required within parking lots for ten (10) or more cars as provided in this section, below. (a) Landscape areas required: The following applies to any parking lot designed or intended to accommodate ten (10) cars or more. (1) Landscape islands, strips or other planting areas shall be located within the parking lot and shall constitute at least eight (8) per cent of the entire area devoted to parking spaces, aisles and connecting driveways. (2) Parking areas shall be separated from sidewalks by a strip of land at least seven (7) feet wide reserved as open space and planted in grass, (except for sidewalks that cross the planting strip). (3) Landscape islands, strips or other planting areas shall be landscaped with any combination of such plant materials as trees, shrubs, grass or ground cover; trees and shrubs shall be mulched. Such planting areas shall be well drained and contain suitable soil and natural irrigation characteristics for the planting materials they contain. (4) As a minimum, a landscaping island shall be located at the end of every parking bay between the last parking space and an adjacent travel aisle or driveway. The island shall be no less than seven (7) feet wide for at least one-half (½) the length of the adjacent parking space. (5) Landscape islands between side-by-side parking spaces shall be no less than seven (7) feet in width and extend for at least one-half (½) the length of the adjacent parking space. Landscaping strips between head-to-head parking spaces shall be no less than five (5) feet in width and provided with wheel stops in the parking spaces such that no vehicular overhang is permitted. (6) Landscape islands shall require regular maintenance including but not limited to the following; pruning, mulching, weeding and shall remain free of litter, rubbish and other obstructions. (7) Plants that die will be required to be replaced. To assure plant material survivability it is imperative that all generally accepted professional horticultural standards and practices be conducted. All plant material is to be installed to meet or exceed current industry standards. (8) A landscape plan along with a plant list of desired plants shall be submitted to the planning department for approval. In general, all plant material selected shall be tolerant of the local growing conditions. (9) All landscaping and other screening devices along street right-of-ways and driveways, etc. must be designed and installed in a manner consistent with standard traffic engineering site distance requirements. (10) All required landscaping shall be installed prior to occupancy or commencement of use. Where compliance with the preceding sentence is not possible due to the season of the year, or other circumstances beyond the control of the owner or contractor, the city may grant a temporary certificate of occupancy permit until installation is completed, at the time installation is completed a standard certificate of occupancy permit will be issued. (b) Trees required. The following applies to any parking lot designed or intended to accommodate ten (10) cars or more. (1) Shade trees shall be provided within or immediately adjacent to and surrounding the parking lot at a ratio of at least one (1) tree for every twenty (20) parking spaces, or portion thereof. (2) Trees must be placed in or around the parking lot such that every parking space is within fifty (50) feet of a shade tree. The fifty-foot distance is measured from the center of the tree to any point within the parking space. (3) New trees shall have a caliper of no less than two (2) inches DBH upon planting, and shall be maintained in good condition. Trees must be removed as a result of disease, damage or death, and must be replaced. (c) Tree planting areas. Tree planting areas shall be no less than five (5) feet in width and shall provide at least one hundred twenty (120) square feet of use able planting area per tree. No tree shall be located less than two (2) feet from the back of curb. All parking lot landscape islands, strips or other planting areas shall be curbed in accordance with city specifications. (d) Administrative variance. If there are conditions pertaining to a particular piece of property because of its size, shape, or topography where the strict application of the provisions of this subsection would create an unnecessary hardship, and where relief if granted would not cause a substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purpose of this subsection, then the director of planning is authorized to grant a variance to the conditions of this subsection.
