( W-13-17 ) of 6-6-17) Sec. 58. - Home occupations. 58.1. Overview. (a) The standards of this article dealing with home occupations are designed to protect and maintain the residential character of a neighborhood while permitting certain limited commercial activities may be carried out in a home. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on a home occupation at a residence in an area of the city zoned R-1, R-1A, R-1B, R-2, R-3, MH, TNPD, A-1 and A-2, unless the person has applied for and received a license to do so in compliance with this article. Application for a home occupation permit shall be made in writing on forms provided by the city. Applications shall be reviewed and approved by the planning and permit department. (c) It shall be unlawful for the property owner to knowingly allow a person to use the real estate for a home occupation in violation of this article. (d) All local and state licenses/permits as well as any necessary licenses/permits from any other agency required for the home occupation must be obtained prior to the business being opened. (e) A fifty dollar ($50.00) permit application fee for new home occupation permit shall be required and is nonrefundable. The permit would remain in effect until either it is revoked, the holder ceases the business or the holder fails to pay any required occupational tax due the city. 58.2. Definition. "Home occupation" is defined as any business, profession, occupation, trade or activity conducted within a residential building, or an accessory building thereto, which is incidental or secondary to the use of such building for dwelling purposes and which does not change the essential residential character of the building. This definition applies to all zoning districts. 58.3. Evaluation standards. (a) The structure or appearance of the exterior of the dwelling shall not be altered or remodeled for home occupational purposes either by color, materials, construction, lighting, or in any other way. (b) The entrance to the home occupation portion of the dwelling shall be from either within the dwelling or through an existing entrance; not through a new outside entrance. (c) No activities shall be allowed and no equipment or material shall be used that would change the fire safety or occupancy classifications of the premises. (d) Not more than twenty-five (25) percent of the floor area in the residential unit may be used for a home occupation. This is a maximum amount regardless of the number of occupations at any one (1) residence. Additionally, a home occupation may occupy a maximum of two hundred (200) square feet of floor area of any accessory building. (e) Hours of operation. Customer visits shall be limited to the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. (f) Any sign or display shall be limited to only one (1) and shall not exceed four (4) square feet in size. It shall carry only the name and occupation of the occupant of the premises. The sign or display shall be nonlighted and nonreflective in nature and shall be attached to the dwelling or accessory building or located within ten (10) feet thereof. (g) The interior of the residence shall maintain an operational kitchen, bathroom, and sleeping area and shall have active utility accounts, including water and electricity. (h) The home occupation shall not generate pedestrian or vehicular traffic beyond what is normal to the neighborhood where it is located. (i) There shall be no outdoor display or storage of equipment or material used in the home occupation. (j) A home occupation permit/occupational tax certificate for a home occupation is valid for only the original applicant and is not transferable to any resident, address or any other occupation. Upon termination of the applicant's residency, the home occupation permit shall become null and void. (k) If there are any changes proposed in the dwelling or in the plumbing or the electrical system, appropriate permits will be required. 58.4. Restriction on sales. The home occupation shall involve the sale of only those goods or services produced on the premises, except in the case of mail order or home marketing services. 58.5. Mail order or home marketing services. (a) If the home occupation consists of either a mail order business or a home marketing business, the residence will be the mailing address and office only. The business will only take orders at the home and the orders will be filled by direct shipment from factory/warehouse to customer. No inventory beyond samples may be stored on the premises. 58.6. Catering and food sales. A home occupation providing food catering or food sales must meet all of the requirements of the Georgia Department of Agriculture Food Safety Division Chapter 40-7-19 Cottage Food Regulations. 58.7. Beauty shops and barber shops. (a) Beauty shops and barber shops are allowed provided customer visits are by appointment only. The business shall consist of no more than one (1) beauty/barber chair and no more than two (2) customers shall be permitted at one (1) time. Beauty shops and barber shops allowed under these provisions shall be registered with the appropriate licensing and inspection authorities. (b) All local and state licenses as well as any necessary permits from the Barrow County Health Department must be obtained prior to the business being opened. 58.8. In-home childcare. (a) In-home childcare is limited to six (6) children at a time, including the caregiver's own preschool-aged children. (b) No other home occupation permit/occupational tax certificate can be combined with an in-home childcare home occupation permit. (c) Home childcare providers and their employees must also pass a fingerprint check and a preliminary records check to make sure that there is no history of criminal behavior. A background check conducted by the state within sixty (60) days will satisfy this requirement. (d) All local and state licenses as well as any necessary permits from the Barrow County Health Department must be obtained prior to the business being opened. 58.9. Impact-related standards. (a) Noise. The maximum noise level for a home occupation is fifty (50) dBA. Noise level measurements are taken at the property line. Home occupations that propose to use power tools or music must document in advance that the home occupation will meet the fifty (50) dBA standard. (b) Deliveries. Truck deliveries or pick-ups of supplies or products, associated with the home occupation, are allowed at the home only between 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. (c) Vehicles. No more than one (1) marked vehicle may be used in association with the home occupation. No heavy equipment, semi-tractors, dump trucks, or track vehicles shall be permitted to park on the premises. (d) Parking. No on-street parking of business-related vehicles or customers shall be permitted at any time. The home occupation shall have necessary parking needed for both residents and customers without using public roads. (e) Prohibited equipment and materials. There shall be no chemical, mechanical or electrical equipment on the premises other than that normally found in a purely domestic residence. Chemical shall also include any chemicals which are not normally found in a purely domestic residence. (f) Nuisance. There shall be no emission of smoke, dust, odor, fumes, glare, vibration, electrical or electronic disturbance detectable at the property line or beyond. (g) Employee. The occupation shall be conducted by members of the family who are actively living in the primary residence and a maximum of one (1) additional employee. 58.10. Occupations which are not allowed. (a) Motor vehicle and accessory/parts sales, rental, repair and/or painting. (b) Vehicle detailing, cleaning or vehicle glass repairs. (c) Combustion engine repairs or cleaning. (d) Equipment rentals. (e) The assembly, repair, or reconstruction of major household appliances, including refrigerators, freezers, clothes washers, clothes dryers, dishwashers, stoves, heating equipment, and air conditioning equipment. (f) Consignment sales where items are stored on the property. (g) Medical doctors or any practice of physical and/or medical application, including chiropractors and massage therapists or any other uses which involve medical procedures. (h) Dentists. (i) Funeral home. (j) Uses that require the handling of any hazardous, biologically, or toxic materials. (k) No home occupation shall include the manufacture, repair, sale or storage of firearms, ammunition or other items which are regulated by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, at the site of the home occupation. (l) Dismantling, junk, scrap, or recycling materials. (m) Outdoor recreational or sporting clinics or activities. (n) Commercial greenhouses or nurseries. (o) Commercial cabinet or furniture making, furniture refinishing/antique restoration and sales are not permitted. (p) Restaurant. (q) Occupation involving explosive materials. (r) Breeding of animals or selling of animals other than domestic animals typically weighing less than one hundred fifty (150) pounds at maturity. Breeding and selling of domestic animals are not permitted in R-1B, R-2, R-3, MH and TNPD zonings. (s) Animal hospitals, veterinary clinics; pet care services such as grooming, animal day cares or kennels of any size. (t) Garage sales/yard sales are not allowed as a home occupation provided however that garage sales are allowed if they meet the requirements of chapter 13, article IX and are permitted as required by said ordinance. 58.11. Consent to inspection. (a) The signature of the applicant upon the application shall grant the consent by the applicant to an inspection of the home occupation premises by the City of Winder. (b) The dwelling in which the home occupation is being conducted shall be open for inspection to city personnel during reasonable hours. (c) Failure by the applicant to allow for the inspection of the premises by the code enforcement officer or position(s) designated by the city administrator shall be grounds for refusal to grant the permit or to revoke any current permit. 58.12. Revocation of a home occupation permit/occupational tax certificate. The city administrator or designee has the authority to revoke a home occupation permit/occupational tax certificate, or modify or amend the conditions of a home occupation permit/occupational tax certificate, upon determining that the use as operated or maintained creates one (1) or more of the following conditions: (a) A nuisance or other undesirable condition interfering with the public health, safety, or general welfare. (b) A violation of the provisions of this article or any other applicable law or ordinance, or a violation of the conditions imposed upon the home occupation permit. (c) Failure to allow the city to inspect the property during hours of operation. (d) Before revoking a home occupation permit, the city shall give a ten (10) day written notice to the permit holder addressed or delivered to the premises. The permit holder may appeal the revocation to the city council by filing a written notice of appeal with the city clerk within said ten-day period. The revocation shall be stayed pending the council's decision on the appeal. (Ord. (W-3-13) of 1-8-13; Ord. ( W-18-17 ) of 9-14-17) Sec. 59. - Garages required. (a) Each detached single family residential dwelling unit shall have a garage, enclosed on four sides with a garage door of at least sixteen feet in width or two garage doors of at least eight feet in width each and a minimum area of at least 500 square feet. For each two-family residential dwelling (duplex) a garage is required for each dwelling unit, each garage shall be a minimum of 260 square feet in area with inside dimensions of at least twenty feet in length and thirteen feet in width, enclosed on four sides and with a garage door of at least eight feet in width. Any condominium, townhome or similar residential dwelling shall have a garage for each dwelling unit and each garage shall be a minimum of 260 square feet in area with inside dimensions of at least twenty feet in length and thirteen feet in width, enclosed on four sides with a garage door of at least eight feet in width. (b) Notwithstanding subsection (a), no garage shall be required for a single family residential dwelling in the A-2 Agricultural Zone. (c) Any new single family residential dwelling within the Winder Historic District may request an exemption from the required two car garage requirement of Sec. 59 (a). The new single family residential dwelling must meet the architectural characteristics of the Historic District and a Certificate of Appropriateness must be issued for the new residential home by the Winder Historic Preservation Commission before an exemption is requested. An exemption request must be filed with the Winder Zoning Board of Appeals for their consideration and decision in the same manner as variance applications. (Ord. A minimum of ten (10) acres shall be required with a two hundred (200) foot setback requirement from all property lines. (m) Petroleum or chemical refining. A minimum of ten (10) acres shall be required with a three hundred (300) foot setback requirement from all property lines. (n) Solid waste transfer station/materials recovery facilities or landfill. A minimum of ten (10) acres shall be required with a three hundred (300) foot setback requirement from all property lines. (o) Mining and quarrying. A minimum of ten (10) acres shall be required with a three hundred (300) foot setback requirement from all property lines. (Ord. ( W-8-17 ) of 5-2-17) Sec. 155. - Outdoor storage for conditional uses. (a) Outdoor storage in an industrial zone shall be completely enclosed by solid walls, fences or opaque landscaping or a combination thereof, not less than six (6) feet in height when visible from a public street. (b) No merchandise or materials shall be stored or displayed higher than the screening. This shall not pertain to communication towers or oversized functioning vehicles/vessels (i.e., bus, boat, tractor, etc.) when screening is at a height of eight (8) feet. (Ord. ( W-8-17 ) of 5-2-17) Sec. 156. - Prohibited uses. (a) Animal stock yard, livestock grazing or sales. (b) Cemeteries. (c) Residential. (d) Retirement homes, convalescent homes, personal care homes (personal services provided), community living arrangements, assisted living homes, intermediate care homes, hospice homes, nursing homes, senior daycare homes and children daycare homes. The city adopts the State of Georgia definitions, as amended from time to time, for the previously listed types of facilities. (Ord. ( W-8-17 ) of 5-2-17) Sec. 157. - Development standards. Table I Industrial Zone Development Standards
In the case of a corner lot which abuts any two (2) intersecting streets, the minimum side yard setback for the side of the building or structure facing a street shall be the same as a front yard setback. Setbacks are measured from the edge of the right-of-way, or if no right-of-way exists, the setback shall be measured from the actual property line. (Ord. ( W-8-17 ) of 5-2-17) Sec. 158. - Off-street parking and loading facilities. (a) Off-street parking and loading facilities are required for all uses in an industrial zone. (b) See article V section 53. (Ord. ( W-8-17 ) of 5-2-17) Sec. 159. - Dumpster screening and pad. (a) All dumpsters within fifty (50) feet of a property line shall be enclosed with a wall on three (3) sides by a masonry wall enclosure that is a minimum of eight (8) feet in height, accessed by an opaque gate. (b) Dumpsters shall be placed on concrete pads of sufficient size and strength to support the weight of service vehicles. The minimum thickness of the concrete pad shall be six (6) inches. (Ord. ( W-8-17 ) of 5-2-17) ARTICLE XVI. - A-1 AGRICULTURAL ZONE
Sec. 160. - Generally. The A-1 agricultural zone is composed chiefly of farm area where some development has been occurring. The regulations for the district are designed to encourage a compatible relationship between agriculture and limited development. Sec. 161. - Permitted uses. (a) Single-unit residences in compliance with the R-1 single-unit residential zone regulations, excluding subdivisions, mobile home parks and manufactured housing. All dwelling units must be constructed on site. (b) Public utility stations, public buildings, public structures; provided that the area is adequately screened from surrounding properties. (c) Truck gardening, forestry and buildings incidental thereto. (d) Home occupations which would be otherwise allowed in the R-1 zone. (e) Advertising signs which would be otherwise allowed in the R-1 zone. (f) Accessory and temporary buildings which would be otherwise allowed in the R-1 zone. (g) The noncommercial grazing of cows and horses subject to the following restrictions: 1. The total number of such animals, other than their young under the age of six (6) months, that shall be allowed on a lot shall be limited to the square footage of the lot divided by the total minimum areas required per animal, in the case of cows and horses, 43,560 square feet (1 acre) per animal. 2. Any such animal shall be placed to the rear of all adjacent and adjoining residences and shall be either penned or tied not closer than seventy-five (75) feet to a side property line or shall be confined to the lot by the means of a suitable fence. No structure accessory, such use that contains livestock, manure or other odor-producing or dust-producing substance or use, shall be located within two hundred (200) feet of a property line. (h) The keeping of domestic fowl provided it is conducted on a tract of land not less than five (5) acres in area. "Domestic fowl" shall include only female chickens, chicks and ducks. The keeping of domestic fowl is subject to the following restrictions: (1) Every person owning or keeping domestic fowl is required to keep such fowl under fence and shall not allow such fowl to run on any property other than his own. (2) All places wherein domestic fowl are kept shall have adequate drainage sufficient to prevent standing water in yards or pens and prevent waste products from entering into storm drains, rivers or streams or city sewer lines. (3) No structure housing domestic fowl shall be located within 200 feet of a property line. Domestic fowl enclosures and coops and related structures and areas must be maintained in a manner that will not disturb the use and enjoyment of neighboring lots due to noise, odor or other adverse impact. (4) No slaughtering of domestic fowl is allowed. (Ord. (W-5-11) of 6-7-11) ARTICLE XVII. - A-2 AGRICULTURAL ZONE
Sec. 170. - Generally. The A-2 Agricultural zone is composed chiefly of the open farm areas where a more intensive use of land is unlikely to occur in the near future. The regulations for the zone are designed to encourage the maintenance of a rural character and the right to farm. Sec. 171. - Permitted uses. 171.1. Dwellings, one-family, excluding subdivision and mobile home parks and dwellings built or suited exclusively for rental. 171.2. There shall not be more than one (1) tenant dwelling per five (5) acres of land. All tenant dwellings shall meet the yard and area requirements of the district in which it is located and the building code. 171.3. Public utility stations, buildings and structures; provided that the area is adequately screened (shall be a wall, fence or tight evergreen hedge not less than six (6) feet in height), and provided that no office or equipment is located or stored on-site. All types of lighting must be directed to reflect away from dwellings and public rights-of-way. 171.4. Crop or row farming. 171.5. Truck gardening or farming. 171.6. Feedlots, kennels, pork, beef and poultry production; provided that the operation is conducted on a tract of land not less than ten (10) acres; and no poultry house, feedlot or structure containing livestock, manure or other odor- or dust-producing substance shall be located within two hundred (200) feet of a property line for any new operation. In turn, no living structure may be erected within two hundred (200) feet of a confinement-feeding operation. 171.7. Home occupation applicants must be the owner of the property or have written approval if they are a tenant. It must be operated by members of the family residing, and the article or service shall only be sold or offered for sale except as may be produced by members. 171.8. Signs shall be subject to the requirements of the Sign Regulations, Article XXIII. 171.9. Accessory and temporary buildings must meet the following requirements: Where an accessory building is attached to the main building, a substantial part of one (1) wall of the accessory building may be part of or attached on the main building. Detached accessory buildings shall not be closer than five (5) feet to the lot line. Accessory buildings will not be located in the front yard and will not have more than two (2) stories which take up more than thirty (30) per cent of the rear yard. 171.10. All uses allowed in the A-1 Zone but subject to the area and distance requirements of the A-2 Zone. (Ord. (W-5-11) of 6-7-11) ARTICLE XVIII. - E EXHIBITION ZONE
Sec. 180. - Permitted uses. (a) All uses allowed in the A-2 zone except single-unit residences described in section 171.1. (b) Recreation facilities. (c) Fairs, carnivals, temporary livestock exhibits. (d) Civic club meetings, activities, charitable uses, temporary camping for charitable groups. (e) Voting locations or other public uses as allowed from time to time by the council. (f) Other compatible uses as allowed from time to time by the council. ARTICLE XVIII.I. - TNPD—TRADITIONAL NEIGHBORHOOD PLANNED DEVELOPMENT ZONE
Sec. 180.1. - Scope of article. 1.1 General: The provisions of this section shall govern all developments in the TNPD zone. All proposed TNPD zones have to be reviewed by the planning board and approved by the city council. (Ord. No. W-03-03, 2-4-05) Sec. 180.2. - Purpose. The purpose and intent of a TNPD zone is to allow, coordinate and regulate comprehensive developments which may not follow standard design practices otherwise allowed by the city's zoning regulations. (Ord. No. W-03-03, 2-4-05) Sec. 180.3. - Procedures and regulations. Traditional Neighborhood Planned Developments (TNPD) will sometimes involve mixed uses, varying densities, grouping of housing and/or open spaces and may have densities and setbacks that are non-conventional in developments of the type being sought by the developer of a TNPD. Each applicant seeking a TNPD approval must indicate the applicant's understanding and willingness to adhere to the various procedures and regulations applicable to TNPD developments. Also, the applicant must be aware that to enable thorough analysis of a TNPD, more information is required about the proposal than would normally be needed if the development was to be pursued under conventional zoning requirements. Prior to submittal, it is required that a pre-submittal conference be conducted with the developer or his authorized representative and the appropriate City of Winder staff. In some instances, more than one (1) pre-submittal conference maybe required. The City of Winder staff reserves the right to take up to three (3) weeks to review information presented at the pre-submittal conference(s). (Ord. No. W-03-03, 2-4-05) Sec. 180.4. - Conditions of rezoning. Property will be considered for rezoning to a TNPD zone only in accordance with the following conditions, procedures and regulations. a) Ownership; sale or transfer: None of the land may be sold or otherwise transferred by lease, deed, encumbrance or otherwise until the applicant has recorded the final plat with the Barrow County Clerk of Courts office in the form approved by the City of Winder and that the overall tract of land described therein is a portion of a Traditional Neighborhood Planned Development (TNPD) that will result in substantial perpetual restrictions on the future use of the property encompassed therein including; (a) designating portions thereof as open areas for no other use other than as open areas and (b) prohibiting the redevelopment of any area of the TNPD at a density greater than that assigned to the area of the TNPD at the time of final approval of the development plan (including density) for that area; provided however, the foregoing provisions shall not prohibit the same owner of more than one (1) area of a TNPD from reassigning density rights between two (2) or more areas of a TNPD as long as such reassignment is reviewed by the planning board and approved by the city council and does not increase the overall density of the TNPD and is otherwise consistent with the overall development plan. b) Conditions for preliminary approval: In considering the preliminary approval for the rezoning of property to a TNPD zone, the planning board shall consider the following and give a preliminary recommendation only upon satisfaction of the following conditions: 1) The proposal will utilize design and development standards which would not be permitted in any other zoning district or which would combine various types of uses of housing into a single district. 2) The proposal would not substantially alter or adversely affect nearby property values. 3) The proposal would not be incompatible with existing land uses within the area. 4) The proposal would not be inconsistent with the goals and policies of the City of Winder's Comprehensive Land Use Plan or with the purposes sought by this chapter. 5) The site plan for the proposal provides for adequate ingress and egress for vehicular traffic and will not create safety, health or unreasonable traffic problems in the area. 6) The proposal makes adequate provisions for community facilities such as water, sewer, recreation and open areas. Seventy (70) per cent of the proposed recreation and open areas within the proposed TNPD land area must be outside of all flood hazard areas as defined by the appropriate flood insurance rate map for the City of Winder. Open areas must be free from impervious surfaces. Landscape areas: Within a TNPD the minimum per centage of landscaped/open space required for each portion of the development is as follows: i. Single-family residential—20% ii. Multifamily residential—20% iii. Professional area—15% iv. Commercial area—5% Common open space areas shall be arranged so as to maximize access and utilization by residents of the TNPD. All landscape plans shall be approved by the City of Winder. 7) The proposal is justified based on facts presented to indicate the need for such a development within the City of Winder. 8) The proposal cannot have commercial areas in excess often ten (10) per cent of the proposed TNPD's land area. The city council reserves the right to increase the maximum allowed per centage of commercial areas associated with infill projects located in the downtown area. 9) Parking: Residential areas shall have two (2) spaces per single-family dwelling. Multifamily shall have one and one-half (1.5) spaces for units greater than one thousand square feet (1,000 square feet) of living space, units having less than one thousand square feet (1,000 square feet) of living space shall be required to have one (1) space per unit. Parking areas shall be to the side or rear of the buildings they serve. On-lot parking only will be allowed, no on-street parking will be allowed. Other parking requirements necessary will be required to meet or exceed current City of Winder ordinances. 10) The developer shows the proposed schedule of phases of development. 11) The developer presents the proposed utility corridor(s), for all phases of the TNPD development, and the City of Winder has to agree with and approve all utility corridors. 12) Private streets may be allowed provided the specifications for such streets are reviewed and approved by the City of Winder. 13) Proper design: It is encouraged that the layout of the TNPD development, as a whole, utilize the natural topography of the site, take advantage of existing trees and any historical features on the property. The design of the TNPD must provide for an orderly and creative arrangement of land uses that are harmonious and beneficial to the City of Winder. 14) The developer provides detailed drawings showing what is proposed to buffer the development site from adjacent properties. 15) The developer presents guidelines for the physical development of the property including illustrations of proposed architectural, landscape, open space, signage and other hardscape concepts. c) Minimum size: The minimum area that will qualify for a TNPD zone will be ten (10) acres; provided, however, smaller tracts of land contiguous to an existing TNPD zone may be rezoned TNPD if same are an expansion of the existing adjacent TNPD or used fot infill adjacent to or within the First Fire District as defined in section 5-22 of the City of Winder Code of Ordinances. d) Permitted uses: The TNPD zone is planned to be primarily a single-family residential zone with small per centages of the total land areas contained within a TNPD being available for use for multifamily residential, professional and commercial. In order to ensure that limited uses and overall densities for a TNPD are not violated, the following express limitations must be satisfied in each phase of the TNPD approval and development process: 1) The maximum area of a TNPD to be developed or allotted for development as multifamily residential, single-family residential, professional or commercial cannot exceed the following per centages of the entire property. 2) The maximum area of a TNPD to be developed or allotted for development as multifamily cannot exceed five (5) per cent of the total TNPD. The density of the multifamily shall not exceed eight (8) units per acre, however, the maximum density per acre within the multifamily portion of the TNPD may be increased up to fifteen (15) units per acre if the multifamily area has designated open areas adjacent to same at least twenty-five (25) per cent as large as the multifamily area. No multifamily development within a TNPD may be contiguous to any property outside of the TNPD that is in a R-1, R-1A or R-1B zone. 3) Any use permitted in the R-1 single-family residential zone, see article VI, (but subject to the same conditions as the aforesaid section, except lot size, building size and setbacks) shall be permitted anywhere in the TNPD except those areas previously set aside as open areas. 4) Open areas shall be disbursed throughout the TNPD developments so the open areas are readily available to the various developments within the TNPD. Open areas may be in the form of open fields or wooded areas, ballparks, golf courses, recreational fields and other recreational uses permitted by the planning board and city council. All common open space shall be preserved for the purpose as shown on the developments master plan. The developer shall choose one (1) or a combination of the following three (3) methods of administering the common open spaces. i) Dedication of the common open space to the City of Winder, which is subject to formal acceptance and available revenue sources to maintain the space. ii) Establishment of an association or non-profit corporation of all property owners or corporations within the project area to ensure perpetual maintenance of all common open space. iii) Retention of ownership, control and maintenance of all common open spaces by the developer. All privately owned common open space shall continue as such and shall only be used in accordance with the developments master plan. Appropriate land use restrictions shall be contained in all deeds to insure that the common open space is permanently preserved according to the developments master plan. Said deed restrictions shall run with the land and be for the benefit of present as well as future property owners, and shall contain a prohibition against partition of common open space. 5) Except as hereinafter provided, height limitations, minimum lot area, setbacks (front, side and rear yard) and minimum building size shall be established by the City of Winder staff and are to be approved in conjunction with the final approval for each area of development within the TNPD. All buildings constructed within a TNPD shall have a minimum fifty-foot setback from all exterior boundary lines except where like uses are present. e) Density: Unless increased by approval of the mayor and city council as part of the general approval of special criteria, the gross density for a TNPD shall not exceed five (5) residential units per net acre contained within the TNPD. Net acreage means the gross area within the TNPD's exterior boundaries inclusive of streets, roads and other right-of-ways, but less the maximum area planned for either professional or commercial developments and less portions of the areas designated as open areas that exceed the permitted limitations on building areas and impervious surface areas (such as parking lots) contained in subsection 1.4, d) 4) above. f) Application of other city ordinances: Unless specifically waived by the mayor and city council as a part of its general approval of special criteria for the TNPD, each development within the TNPD shall comply with all other city ordinances and regulations contained within the City of Winder's Code of Ordinances, including, but not limited to, parking requirements, utilities specifications, wetlands, floodplains, soil erosion, issuance of permits, inspections, the Georgia State Energy Code, all standard building and other codes, electric codes, fire codes, fire walls and petitions, development reviews, and other code provisions or regulations that are normally applicable to the development of property within the City of Winder. g) Since the primary intended use of land areas within a TNPD is single-family residential, any area of a TNPD may be platted and subdivided in accordance with the city's subdivision regulations as though they were in the R-1 use district unless such subdivision would result in exceeding the overall density requirements of the TNPD. The preliminary plan submittal: TNPD development plan submittals must at a minimum include the following items: (1) A complete application form and the application fee must be received by the City of Winder. Clearly state the purpose of the application. (e.g. size/area of the project site, size/number of proposed buildings, number of proposed dwelling units, unique characteristics of the proposal, etc.) In addition, the property owner must sign the application form or provide a written letter of authorization. (2) A written narrative which introduces the project and describes in detail any elements of the project which are not readily apparent in the exhibits. (3) A site plan showing locations of all streets, as well as widths of all streets, parking, buildings, and other structures and, where applicable, any bicycle paths and trails, lot lines, property boundary lines, project phasing lines, dimensions, setbacks (front, back and side yards), easements, right-of-ways, north arrow, scale, widths of medians and median openings, project designer, developer's name and the twenty-four-hour contact person and their phone number. (4) Typical/conceptual architectural elevations showing all four (4) sides of any structure(s) proposed in the plan. The elevations should be of sufficient detail to show building heights, materials, colors, textures, and general design characteristics and any conceptual sign plans showing sign types and locations. The intent of the developer's conceptual look for the development must be made clear to the City of Winder. Final building elevations shall be approved by the City of Winder staff for conformance with the aforementioned typical/conceptual architectural elevations. (5) For residential projects, floor plans showing all model types must be submitted, floor plans may also be required for commercial projects. Custom designed residential homes shall be allowed, the City of Winder staff will review all proposed plans for homes to be custom built for conformance with the overall concept of the TNPD project. (6) A table listing land coverages by per centage and acreage for the following: landscaped areas and natural open space, building coverage, parking, streets and sidewalks and recreation facilities. (7) A topographical map showing existing contours and proposed lot lines (may be integrated with the site plan described above); this map must normally be at a scale no smaller than one (1) inch equals one hundred (100) feet with contour lines at an interval no greater than two (2) feet. A plan with a map scale of one (1) inch equals two hundred (200) feet may be submitted with approval from the director of planning. Some areas of the TNPD development may be required to be shown in further detail at a much larger scale. (e.g. one (1) inch equals twenty (20) feet) (8) Residential developments must include a density calculation and per centages of areas within the development based on use. This includes all types of proposed residential. (9) Professional and commercial developments must include a specification of the permitted and conditional uses desired in these areas. (10) For certain developments, a traffic analysis prepared by a certified traffic engineer may be required. This potential requirement should be discussed in the pre-submittal conference. (see section 1.3 Procedures and Regulations) (11) Location and/or source of water and sewer facilities. Septic tanks and individual water wells are prohibited in a TNPD development. (12) Flood Zone demarcation lines, indicate FIRM Map and panel number. Note that areas included within the flood hazard limits can be used as thirty (30) per cent of the total required open space of the entire TNPD development. (13) Existing wetland areas must be shown on the site plan. Note that wetland and floodplain areas can only be used as thirty (30) per cent of the total required open space of the entire TNPD development. If no wetlands exist on the site, the applicant/developer shall have a licensed professional from the State of Georgia sign the following note and said note is to be shown on the construction documents: Wetlands disclaimer statement: After thorough investigation of the site, no wetland areas were found to be within the boundaries of the TNPD development. Licensed Professional's Signature Date (14) Showall rivers, streams, creeks and other water features on the site plan and their required buffers. (15) Restrictive covenants including the assurance of maintenance of common areas and the continued protection of the TNPD. (16) Legal description of the entire property. (17) Show environmentally sensitive areas, historical structures or sites, archeological sites and graveyards included within the boundaries of the property or any that might be outside of the project boundaries that potentially could be affected by the proposed development. (18) List of all adjacent property owners. These owners must be shown in their appropriate locations on the site plan with their existing zoning district. (19) Property taxes: Proof must be provided by the applicant that there are no delinquent taxes constituting a lien on the whole or on any part of the property. (20) The applicant shall specify if any existing structures are to be removed or demolished within the boundaries of the site. (21) If over one hundred (100) residential units/structures are to be included within the boundaries of the TNPD, at least two (2) entrances will be required. In extremely large developments more than two (2) entrances may be required. (22) The development is designed in a way to be pedestrian oriented with sidewalks, minimum five (5) feet in width, on both sides of the streets with a fully connected pedestrian network throughout. Automobile traffic and parking shall be accommodated in ways that respect pedestrian passages and the form of public space. (23) Street trees shall be required along all thoroughfares. At a minimum, trees are to be located at thirty (30) feet intervals along both sides of the streets. The City of Winder will approve all landscape plans. The approval process: The process to secure the approvals and zoning for development of property as a Traditional Neighborhood Planned Development (TNPD) will involve the following steps. Step #1: As stated in section 1.3, at the least one pre-submittal conference will be required. The pre-submittal conference is between the developer and the appropriate City of Winder staff, this preliminary meeting is held to try and develop a more completed plan before it is submitted to the planning board. At the pre-submittal conference, the concept of the proposed TNPD will be discussed in detail. Preliminary plans and other pertinent documents can be submitted to the city for preliminary review and comment at this time. The City of Winder reserves the right to take up to three (3) weeks to review information presented at the pre-submittal conference(s). Step #2: Once the City of Winder staffis satisfied that the applicant's proposed TNPD project meets or exceeds all applicable articles and chapters of the city's Code of Ordinances and is ready for submission to the planning board, the director of planning will submit the application and plans to the planning board for consideration. The information required for submittal to the planning board is to include, but not limited to the following: (a) The density, lot size and setback requirements that apply to each phase of the development, including in particular, any special situations or criteria. Each phase of the development must also list the maximum number of residences to be constructed. (b) The maximum area to be developed as multifamily residential, the maximum area to be developed as residential, professional or commercial. (c) The exact acreage contained in the applicant's requested TNPD development as shown on a plat survey by a licensed surveyor or engineer. (d) The minimum area of open space to be dedicated. (e) If the development contemplated by the application has a proposed density greater than the maximum overall density per acre within the TNPD, the applicant shall have designated and dedicated sufficient open areas so as to ensure that the overall approved density within the TNPD will not be exceeded if developed to its full potential. Open areas to be "dedicated" shall mean the official designation in the deed records of Barrow County, Georgia of a land area by plat dedication with metes and bounds of an area described as an open area in a TNPD under the City of Winder TNPD regulations in a form acceptable to the City of Winder attorney. (f) The developer shall submit the final restrictive covenants and/or easements for the area encompassed by the plan under consideration as an integral part of the application. The covenants must require language that allows the City of Winder to enforce said covenants at the discretion of the city. (g) Signs: Unless other sign regulations are approved or deemed required by the City of Winder as apart of the general approval of special criteria, the city's sign regulations shall apply to the specified areas of the TNPD. (h) Refer to the preliminary plan submittal section for landscape requirements. (i) All utility corridors are to be approved by the City of Winder. (j) Maintenance bond requirements, see section 28-40 of the City of Winder Code of Ordinances. (k) TNPD projects must adhere to all City of Winder subdivision and development regulations unless specifically allowed otherwise. Since approval of a TNPD constitutes a rezoning of a property, a public hearing shall be conducted in accordance with Article 22 (Zoning Changes and Ordinance Amendments) of the City of Winder Code of Ordinances. The public hearing is held to review and consider the application, the applicant's preliminary site plan, and a draft of the regulations concerning the applicant's proposed TNPD. If the Planning Board determines that the application is complete and consistent with the City of Winder's future land use goals and provisions of Article 28 (Subdivisions) of the City of Winder Code of Ordinances it shall pass along the application and plans to the city council for final approval. In the case of denial of the application by the planning board, the applicant shall be entitled to gather further information or change his proposed concept to better suit the requirements of the planning board and come back before the planning board for consideration again. Step #3: Final approval shall arise only after the developer has submitted all the required information pertaining to the proposed TNPD project to the planning board and the planning board has reviewed all proposed plans, densities, setbacks and covenants, etc., then the planning board will make a recommendation for consideration by the city council. After receiving a recommendation from the planning board, the mayor and city council shall either reject the application, and stating the reasons, or remand the application to the planning board for further consideration and recommendations thereon in light of the comments being developed at the public hearing, or grant approval. The mayor and city council can either approve or reject the application in whole or in part and specify the reasons. Granting approval shall have the legal effect of changing the property from the then existing zoning district to the TNPD district. The mayor and city council may require additional public hearings as deemed necessary. The City of Winder shall maintain such information as necessary to ensure that each portion of the TNPD development complies with the provisions of this section. Such information shall include a detailed listing of total areas within the TNPD, the maximum amount of multifamily residential development, the maximum amount of residential, professional or commercial development, the maximum number of residential units permitted within the TNPD, the maximum number of residential units per acre to be constructed in areas of the TNPD, other than multifamily, the number of acres to be dedicated to open space and a running total of final approvals given and areas thereby committed to specified densities and uses. Modifications: After securing the appropriate final approval by the mayor and city council for a development within a TNPD, all developments on that portion must be done according to the plans approved and no adjustments or alterations shall be made without prior approval of each reviewing body that was required to give such approval. If major changes are proposed, a new public hearing shall be required before approval of the final plat. (Ord. (W-03-03) of 2-4-05) Sec. 180.5. - Limitations of new application. In the event where an application allowed or provided for by the provisions of this chapter is finally denied after exhaustion of all local appeals, and unless the denial is specifically stated to be without prejudice, it shall not be eligible for re-submittal for the period of six (6) months from the date of final denial unless, in the opinion of the City of Winder, new evidence is submitted or conditions have changed to an extent that further consideration is warranted. (Ord. (W-03-03) of 2-4-05) ARTICLE XVIII.II. - DOWNTOWN OVERLAY DISTRICT
Sec. 181. - Downtown overlay district boundaries. This article applies to land within the city limits of Winder generally bounded on the southwest and south by the CSX railroad right-of-way, on the southeast and east by Park Avenue (extended) on the northeast and north by E. Candler Street, N. Jackson Street and E. Midland Avenue and on the west by Woodlawn Avenue, and more particularly described as exhibit A attached to Ord. W-8-12 and hereby made an exhibit to the "Official City of Winder Zoning Map" as adopted and amended by section 41 of article IV of this appendix. (Ord. (W-8-12) of 7-10-12; Ord. ( W-12-17 ) of 6-6-17) Sec. 181.1. - Effect of downtown overlay district provisions. This downtown overlay district is supplemental to the underlying zoning district classifications established in this Code governing all properties and approvals within the downtown overlay district. The provisions of this article shall be overlaid upon and shall be imposed in addition to said underlying zoning regulations and other city ordinances. In any case where the standards and requirements of the downtown overlay district conflict with those of the base-zoning district or with other provisions of this Code, the standards and requirements of the most restrictive shall apply except as to permitted uses set forth in section 181.2. (Ord. (W-8-12) of 7-10-12; Ord. ( W-12-17 ) of 6-6-17) Sec. 181.2. - Permitted uses. The following uses are permitted uses in the downtown overlay district: (a) All uses allowed by the base-zoning district of the parcel. (b) On any parcel where the base-zoning is B-1 or B-2, the following uses may be allowed as a conditional use granted under section 131.4 or 141.4 of this appendix: (a) Bar, pubs, taverns, brew pubs, or public entertainment; (b) Hotel or bed and breakfast; (c) Massage establishment as defined in section 13-145; (d) Residential uses; (e) Tobacco retailer as defined in section 13-2; (f) Tattoo artist and/or body piercing establishments as defined in section 13-2. Setbacks are measured from the edge of the right-of-way, or if no right-of-way exists the setback shall be measured from the actual property line. Setbacks may be reduced or eliminated by application to the historic preservation commission taking into account the historic character or appearance of the parcel and surrounding parcels. (Ord. Sec. 190. - Height. 190.1. R residence zones: A structure in an R residence zone may be increased in height; providing that the required side yards are increased by one (1) foot for each additional three (3) feet in height, and the structure meets the standards set forth by the Winder-Barrow Airport Zoning Ordinance. 190.2. Structures permitted above height limit: The following structures may extend above the established zone height regulations, providing that they shall not be used primarily for dwelling purposes and meet the standards set by the Winder-Barrow Airport Ordinance: (1) Chimneys or smokestacks. (2) Cooling towers. (3) Elevator penthouses. (4) Fire or parapet walls. (5) Flagpoles. (6) Gas containers. (7) Radio or television towers. (8) Roof signs. (9) Skylights. (10) Stairways. (11) Steeples or spires. (12) Water tanks or standpipes. (13) Similar structures. Sec. 191. - Yards. 191.1. Side yard waived: For the purpose of side yard regulations, semidetached dwellings and row dwellings with common party walls shall be considered as one (1) building occupying one (1) lot. 191.2. Projection into yards: (a) Cornices, sills, eaves, belt courses, chimneys or other similar architectural features may extend or project into a required rear yard upon approval by the building inspector or his designee. (b) Unroofed platforms, landings, steps or balconies may extend or project into a required rear yard upon approval by the building inspector or his designee. (Ord. ( W-9-17 ) of 5-2-17, § V) Sec. 192. - Fence, wall or landscape feature. A fence, screen, solid wall or shrubbery not exceeding six (6) feet in height between the building setback line and the lot line may be located in any required front, side or rear yard. For corner lots, the height shall be decreased to allow for visibility in accordance with municipal ordinances. Sec. 193. - Buffers between incompatible land uses. An undisturbed buffer, fence, solid wall or vegetative screen, or a combination of the aforementioned, will be required for separation of incompatible types of land uses. After a determination of a proposed land use is made, the City of Winder Planning Department will conduct a review of the surrounding and adjacent land uses. The City of Winder Planning Department will then make a determination on the type of required buffer and a plan will have to be submitted to the planning department for review and approval. If a property's land use changes in the future and it is deemed to adversely affect the adjacent properties, a buffer will be required in accordance with the above. (Ord. (W-28-06) of 10-3-06) ARTICLE XX. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 200. - Enforcing officer. The provisions of this ordinance shall be administered and enforced by the building inspector or his designee. His duties shall include: (a) Applications for building permits and certificates of occupancy; (b) Issuing building permits and certificates of occupancy; (c) Inspecting premises for compliance with the terms of this ordinance; and (d) Notifying the owner of any violation. (Ord. ( W-9-17 ) of 5-2-17, § VI) Sec. 201. - Building permits and certificates of occupancy. 201.1. Building permit required: It shall be unlawful to commence the excavation or filling of any lot for any construction of any building or commence the moving or alteration of any building until the building inspector or his designee has issued a building permit for such work. In applying to the City of Winder for a building permit, the applicant shall file plans as specified below. 201.2. Filing plans, issuing permits, construction thereunder: All applications for building permits shall be accompanied by plans in duplicate, drawn to a scale of not less than one-eighth ( 1/8 ) of an inch equal to one (1) foot, showing the actual shape and dimensions of the lot to be built upon, the exact size and location on the lot of the proposed building or structure and the exact size and location of any existing buildings or structures on the lot. Plans shall show the existing or proposed use of each building or part of building and such other information with regard to the building or lot, parking areas, distances from nearby buildings or neighboring lots as may be necessary to determine and provide for the enforcement of this ordinance. One (1) copy of such plans shall be returned to the owner or agent when such plans shall have been approved by the building inspector. The lot and location of the building thereon shall be staked out on the ground and approved by the building inspector or his designee before starting any construction. If the proposed excavation, filling or construction as set forth in the application are in conformity with the provisions of this ordinance and other ordinances of the city then in force, the building inspector or his designee shall issue a building permit upon the payment of the required fee. If a building permit is refused, the building inspector shall state such refusal in writing with the cause. Construction shall be started within six (6) months from the date of issuance of this building permit. Record of application and plats or plans shall be kept by the City of Winder. 201.3. Certificate of occupancy; required issuance: A certificate of occupancy issued by the building inspector or his designee is required in advance of occupancy or use of: (a) A building hereafter erected. (b) A building hereafter altered so as to affect the front, side or rear yards thereof or its height. (c) A building or premises in which there is a change of use. Within three (3) days after the application for a certificate of occupancy, a final inspection of the property in question shall be made. The building inspector or his designee shall issue a certificate of occupancy if the building is found to conform to the provisions of this ordinance and the statements made in the application for the building permit. A record of all certificates shall be kept on file in the office of the building inspector planning office and copies shall be furnished on request to any person having a proprietary or tenancy interest in the building or land involved. (Ord. ( W-9-17 ) of 5-2-17, §§ VII—IX) Sec. 202. - Inspections. The building inspector has the power to make inspections of buildings, their construction, use and land (its use, development and subdivision) to determine if they conform to the requirements of this ordinance. If the building inspector shall determine that any such building or land does not conform to this ordinance, he shall notify the owner thereof in writing of the manner in which such building or land does not conform, and the owner shall have sixty (60) days in which to remedy the conditions therein specified; provided, however, that the building inspector may, in his discretion, extend the time for compliance with any such notice. Sec. 203. - Penalties. Any person, firm, corporation or other entity violating any provision of the Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance, City of Winder, Georgia, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-8 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Winder, Georgia. Each offense shall constitute a separate offense for each day such violation shall continue. (Ord. ( W-18-17 ) of 9-14-17) ARTICLE XXI. - BOARD OF APPEALS
Sec. 210. - Composition. For the purpose of this ordinance, the mayor and council and one (1) member of the planning board shall serve as the zoning board of appeals. The mayor, or his/her designee shall preside at all proceedings of the board of appeals. (Ord. No. W-12-03, 7-8-03) Sec. 211. - Public hearings. The board of appeals shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeals or other matters referred to it and give public notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation at least fifteen (15) days and not more than forty-five (45) days before the hearing. Upon a hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. Prior to any hearing, any matter to be brought before the board of appeals shall first be referred to the planning board for a recommendation. The planning board shall meet and make a recommendation within forty-five (45) days of the date any matter is referred to it, or the matter shall be deemed to have been recommended for approval. The recommendation of the planning board shall be presented at the hearing along with any other public input. 211.1. Signs. Upon the filing of a petition or application for a variance, conditional use, appeal of an inspector's decision or related matter, the city will cause to be erected in a conspicuous place on the property in question a sign which shall state that a variance, conditional use, appeal of an inspector's decision or related matter concerning the subject property has been filed with the city. The sign shall contain the time, date and place of the zoning board of appeals hearing and a telephone number where additional information may be obtained. The city may charge a fee, set from time to time by the mayor and council, to cover all administrative costs, including sign and advertising costs. (Ord. No. W-12-03, 7-8-03; Ord. ( W-9-17 ) of 5-2-17, § XIV) Sec. 212. - Stay of proceedings. An appeal to the board of appeals stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the building inspector certifies to the board after the notice of appeal shall have been filed with him that, by reason of facts stated in the certificate, a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life and property. Sec. 213. - Powers and duties. The board of appeals shall have the following powers and duties: 213.1. Generally: To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged that there is error in any order, requirement, decision or determination of the building inspector in the enforcement of this ordinance. 213.2. Special exceptions, questions: To hear and decide applications for special exceptions of this ordinance and for decision of any special questions upon which the board of appeals is authorized by this ordinance to pass. 213.3. Variance: To authorize upon appeal in specific cases such variance from the terms of this ordinance as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of this ordinance will, in an individual case, result in unnecessary hardship so that the spirit of the ordinance shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured and substantial justice done. Such variance may be granted in such individual case of practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship upon a finding by the board of appeals that: (a) There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular piece of property in question because of its size, shape or topography; and (b) The application of the ordinance to this particular piece of property would create an unnecessary hardship; and (c) Relief, if granted, would not cause a substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purpose of this ordinance. Provided, however, that no variance shall be granted for the use of land or building or structure that is prohibited by this ordinance. In exercising the above powers, the board of appeals may, in conformity with the provisions of this ordinance, reverse or affirm, wholly or in part, or may modify the order, requirements, decision or determination of the building inspector and, to that end, shall have all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken and may issue or direct the issuance of a permit. ARTICLE XXII. - ZONING CHANGES AND ORDINANCE AMENDMENTS
Sec. 220. - Authority of city council. The city council may from time to time amend, supplement or change by ordinance the boundaries of the use districts or zones established on the comprehensive zoning map or the regulations set forth in this ordinance. Any proposed amendment, supplement or change shall first be submitted to the planning board for its recommendation. Sec. 221. - Procedure. 221.1. Application: Any person desiring to submit a change in zoning shall have title to the property. Any person or persons, other than the city council or planning board, desiring to submit a petition requesting a change in zoning shall file such petition with a plat of the property attached thereto and a site plan as defined, together with adequate payment to cover administration costs, with the planning office. 221.2. Erection, contents of sign: Upon the filing of a petition for a change in zoning, the applicant shall at his or their expense cause to be erected in a conspicuous place on the property in question a sign of not less than nine (9) square feet, with not less than one and one-half inch letters upon a white background which shall read as follows: NOTICE TO THE PUBLIC A petition has been filed with the City Council requesting that this property be changed from Zone (insert present zone) to Zone (insert zone requested). A public hearing will be held at (insert place) on (date) at (time). All those objecting to this petition should be present to voice their objection. (Map and Parcel #) (Address) 221.3. Advertising hearing: At least fifteen (15) days and not more than forty-five (45) days before such public hearing, the planning office shall advertise such hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 221.3.1 Conduct of hearing: The public hearing shall be held by the planning board as follows: a. All public hearings on zoning amendments shall be chaired by either the chairman of the planning board or his designee. b. A secretary shall record the minutes of the public hearing. If requested by any party, verbatim transcripts of the public hearing can be prepared but only if requested, arranged, and purchased in advance by the requesting party. c. The minutes of the public hearing and all documentary evidence submitted at the public hearing shall become a permanent part of the applicant's file. d. The chairman of the planning board or his designee shall preside at the public hearing and shall identify speakers, maintain order, and conduct the public hearing. e. The process to be followed in conducting these hearings shall be as follows: The presiding officer shall open the hearing by stating the specific zoning amendment being considered at the public hearing. The presiding officer shall determine the number of attendees who desire to testify or present evidence at the hearing. When there are a large number of individuals wishing to testify at a hearing, the presiding officer may invoke time limits on individual speakers. In such cases, these time limits shall apply to all speakers. The presiding officer shall recognize the individual parties wishing to testify on present evidence and allow them to present this information. Once all parties have concluded their testimony, the presiding officer shall adjourn the public hearing. f. At hearings on proposed zoning decisions, proponents and opponents of each zoning decision shall be allotted no less than ten (10) minutes per side for the presentation of data, evidence and opinion. 221.4. The following standards shall be considered by the governing authority in decisions involving: (a) Adoption of a zoning ordinance; (b) Amendment of an existing zoning ordinance; or (c) Amending the official zoning map so as to rezone property from one (1) classification to another: 1. Existing uses and zoning of nearby property. 2. The extent to which property values are diminished by the particular zoning restrictions of current zoning. 3. The extent to which the decrease in property value of the plaintiff's property promotes the health, safety and general welfare of the community: a. Would the change alter the population density pattern and thereby increase the load on community facilities, such as schools, sewers and streets? b. Will a change adversely influence living conditions in the neighborhood? c. Will a change stimulate any adverse environmental impact, such as soil erosion, drainage problems, restriction of light or pollution? d. Will a change adversely affect property values in adjacent areas, and to what extent is the property value of the subject site diminished by the present zoning? 4. The relative gain to the public as compared to the hardship imposed upon the individual property owner. 5. The suitability of the subject property for its current zoning. 6. The suitability of the subject property for the proposed zoning. 7. The length of time the property has been vacant as zoned considered in the context of land development in the area in the vicinity of the property. 8. Conformity with or divergence from applicable local or state laws or ordinances and land use plans or guidelines, if any. 9. The availability of adequate sites for the proposed use in districts that permit such use. 10. The suitability of the site for the proposed use relative to the requirements set forth in the zoning ordinance, such as off-street parking, yard requirements, buffer zones and open space. 221.5. Disclosure of campaign contributions: When any applicant has given, within two (2) years immediately preceding the filing of the application for the rezoning action, campaign contributions amounting to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or more or gifts having a total value of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or more to an official of the city, it shall be the duty of the applicant and any attorney representing the applicant to file a disclosure report with the city council showing: 1. The name of the official of the city to whom the campaign contribution or gift was given; 2. The amount (in dollars) of each campaign contribution made by the applicant to the official during the two (2) years immediately preceding the filing of the application for rezoning and the date of each such contribution; and 3. An enumeration and description of each gift having a value of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or more made by the applicant to the official during the two (2) years immediately preceding the filing of the application for rezoning. 221.6. Duty of planning board: The planning board shall make a recommendation to the city council within thirty (30) days of the public hearing, or the request shall be deemed to have been recommended for approval. 221.7. Time period for rezoning: If an amendment to the zoning ordinance to accomplish a rezoning is defeated by the local government, the same property may not again be considered for rezoning until the expiration of at least six (6) months immediately following the defeat of the rezoning by the local government.
